headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to TE Connectivity First Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Call. [Operator Instructions] And as a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to TE Connectivity First Quarter 2016 Earnings Release Call. [Operator Instructions] And as a reminder, today's conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Sujal Shaw, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining our conference call to discuss TE Connectivity's First Quarter Results. With me today are Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Lynch; President, Terrence Curtin; and Chief Financial Officer, Bob Hau. During t
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining our conference call to discuss TE Connectivity's First Quarter Results. With me today are Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Lynch; President, Terrence Curtin; and Chief Financial Officer, Bob Hau. 
During the course of this call, we'll be providing certain forward-looking information, and we ask you to review the forward-looking cautionary statements included in today's press release. In addition, we will you certain non-GAAP measures in our discussion this morning, and we ask you to review the sections of our press release and accompanying slide presentation that address the use of these items. Press release and related tables, along with the slide presentation, can be found on the Investor Relations portion of our website at te.com. [Operator Instructions] 
Now let me turn the call over to Tom for opening comments.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for joining us today, and here are the key takeaways from today's call. We've begun fiscal 2016 with a quarter of solid execution, delivering $0.84 in adjusted EPS, $0.08 above the high end of guidance with sales slightly above our midpoint. This w
componenttext:
Thanks for joining us today, and here are the key takeaways from today's call. We've begun fiscal 2016 with a quarter of solid execution, delivering $0.84 in adjusted EPS, $0.08 above the high end of guidance with sales slightly above our midpoint. This was driven by strong performance in our Transportation segment and SubCom business in combination with tight cost management in light of the macroenvironment. Excluding the impact of currency exchange rates, we want adjusted EPS was flat year-over-year and adjusted operating margins of 15.7% were ahead of expectations. For the full year 2016, we are reiterating our adjusted EPS guidance of $4. This is 11% year-over-year growth and 15% growth in constant currency. Relative to our view last quarter, the Transportation segment is a little stronger. Global auto production expectation is improving. In industrial, our direct business with OEMs developed as expected and appears to be stabilizing, but sales through our distribution channel were weaker than expected, and the recovery is taking longer than anticipated. The oil and gas market remains very weak, with derivative effects impacting some other industrial markets. The midpoint of our annual guidance assumes 2% global auto production growth in our fiscal year. We're also assuming sequential improvements in industrial sales and orders in the second quarter and into the second half. 
For the full year in communications, we assume double-digit growth in SubCom, second half growth in Appliances and continued declines in Data and Devices. By region, we assume that the overall U.S. and European economies continue to grow slowly and China returns to growth in our markets in the second half. We continue to take a balanced approach with our capital strategy and over time expect to return approximately 2/3 of our free cash flow to shareholders through dividends and buybacks, with 1/3 of free cash being used for acquisitions and we'll talk more about this later in the call. 
We're very pleased with the performance of the businesses we acquired last year, and we'll continue to look for acquisition opportunities that broaden our ability to address harsh environment applications and provide integrated solutions to our customers. We believe that integration is another emerging secular trend for our business, and we are well positioned to capitalize with our broad portfolio of products. 
In Sensors, our unmatched presence across virtually every industry, coupled with the broad technology and product portfolio we acquired, is enabling us to expand our design win pipeline across market verticals and provide integrated solutions in certain applications. In Medical, we have increased our presence in the high-growth, minimally invasive market and are well positioned to provide integrated solutions to our customers that incorporate our connectors, sensors, fine wire technology and material science know-how. 
While we can't control the macroenvironment and inevitable economic cycles, we have positioned TE around harsh environment applications and continued to benefit directly from the secular trends of electronic content growth. We believe TE is uniquely positioned to provide highly engineered solutions that integrate connectors, sensors and other technologies to improve reliability, lower cost and increase performance, making the company an increasingly valued partner to our customers. And we have secured several key integrated solutions design wins, particularly with major auto OEMs over the last several months throughout this point. 
Now please turn to Slide 3 for a summary of Q1 results. While we continue to have the backdrop of a challenging macroenvironment, we generated adjusted EPS above the high end of the guidance with sales slightly above the midpoint of guidance. Sales of $2.8 billion were down 7% year-over-year but down only 1% in constant currency. Adjusted EPS was down 6% year-over-year and flat in constant currency. Performance of our guidance in the quarter was driven in the strength of our Transportation segment and higher sales in SubCom as a key program moved to the completion earlier than expected. This, coupled with tight cost control, more than offset industrial being a little weaker than expected in the quarter. 
We generated adjusted operating margins of 15.7% in Q1, which were ahead of expectations, and our adjusted EBITDA margins were 21%. During the quarter, we returned $1.4 billion to shareholders, including $1.3 billion in share buybacks. The Board of Directors also approved a recommendation to raise our dividend by 12% to an annual rate of $1.48 per share. We expect this to be approved by shareholders in March and be effective in June. We also paid $127 million in dividend in the quarter. In addition, we returned approximately $1.3 billion of cash to shareholders through the share buyback. 
While down year-over-year due primarily to weakness in China, our Transportation segment sales were above expectations with better-than-expected demand in China. Though China was weak, but it was not as weak as we thought. In the industrial segment, our direct business with OEMs performed about as expected, but we did see lower sales through the distribution channel. Overall, we continued to perform well in harsh environment applications. Last year's acquisition in Sensors and Medical gaining momentum. And during the quarter, we announced the sale of our Circuit Protection business, which is on track to close later this quarter. 
Before we get into the segment update, I'd like to provide a brief insight into the order pattern, which will help provide a baseline for our results and expectations. Now please turn to Slide 4. 
Organic orders were down 3% from the prior year but were better than our expectations 90 days ago. Orders were up 3% sequentially excluding SubCom, and our book-to-bill was 1.04. Orders were up 11% sequentially on an organic basis and better than expected. These data points re positive indicators for our expectations of second half sales growth. One area that doesn't remain weak is the distribution channel where expectations of sales and orders recovery has pushed out slightly versus our prior year. Distribution accounts for about 15% of our total sales. Transportation orders improved 7% sequentially, reflecting incremental growth in global auto production expectations. During the quarter, we saw our industrial orders stabilizing growth slightly sequentially, with direct orders improving in line with expectations and weakness in the channel that I previously mentioned. Communications orders x SubCom declined 9% sequentially, driven by previously announced product exits and weakness in the distribution channel. 
To provide a little additional color on China, while both orders and sales were down year-over-year in aggregate in Q1, we are seeing improvement in auto production and saw a year-over-year organic growth in orders of Transportation. We continue to see China weakness in the industrial and communications segment but are expecting growth in the second half as inventories become more imbalanced. Excluding SubCom, our book-to-bill ratio was 1.04 in Q1 with all segments book-to-bill exceeding 1.0. 
With that backdrop, I'll now turn it over to Terrence to cover each of our segments in more detail.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. If you could please turn to Slide 5 and we'll start with Transportation Solutions. Sales grew 1% organically in the quarter, above our guidance expectations due to China sales being stronger than we anticipated.
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. If you could please turn to Slide 5 and we'll start with Transportation Solutions. 
Sales grew 1% organically in the quarter, above our guidance expectations due to China sales being stronger than we anticipated. Overall, segment organic growth of 1% was driven by Automotive and Sensors. Our auto sales organic growth of 1% in the quarter was driven by Europe growing 6% and North America growth of 3% offsetting the expected reductions in China that Tom talked about. With the orders that we experienced, along with production schedules, we expect China to return to growth in the second quarter, reflecting the positive demand impacts from the government tax incentives that are driving increased production levels. 
For fiscal 2016, we now expect global auto production to be up 2% to just under 88 million vehicles, with China production up 6% compared to 2015. This compares favorably to our view last quarter when we expected global auto production with China production growth of only 2%. We continue to be confident that our auto business can grow well ahead of production as its included in our annual guidance, and this is driven by electronic content growth and a rich pipeline of platform ramps from design wins generated over the past several years. 
As expected, our Commercial Transportation business was down year-over-year, driven by a weak global construction in agriculture market and weakness in the North America heavy truck area. While our sales declined versus last year, our organic orders were up 10% sequentially as we're seeing signs of this business stabilizing, and we expect to be up to flat low single digits on an organic basis for the year. 
Turning to Sensors. Our business continue to show strong momentum in the quarter in both sales and design wins. Along with our acquisition rationale, we are using the existing TE go-to-market teams to take new products and system-level solutions to our customers. These results in new sensor program awards across multiple market verticals. TE is uniquely positioned with the world's broadest portfolio of connector and sensors solutions, and we have recently been awarded design wins in the automotive space and integrate multiple components to provide a complete solution to our customers. In this segment, adjusted operating income was $280 million in the first quarter. This was down year-over-year due to currency, a change in product mix and our continuous investment for growth in Automotive and Sensors businesses. Adjusted operating margins came in higher than we expected, and we anticipate the second half margin to be at 20% or above. 
Please if you could turn to Page 6 to discuss our Industrial Solutions segment. Aligned with our expectation, revenue in the segment declined 6% organically year-over-year in the first quarter. As Tom mentioned, we are being impacted by weakness in the distribution channel, which is almost 30% of the segment sales organically. Distribution sales were down 6% organically in the quarter as we see broad-based supply chain corrections occurring that we highlighted last quarter. Our direct sales to OEMs are improving in line with our expectations, and we saw our OEM orders improve sequentially by nearly 3% while orders through the channel partners remained flat sequentially. We currently expect that our distribution partners will continue to work through the second quarter to get in line with OEM demand. In addition to the distribution channel, we continue to be impacted by the oil and gas market. You can see on the slide, we broke this out separately this quarter, and it shows the 44% organic reduction in sales year-over-year in this market and the impact that's having on the segment. With the weakness in the oil and gas market, our business is now running at approximately $30 million per quarter, down from approximately $60 million per quarter a year ago. We have seen order rates stabilize around the $30 million level, and we expect a more favorable year-over-year compare in the second half. I also want to highlight that the low oil and gas prices are also having some derivative effect in other areas of the industrial segment, impacting sales in our Industrial Equipment business and areas like factory equipment and rail and also in helicopter demand, which affects our Aerospace business. These derivative effects are all reflected in our guidance in our results. 
In the commercial Aerospace and Defense business, our momentum remain strong, with the slight year-over-year decline driven by the defense business due to program timing. We remain very well positioned with our program wins in the Aerospace and expect to benefit from growth in the Commercial Aerospace and as the defense market continues to improve. 
Our Energy business grew 4% organically, with strengths in Europe and the Americas more than offsetting softness in China. From an adjusted operating income perspective, it was $78 million in the first quarter, down year-over-year as expected due to the impact of currency, declines in our higher-margin oil and gas business and 6% organic decline in the channel. If you exclude the oil and gas business and FX impacts, our operating margins remained constant year-over-year, reflecting the benefit of our TOA program as well as cost management. 
If you could turn to Slide 7, please, so I can talk about Communications Solutions. In the first quarter, the segment revenue of $617 million was down 6% and 3% organically as expected. Our SubCom business saw strong year-over-year growth as we successfully completed the America, Europe connect program earlier than our original plan. We now expect SubCom to grow low double digits for the full year, which is slightly better than our expectations 90 days ago. 
Our Data and Devices and Appliances businesses were impacted by the slowing in China as well as the supply chain adjustments by our distribution partner that I talked about in industrial. We expect this to be largely behind us as we head into the second half to the year. And just to remind you, Data and Devices growth is also impacted by the product exits that we initiated late in 2015 as part of our repositioning effort. From a margin perspective, adjusted operating margins expanded 380 basis points year-over-year, which was above expectations, driven by the early completion of the program in SubCom that we highlighted. 
Now let me turn it over to Bob, who'll cover the financials.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terrence, and good morning, everyone. Please turn to Slide 8 where I'll provide more details on earnings. Adjusted operating income was $444 million, down 5% in constant currency due to investments in Transportation, impacts of oil and gas weakn
componenttext:
Thanks, Terrence, and good morning, everyone. Please turn to Slide 8 where I'll provide more details on earnings. 
Adjusted operating income was $444 million, down 5% in constant currency due to investments in Transportation, impacts of oil and gas weakness and the distribution inventory corrections impacting our industrial segment that Terrence covered. Including $30 million of foreign currency headwinds, operating income was down 11% in the prior year. GAAP operating income was $298 [ph] million and included $6 million of acquisition-related charges as well as $40 million of restructuring other charges related to Data and Devices product exits, elimination of corporate stranded cost from the BNS divestiture and general cost reductions. Our adjusted EPS was $0.84 for the quarter, down $0.05 from the prior year with reduced volume from higher-margin products and negative impacts from foreign currency exchange rates offsetting incremental benefits from the share buyback. Excluding the $0.05 impact from foreign currency, adjusted EPS was flat to the prior year. GAAP EPS was $0.83 for the quarter and included acquisition-related charges of $0.01, restructuring and other charges of $0.07 and $0.07 from tax-related income. I now expect approximately $85 million of restructuring charges for the full year 2016, a $10 million increase from our prior guidance 90 days ago. 
Now please turn to Slide 9. While we remain in a challenging environment, the progress we've made with TEOA and productivity initiatives enabled the business to demonstrate resiliency as reflected in our margins. Our adjusted gross margin in the quarter was 33.4%. While this was down from last year due to lower sales in higher-margin products, it's up 90 basis points sequentially from Q4. As Terrence discussed in the industrial section, we're seeing softness in some higher-margin businesses like oil and gas and lower sales in the distribution channel. 
Adjusted operating margins declined 70 basis points, driven by lower volume in product mix but benefiting from the early completion of the SubCom program in the quarter. Total operating expenses were $502 million in the quarter, down 8% from the prior year. We continue to technically manage discretionary spending but are also continuing to invest in our harsh businesses. In the quarter, cash from continuing operations was $367 million, and our free cash flow was $237 million, up from prior year levels due to lower capital -- working capital and reduced revenue and timing of SubCom payments. 
We continue to have a balanced capital allocation strategy. In Q1, we returned at $1.4 billion to shareholders, including $1.3 billion in buybacks. In the quarter, we bought back nearly 21 million shares, executing against our commitment to returning the proceeds in broadband networks divestiture. We're also introducing a chart on EBITDA margins, which better shows the profitability performance of our businesses, including acquisitions. EBITDA margins in Q1 were 21% and shows our margin resiliency despite lower sales levels. We continue to be pleased with the operating performance of our business, especially in light of the challenging macro backdrop. 
Also, you may have seen in the 8-K filed yesterday, Tyco International on behalf of TE Connectivity, has entered into an agreement with the Internal Revenue Service to resolve all disputes related to the previously disclosed intercompany debt issues. The resolution would result in a total cash payment to the IRS from TE Connectivity of between $147 million and $163 million, which includes all interest and penalties. We're pleased with the proposed settlement and look forward to having this behind us in the near future. Of course, we've also added a balance sheet and cash flow summary in the Appendix for additional details. 
Now I'll turn it back to Tom.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. Please turn to Slide 10, and I will cover Q2 guidance at a high level with additional details provided in the slide deck. We expect Q2 revenue your $2.88 billion to $3.08 million, down 3% or 1% organically; and adjusted EPS of $0.84 to $0.92,
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. Please turn to Slide 10, and I will cover Q2 guidance at a high level with additional details provided in the slide deck. We expect Q2 revenue your $2.88 billion to $3.08 million, down 3% or 1% organically; and adjusted EPS of $0.84 to $0.92, down approximately 3% year-over-year at the midpoint or flat in constant currency. Versus our view last quarter, we expect Transportation to be a bit stronger, industrial will be a bit weaker and communications to be impacted by the early completion of the SubCom program we discussed earlier. Most of that was in Q2 when we guided last time. For the full year, we expect revenue of $12.3 billion at the midpoint, up 1% versus the prior year and reflecting 4% organic growth at midpoint. We are reducing top line by about $100 million, reflecting the sale of our Circuit Protection business that we expect to complete this quarter. Our adjusted EPS guidance remained at $4 and represents year-over-year growth of 11% at midpoint. On a constant currency basis, revenue is expected to grow over 3%, and adjusted EPS is expected to grow by 15% year-over-year. Versus our prior view, Transportation is expected to have higher growth, industrial is a little weaker and communications is weaker, factoring the impact of the sale of the Circuit Protection business. I think you've heard the Constantine or Transportation a little better; industrial, a little weaker; but overall, no big change from the prior guidance. Our full year outlook is based on the following market and regional assumptions: in Transportation, we expect mid-single-digit actual and high single-digit organic growth. We're assuming that global auto production is up 2% year-over-year, which is an improvement from our prior view of flat production. We're anticipating China auto production to grow 6% year-over-year. We expect the year -- another strong -- another year of strong growth in our Sensors business. In industrial, we are assuming flat actual and low single-digit organic growth. We have seen orders stabilize in some industrial end markets and assume inventories come into balance by the end of Q2, ending the negative supply chain effect on our business. We continue to assume a weak oil and gas market, and we'll continue to see the signs of the negative impact in other adjacent markets in the industrial space. This is also factored into our guidance. 
In communications, we assume high single-digit actual and low single-digit organic declines, with growth in SubCom and Appliances being more than offset by product exits and the sale of the Circuit Protection business in Data and Devices. By region, we assume Europe and the U.S. to continue to improve, with China markets rebounding in the second half. Outside of auto, China markets are as expected 90 days ago. 
Our guidance does assume a 53rd week and currency exchange rates. As the year progresses, we have much less of a headwind from FX translation and an increased earnings tailwind from our share repurchase program. We remain positive on our outlook and have several levers to drive growth in a very challenging macroenvironment. As a result of the transformation of our portfolio and increased focus on harsh applications, we are well positioned with differentiated solutions for our customers. Secular trend of content growth is increasingly apparent in our served markets, and our ability to produce integrated solutions at all system-level challenges for our customers will enable TE to continue to become an even more valuable strategic partner for our customers in the future. These factors, combined with our TEOA initiatives and capital strategy, are expected to drive consistent double-digit earnings growth. 
Now to Joel, let's open it up for questions.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question is going to come from the line of Amit Daryanani of RBC Capital Markets.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess, just to start with, on the industrial segment, could you just talk about the margin ramp or expectations as you go forward after the December quarter numbers? And is there incremental cost-cutting initiatives that you guys are thinking about t
componenttext: So I guess, just to start with, on the industrial segment, could you just talk about the margin ramp or expectations as you go forward after the December quarter numbers? And is there incremental cost-cutting initiatives that you guys are thinking about to help drive these margins potentially towards the mid-teens of corporate averages?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's Bob. Good morning. We do have some increment the restructuring as I mentioned. Our prior guidance included $75 million of restructuring. We've now raised that to $85 million. In the first quarter, we spent $35 million. So the actions that we did have
componenttext: It's Bob. Good morning. We do have some increment the restructuring as I mentioned. Our prior guidance included $75 million of restructuring. We've now raised that to $85 million. In the first quarter, we spent $35 million. So the actions that we did have planned for the year, we pulled the trigger a little bit faster, so we'll see some benefit of that in the latter part of the year as well as the increased spending. That's not particularly directed at industrial. It's more directed at Data and Devices where we got the product exits in corporate spending overall, which impacts all of our segments from the BNS stranded cost. There's some additional activity and additional benefit in oil and gas that will obviously benefit industrial. Overall, as we see volume recover and, in particular, as we work through the final implications of the distribution inventory channel recovery in the second half of the year, you'll see margins lift obviously at 11% in the current quarter with revenue down and, in particular, oil and gas high margin and channel, distribution channel very high margin. We're seeing a negative impact that improves into the second half of the year.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just as a follow-up, the guide, I apologize if I missed this. You're looking at sales to be up rather nicely, sequentially but the EPS guide or the operating margins are implied to be down. Is there a gross margin dynamic that's driving i
componenttext: Got it. And then just as a follow-up, the guide, I apologize if I missed this. You're looking at sales to be up rather nicely, sequentially but the EPS guide or the operating margins are implied to be down. Is there a gross margin dynamic that's driving it sequentially? Or is OpEx going to ramp up? And if so, can you just talk about why and how much?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there's probably a number of moving pieces as you move from Q1 to Q2. Probably the biggest one and Tom and Terrence alluded to this a little bit and I gave a brief comment on it on my opening comments, part of the benefit in Q1 was the timing of the
componenttext: Yes, there's probably a number of moving pieces as you move from Q1 to Q2. Probably the biggest one and Tom and Terrence alluded to this a little bit and I gave a brief comment on it on my opening comments, part of the benefit in Q1 was the timing of the completion of the SubCom program. That's very high margin. As you ramp up the SubCom program, you typically record very good margins on that last, last gasp spending there. And that is pure timing that was completed earlier. So we saw the benefit in Q1. That falls strictly out of Q2 and, to some extent, Q3.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Next, we'll go to the line of Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Next, we'll go to the line of Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question for Tom. The opportunity in auto seems intriguing in terms of you're talking about integrated products, so I just wanted to get some background there in terms of the technology pieces you have to offer, really, as you interact with customers and
componenttext: Question for Tom. The opportunity in auto seems intriguing in terms of you're talking about integrated products, so I just wanted to get some background there in terms of the technology pieces you have to offer, really, as you interact with customers and suppliers kind of how you see the market evolving there and how you can plan to that?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. In our core connector business, we have an incredible range of product, and we're in every facets of the vehicle so -- and that's reported by almost 2,000 engineers facing the customer. So you have this tremendous presence at every customer with a w
componenttext: Sure. In our core connector business, we have an incredible range of product, and we're in every facets of the vehicle so -- and that's reported by almost 2,000 engineers facing the customer. So you have this tremendous presence at every customer with a wide range of connectivity products. But we also, of course, now have sensors and a broad range of sensor technology. We have dealing in protective products. We have relays. We've been doing integration on a very small scale for many years. And with the advent of the Sensors in the product line, the ability to go into certain application, not every application, but the more complex application and full 3 or 4 different products together, which might have been handled by 3 or 4 suppliers before and integrate them into a subsystem, take that cost base, wait and from a customer perspective, it's 1 supplier to deal with. We've had -- we've been doing this in the past, but the addition of sensors into the product line has really opened up much more for us, and we've had some very nice designing wins, I mean, significant designing wins in the last 6 months that they won't start shipping probably for about 1.5 years to 2 years. It's just broad range of products and all these engineers we have sitting in front of the customer. And we know the architecture is almost as well as our customers. We're doing this for so light, and we have that many engineers, we have this deep knowledge and they share with us what they're trying to accomplish. They're not just -- they're telling us this is what we're trying to do, and that really opens it up for us to bring in the solution.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just as a follow-up, certainly we're seeing a lot of relative pressure in the equity markets. I'm just curious as you look at your M&A pipeline and on the private side of your seeing much change, do think there could be opportunities? Any
componenttext: Got it. And then just as a follow-up, certainly we're seeing a lot of relative pressure in the equity markets. I'm just curious as you look at your M&A pipeline and on the private side of your seeing much change, do think there could be opportunities? Any thoughts on that for M&A?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, our strategy is around harsh environment connectivity and sensors, and we have a robust pipeline that's based on our product strategy. So the last -- the first part of your question, that's in a sense what drives our acquisition strategy. We're no
componenttext: I mean, our strategy is around harsh environment connectivity and sensors, and we have a robust pipeline that's based on our product strategy. So the last -- the first part of your question, that's in a sense what drives our acquisition strategy. We're not just buying parts. We want there to be customer synergy as well. So yes, we expect last year we acquired acquisitions worth about $700 million of revenue. Our goal is to continue to plug in technology and products like we've been doing because with all this engineering presence and all the sales and marketing presence in front of the customer, it's just think of is adding more fools into our tool bag and that's what customers want. So it's a pretty powerful model we have. And as you know, we're selective. we don't do that many. We look hard. We make sure that there is a good fit, but we have a pretty active pipeline. Terrence, do you want to add to that?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think, Tom, you handled it well. And I think when you look at last year, we did do 4 last year. Certainly, the big ones were around Measurement and the sensors that Tom talked about. Also, in the Medical space where -- that is another example of a h
componenttext: No, I think, Tom, you handled it well. And I think when you look at last year, we did do 4 last year. Certainly, the big ones were around Measurement and the sensors that Tom talked about. Also, in the Medical space where -- that is another example of a harsh environment application leveraging the capabilities that Tom talked about to your first question, Craig. So I think you're going to continue to see things like that. And I think when you think about the pipeline momentum we have, we feel very good about it. And I don't think there's anything that has meaningfully changed even with all the macro backdrop as we look at the pipeline to sort of answer one element of your question.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Wamsi Mohan with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Wamsi Mohan with Bank of America.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your restructuring charges incrementally are going up $10 million over here, but is that enough given that the near-term weakness in Data and Devices is really pronounced? Organic revenues were down close to $90 million. It's the largest decline in the sh
componenttext: Your restructuring charges incrementally are going up $10 million over here, but is that enough given that the near-term weakness in Data and Devices is really pronounced? Organic revenues were down close to $90 million. It's the largest decline in the share dollar amount relative to much larger segments. I'm curious how you see this progressing, especially given your also divesting the CPD business. And then I have a follow-up.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The $85 million, as I mentioned, is a small increase. We did spend quite a bit of restructuring last year, particularly at data and devices proactively get some of the cost as we execute against those product exits that we initiated in the first part of 2
componenttext: The $85 million, as I mentioned, is a small increase. We did spend quite a bit of restructuring last year, particularly at data and devices proactively get some of the cost as we execute against those product exits that we initiated in the first part of 2015, we took a lot of restructuring charges and started actions. And as we continue to execute against those exits and the revenue decline, that's what's driving some of the incremental spend. So we got out in front of it early on in 2015 as we announced those exits, and we continue to take a cost where appropriate.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. As my follow-up, so what's the margin trajectory that we should assume sort of x SubCom within Data and Devices? Should we be expecting some of these past actions to start to bear fruit from the margin front here through the next cou
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. As my follow-up, so what's the margin trajectory that we should assume sort of x SubCom within Data and Devices? Should we be expecting some of these past actions to start to bear fruit from the margin front here through the next couple of quarters? I mean, you're doing most operating margin improvement in that segment came from better SubCom performance in this quarter?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Tom. I would say, you'll see it next year. The market outlook is pretty weak, and we're dropping -- we're getting out a lot of revenue. Most of them is very, very little margin. But by the time we get through this year's restructuring and the prod
componenttext: This is Tom. I would say, you'll see it next year. The market outlook is pretty weak, and we're dropping -- we're getting out a lot of revenue. Most of them is very, very little margin. But by the time we get through this year's restructuring and the product exits, we expect that we'll begin to build margin momentum. Because you've heard her say before, about 2/3 of the business is very good solid business. The core kind of highly-engineered products that we do, so next year. I wouldn't look for much this year.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to remind you, we got product exits or the divestiture of the Circuit Protection business that's part of Data and Devices that will impact us in the second half of the year. We expect to complete that here in the current quarter.
componenttext: Just to remind you, we got product exits or the divestiture of the Circuit Protection business that's part of Data and Devices that will impact us in the second half of the year. We expect to complete that here in the current quarter.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Matt Sharon with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Matt Sharon with Stifel.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016

componenttext: Question, Tom, on your commentary regarding the distribution inventory correction that looks like it's extending here another quarter. Are you getting a sense of that sellout of distribution has stabilized and relatively normal or -- and there's just an inventory build that has to be reduced here? Or are you getting sense of that sell-in for -- sorry, sellout for distribution is still weak or maybe getting weaker?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm going to let Terrence handle that one. He was just with that group, so he'll give you a real
componenttext: I'm going to let Terrence handle that one. He was just with that group, so he'll give you a real

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Couple of insights. I think when you look at it, one of the things that was weaker, we actually saw the inventory come down as expected with our partners, but sell-through is little weaker than we expected, which is why we see supply chain correction happ
componenttext: Couple of insights. I think when you look at it, one of the things that was weaker, we actually saw the inventory come down as expected with our partners, but sell-through is little weaker than we expected, which is why we see supply chain correction happening impacting our channel partner. So the inventory bring down in the fourth quarter on what they had -- but the sell-through was weaker. What we look at is also the direct order patterns that we see, and what we see the direct order patterns out of turn that Tom talked about as well as what we're seeing elsewhere, it does look like it's going to be another quarter or so that we're going to have our partners and expect that sell-through to improve. So when you look at this quarter, we still expect it to be a weak sell-through quarter. I think when you take our segments like industrial, I think what we talk about this quarter, we'll expect the same sort of same next quarter from the channel element of it. So they're still being worked through, and sell-through was a little bit worse than we thought.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Fair enough. It looks like some of the suppliers have already announced earnings have talked about inventory correction having played out. They tend to lead by a quarter or so, so that may be encouraging. And just as my follow-up regarding the recen
componenttext: Okay. Fair enough. It looks like some of the suppliers have already announced earnings have talked about inventory correction having played out. They tend to lead by a quarter or so, so that may be encouraging. And just as my follow-up regarding the recent divestitures of BNS and the other Circuit Protection business. Are there things here that you're looking at to divest? Or is that pretty much done specifically in the Data and Devices area where it looks like you're pruning down and deselecting revenue but are there other parts of that business that you could sell off?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Matt. You stated it well. It's much more around product line exit now. We're pretty -- we feel the portfolio is really strong with the 90% Sensors and connectors, 80% harsh. And even within the Data and Devices piece, I alluded to on the prior questio
componenttext: No, Matt. You stated it well. It's much more around product line exit now. We're pretty -- we feel the portfolio is really strong with the 90% Sensors and connectors, 80% harsh. And even within the Data and Devices piece, I alluded to on the prior question, products that are in there are very good products, consolidated and very profitable. So Circuit Protection was more of a stand-alone business. It was primarily in the Consumer space. So we're pretty much -- I never say never because the world is always changing, but the heavy lifting is behind us.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: From the line of Mike Woo with Macquarie.
componenttext: From the line of Mike Woo with Macquarie.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016

componenttext: It's Ryan, filling in for Mike. I just have a question on the destocking that you guys are calling to this next quarter. What our customers telling you guys that you'll be confident that this is happening? and do you have a rough sense of how much destocking the overall order and particularly in the industrial segment?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Couple of things. what our customers are telling us, certainly, we're seeing -- we have our orders with that increase. So as Tom highlighted, those in Transportation in industrial, we saw sequential order increases, and that was driven by direct activity.
componenttext: Couple of things. what our customers are telling us, certainly, we're seeing -- we have our orders with that increase. So as Tom highlighted, those in Transportation in industrial, we saw sequential order increases, and that was driven by direct activity. When it comes into the actual destocking amount, we did think that was around $20 million in the quarter. Actually, inventory, but the sell-through was a little bit worse than we expected, which is why we think it's going to work through in those quarter as we try to look at our channel partners do have to get back to OEM demand that has come back to parity at some point.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Would I would add to that, our actual orders from the partners were flat this quarter, and they had been declining for 3 quarters. So it's one data point. And as Terrence has said earlier, we got to see the sell-through pickup. But we feel like when you l
componenttext: Would I would add to that, our actual orders from the partners were flat this quarter, and they had been declining for 3 quarters. So it's one data point. And as Terrence has said earlier, we got to see the sell-through pickup. But we feel like when you look at the direct business, still growing, albeit low growth that over time, the channel converge with that. Now we're projecting it'll converge into low growth with that based on the trends we're seeing.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just a follow-up, there any material and market differences or product differences that explains the trend differences between OEM and distribution other than just destocking?
componenttext: Great. And just a follow-up, there any material and market differences or product differences that explains the trend differences between OEM and distribution other than just destocking?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think distribution is pretty broad-based, so the trends that we've actually seen has been broad-based, and that's why you see both the impact in the industrial segment and communications segment. When you look at the direct business, it varies by end ma
componenttext: I think distribution is pretty broad-based, so the trends that we've actually seen has been broad-based, and that's why you see both the impact in the industrial segment and communications segment. When you look at the direct business, it varies by end market dynamics. So certainly, things like commercial aerial are very strong; oil and gas, weak. But on the channel side, it's pretty broad-based.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: From the line of Shawn Harrison with Longbow Research.
componenttext: From the line of Shawn Harrison with Longbow Research.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to dig into auto a bit. You guys have always been pragmatic in terms of thinking about production rates and where the market is going, and it looks like fiscal '16 will be a little bit better than you initially thought. But are we entering kind o
componenttext: I wanted to dig into auto a bit. You guys have always been pragmatic in terms of thinking about production rates and where the market is going, and it looks like fiscal '16 will be a little bit better than you initially thought. But are we entering kind of a peak-ish production environment? I guess, the real question is how, long can kind of this strength kind of last knowing that content was always going to be your friend, but just wondering are there markets where you concerned that they could be peaking in 2016?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say, Sean, couple of different ways to think about it, and you really got to do it almost by region, right, because Europe are still not that back, right back to pre-financial crisis demand levels. The U.S., while calendar '15 was a record level, it's
componenttext: I'd say, Sean, couple of different ways to think about it, and you really got to do it almost by region, right, because Europe are still not that back, right back to pre-financial crisis demand levels. The U.S., while calendar '15 was a record level, it's still slightly the average age of a vehicle is slightly higher than normal. That did change dramatically, we might get worried. And of course, China is naturally slowing down but still going to be a pretty nice growth business, and that's 5% or 6% long term. And if you just look at the emerging markets and how many people are coming into the middle class, I mean the trends show it's a nice place to live and buy a car. So we think those trends are pretty good. And auto production last year slowed a little bit from the prior year this year. It's in the 2% range. So it feels very hot when you're in the U.S, but globally, it's still a little bit below. The fiscal '16 production rate is a little bit below its historical growth rate. And then on top of that, to your other point, the content growth is just consistent in every part of the vehicle, and we don't see that slowing. And then on top of that, the point I made in the comments about this integration, and it doesn't happen overnight, but it's real. I mean, we're being pulled into dozens of opportunities to do this, and this broad product range of ours enables that. There's multiple drivers. And then, of course, if the push stays on green, which I think it will even though will prices are very lower right now, the content in the hybrid vehicle or electric vehicle is a multiple of an internal combustion engine. So I think the positive drivers far outweigh the negative drivers. And I mean, there'll be cycles, but it's not like we've been in a boom cycle. It's been, over the last 5 years, a little bit higher than normal coming off the prior 5 years being lower than normal.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then as a follow-up, I guess, I'm struggling with the flat sales in industrial for the year because the first half of the year understanding all the dynamics are probably be going to be down with mid to high single digits year-over-year implying
componenttext: Okay. And then as a follow-up, I guess, I'm struggling with the flat sales in industrial for the year because the first half of the year understanding all the dynamics are probably be going to be down with mid to high single digits year-over-year implying you need a similar type of growth into the second half. The direct sales within industrial, I think you quote it was up 3% here in the December quarter, and so there's an implication that we either see some restocking event or some acceleration of true underlying demand in the second half across the entire portfolio. And so I guess I'm trying to dig into with a you expect any restocking in the second half of the year? Or where do you expect demand to accelerate or even held flat for the couple of year?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Couple of things, Sean. I do think you're high on an organic basis when you take currency out. So when you do look at it, I think we also were impacted in our fourth quarter on the channel effect as well, so there is a little bit of a favorable compare. B
componenttext: Couple of things, Sean. I do think you're high on an organic basis when you take currency out. So when you do look at it, I think we also were impacted in our fourth quarter on the channel effect as well, so there is a little bit of a favorable compare. But we do expect the overall direct business to be about plus 3%. We'll get some of the anniversary effects. We do assume that our channel business will get back to parity where it ran last year in the latter half, so there is a little bit of a restock that happens in quarter 4 due to quarter 4 being very weak that we talked about last fourth quarter. So there's a little bit of that effect that helps you get closer to flat. We do have programs that are launching, which is an uptick as well as some things in Medical that our launches due to the Medical side and the program wins there. So there are some things that a little bit of uppers in Medical in Comair that help make a little bit rich as well as the distribution channel getting back to more normalized level more of like it was in the middle of last year than where it was in the quarter 4 in time, in quarter 1 time and certainly the quarter 2 time that we're in right now.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That will be from the line of William Stein from SunTrust.
componenttext: That will be from the line of William Stein from SunTrust.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, I'd like to dig a little bit into the Sensors business, in particular, at Automotive. It sounds like these are integrating functions that might have already existed in the car. Is that a fair way to look at what's happening and dynamic in the this
componenttext: First, I'd like to dig a little bit into the Sensors business, in particular, at Automotive. It sounds like these are integrating functions that might have already existed in the car. Is that a fair way to look at what's happening and dynamic in the this part of your business maybe more of a share gain versus a competitor stand-alone sensor competitor in that area? Or is this more sort of new content?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a combination, Will. Where we're seeing the most opportunity now is in the powertrain as customers have all powertrain and the ability to integrate in a subsystem, sensors, connectors, rounding, ceiling, et cetera. So that's where a couple of more ex
componenttext: It's a combination, Will. Where we're seeing the most opportunity now is in the powertrain as customers have all powertrain and the ability to integrate in a subsystem, sensors, connectors, rounding, ceiling, et cetera. So that's where a couple of more exciting opportunities have been. But we think it will -- were you have sort of larger, more complex content, that's where the biggest opportunity.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe you can help me also think about your share and your opportunity in that market. I think you have a very substantial share of Automotive connectors and a very small share in Automotive Sensors. Are you seeing any initial effect in sales, not jus
componenttext: And maybe you can help me also think about your share and your opportunity in that market. I think you have a very substantial share of Automotive connectors and a very small share in Automotive Sensors. Are you seeing any initial effect in sales, not just design wins but actual sales in that market today? And what do you think is the pace of your share gains over the next several years?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it moved slowly, Will. I mean, no, it's not in our sales yet. I mean, we're selling at a high single-digit growth rate products we have in Sensors, so that is playing out very nicely according to plan. I would say the design rate and some of
componenttext: Yes, I think it moved slowly, Will. I mean, no, it's not in our sales yet. I mean, we're selling at a high single-digit growth rate products we have in Sensors, so that is playing out very nicely according to plan. I would say the design rate and some of the applications that we're penetrating is playing out ahead of plan, some of the more rich applications in the auto space. But it'll take some time. But you're right, significant connectors share, but by the way, we feel the opportunity continue gaining as we've been with the new applications we're bringing and very small sensor share because we didn't really have much of a sensor platform. But now with the acquisition, we have pressure, position, humidity, et cetera, I think we didn't have much before, and we're getting design wins across all of those in the auto space, Industrial Transportation space.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can squeeze in one clarification. Is the Circuit Protection revenue included in the March quarter guide? Or is that -- is it excluded from the full year? How's that working?
componenttext: I can squeeze in one clarification. Is the Circuit Protection revenue included in the March quarter guide? Or is that -- is it excluded from the full year? How's that working?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We expect the transaction to complete in the latter part of Q2, so it's in part of Q2. It's out for the second half of the year to drive the reduced guidance on a full year basis.
componenttext: We expect the transaction to complete in the latter part of Q2, so it's in part of Q2. It's out for the second half of the year to drive the reduced guidance on a full year basis.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that will be from the line of Steven Fox from Cross Research.
componenttext: And that will be from the line of Steven Fox from Cross Research.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions on margins. Just looking at off of the base of gross margins, you just reported the 33.4%. You mentioned a bunch of different mix issues going forward, distribution, SubCom, Appliance, et cetera. How is the gross margin get affe
componenttext: Just a couple of questions on margins. Just looking at off of the base of gross margins, you just reported the 33.4%. You mentioned a bunch of different mix issues going forward, distribution, SubCom, Appliance, et cetera. How is the gross margin get affected as we go through the rest of the fiscal year by all of these mix changes coming and going? And then I had a follow-up.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, there's always mix issues both favorable and unfavorable in the current quarter. We're really seeing a negative mix on oil and gas in the distribution channel, in particular, with a positive lift on the SubCom. The SubCom benefit in Q1 is a direct
componenttext: Steve, there's always mix issues both favorable and unfavorable in the current quarter. We're really seeing a negative mix on oil and gas in the distribution channel, in particular, with a positive lift on the SubCom. The SubCom benefit in Q1 is a direct timing out of largely Q2 but also Q3. Oil and gas, really, assuming will continue really through the end of the second quarter and when we start getting easier year-over-year compares. And the distribution channel, as Terrence pointed out, we've got one more quarter of this inventory correction and lower point-of-sale to work through. So you'll see that improve in the second half of the year. You also see lower FX impacts as we saw significant strengthening of the dollar really starting Q2 of last year, and so that year-over-year impact diminishes. And of course, you get the benefit of more restructuring savings and lower middle cost into the second half of the year that help lift the overall gross margin going forward.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it sounds like if you add all those up and that's probably a lot of Math to do right now, but you have more tailwinds around gross margin than headwinds as you get into the second half of the year even excluding the volume pick up that's there?
componenttext: So it sounds like if you add all those up and that's probably a lot of Math to do right now, but you have more tailwinds around gross margin than headwinds as you get into the second half of the year even excluding the volume pick up that's there?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just a quick follow-up question on the SubCom business. So I understand timing had an issue here in terms of the margin impact, but if you smooth out this quarter and last quarter in terms of volumes and then look to this double-digit growt
componenttext: Okay. And then just a quick follow-up question on the SubCom business. So I understand timing had an issue here in terms of the margin impact, but if you smooth out this quarter and last quarter in terms of volumes and then look to this double-digit growth you're talking about for the full year, where are the margins improving to in SubCom? How much increase is coming through and where the adverse maybe prior peak levels?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, what we said in SubCom is at $750 million to $800 million range we're at. We get into the double-digit range. As we see additional volume and new programs sort of come into force and effect volume were to ramp up say $1 billion, which is really where
componenttext: Yes, what we said in SubCom is at $750 million to $800 million range we're at. We get into the double-digit range. As we see additional volume and new programs sort of come into force and effect volume were to ramp up say $1 billion, which is really where we peaked in prior years, you start getting up into the company average, the 15%, 16% operating margins.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. So that's all on track once we smooth everything out here?
componenttext: Great. So that's all on track once we smooth everything out here?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, obviously, we saw better than that in our first quarter, and our full year guide is in that $800 million range. So we'll see double digits, and we won't be up in the company average this year.
componenttext: Yes, obviously, we saw better than that in our first quarter, and our full year guide is in that $800 million range. So we'll see double digits, and we won't be up in the company average this year.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That will be from the line of Sherri Scribner from Deutsch Bank.
componenttext: That will be from the line of Sherri Scribner from Deutsch Bank.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to make sure I understand the operating margin dynamics in the different segments. I think what you said was that Transportation, the margins in the second half would improve to 20% to higher for operating margins. Industrial would get bette
componenttext: I just wanted to make sure I understand the operating margin dynamics in the different segments. I think what you said was that Transportation, the margins in the second half would improve to 20% to higher for operating margins. Industrial would get better in the second half. And then further comps business, it gets -- margins gets worse in 2Q and 3Q, but I think you're implying that they get better in the fourth quarter. I just want to make sure I understood those dynamics.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Essentially, you're exactly right, Chery. On Transportation and industrial, very consistent with what we were trying to describe earlier in the call. From a Communications Solutions segment, I think the way to think about it is, if you adjust out the timi
componenttext: Essentially, you're exactly right, Chery. On Transportation and industrial, very consistent with what we were trying to describe earlier in the call. From a Communications Solutions segment, I think the way to think about it is, if you adjust out the timing benefit of the completion SubCom program, we still see improvement on a year-over-year basis. We're in double digits, just north of 10% operating margin. And we'll see kind of a negative impact of that into Q2, but then more of that 10% range in the second half of the year.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And that's x SubCom?
componenttext: Okay. And that's x SubCom?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's including SubCom.
componenttext: That's including SubCom.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, including SubCom. Okay, perfect. and then I was hoping to get some comments, Tom, in terms of the macroenvironment from you. I think you said that china is about as you had expected 90 days ago, but it sounds like most metrics are suggesting China is
componenttext: Oh, including SubCom. Okay, perfect. and then I was hoping to get some comments, Tom, in terms of the macroenvironment from you. I think you said that china is about as you had expected 90 days ago, but it sounds like most metrics are suggesting China is weaker. So I was up in could maybe provide a little more detail and maybe some detail on what you're seeing in emerging markets?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, China is our big emerging market by far. We do have business in Latin America and India, but it's kind of the big one. China was down as we said year-over-year in revenue. It was up sequentially, flat in orders, up sequentially in orders, wh
componenttext: Sure. I mean, China is our big emerging market by far. We do have business in Latin America and India, but it's kind of the big one. China was down as we said year-over-year in revenue. It was up sequentially, flat in orders, up sequentially in orders, which is a good sign. And it was -- it came back faster than we thought. Now it's one data point we have to see that continue, but we have the first sequential improvement in orders in a year. So that was -- that feels like a pretty good sign. I mean, we expected that to happen in the second quarter and happening in the first quarter is encouraging. So that was a little better. If you go around the rest of the world, I think the U.S. in a way was a little worse because of the industrial and the channel. And oil and gas continues to be down, and as Terrence talked quite in detail about the channel. And then Europe continues to be steady, another I think it 6 or 7 quarters of growth in a row now. In Europe, we don't see any signs of that backing off yet. So versus 90 days ago, the outlook feels slightly better because of this industrial OEMs orders increasing sequentially and China orders increasing sequentially. And of course, this is, I mean, it's a key quarter for that to continue and to set up -- we'll get normal seasonal growth in the second half. So we've been seeing our orders trend naturally the way they always do seasonally as we get towards the second half of the year, but we expect them to pick up from the run rate because of the correction primarily in the channel. And secondarily, if China continues where it was in Q1 orders, it will be a good shape in China for the balance of the year even if it doesn't raise from there and stayed at that level. Terrence, do you want to add?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chery, just one thing I'd like to add and highlight is, when you look at China, China is worth of $2 billion of revenue for us, and 50% of that is around our Automotive business. So when we talk about our China trends, it was a little bit better on our Tr
componenttext: Chery, just one thing I'd like to add and highlight is, when you look at China, China is worth of $2 billion of revenue for us, and 50% of that is around our Automotive business. So when we talk about our China trends, it was a little bit better on our Transportation area, like Tom talked about. and certainly we see production increasing in China. I would see the greater industrial and other spaces, it's moving as we expected. It is a little bit more sideways. Orders are improving, but when you look at it overall, orders increased almost 10% from our fourth quarter to our first quarter, which is a significant step that we didn't see, as Tom talked about, as orders were stepping down quarter-over-quarter last year.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that there is from the line with Sven Suva with Jefferies.
componenttext: And that there is from the line with Sven Suva with Jefferies.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: A quick clarification question and my follow-up kind of back-to-back. On the clarification, you mentioned the second half improvement in industrial. I understand the inventory and distribution issues, but what if oil stays at $30? I'm not smart enough to
componenttext: A quick clarification question and my follow-up kind of back-to-back. On the clarification, you mentioned the second half improvement in industrial. I understand the inventory and distribution issues, but what if oil stays at $30? I'm not smart enough to know if it's going to higher or lower, but if it stays at $30, is that supportive of your second half recovery view? Does that post a risk? Or does that impact you at all? And then my follow-up is on the timing of the stock buyback given the BNS sale, can you give help us understand the cadence that we should expect about that? I mean, in one hand, you been very diligent at always buying back stock each quarter. On the other hand, one would say why not do a big, accelerated program so you get a bigger EPS benefit sooner, especially given the recent stock price volatility?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sven, thank you. Let me take the industrial question oil and gas, and then Bob will take the share question. On oil and gas, one of the things that we have seen, certainly, the program element of the oil and gas market, we've seen in our step-down of reve
componenttext: Sven, thank you. Let me take the industrial question oil and gas, and then Bob will take the share question. On oil and gas, one of the things that we have seen, certainly, the program element of the oil and gas market, we've seen in our step-down of revenue. So like I said, last year, early in the year as well as the year before, we would run about $60 million a quarter. Our business hasn't come down, and oil has been impacted. we're seeing a lot of large projects obviously not happening and there's not being a lot of large projects being bid. The $30 million per quarter level that we have right now is sort of maintenance-type revenue level for us. It's not big project, so whether it's $25, $35, $40, I do actually think that's a floor that we're going to be pretty close to, plus or minus a little bit. So I do think that element that we have in our forecast reflects current oil prices.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Sven, on the share repurchase, our intention remains where we expect to be completed with the return of the proceeds from the BNS transaction in third quarter. As you know, we looked at a variety of different mechanisms to return that cash as we
componenttext: And then, Sven, on the share repurchase, our intention remains where we expect to be completed with the return of the proceeds from the BNS transaction in third quarter. As you know, we looked at a variety of different mechanisms to return that cash as we transition through the between announcement and actual closure and came to the conclusion that best answer was open market transaction. There's a lot of reasons why an accelerated share buyback doesn't work for us. The easiest one to understand is, we're a Swiss company, and the rules are different for Swiss company even though we're registered in New York Stock Exchange, and it makes an accelerated very difficult to do.

componenttext: The first question is on Automotive business. I understand the long-term content opportunity. But in 2016, given that you're seeing China stimulus targeted towards low-end cars, I mean, are you seeing any short-term mix effects that are headwind for content in the near term that you'd thought about?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mark, hi, it's Terrence. Clearly, size of engine does impact it. It's just not that meaningful. I think when you take the penetration that we've done in China both with the local OEMs and the multinational OEMs, the mix effect is what it used to be, and i
componenttext: Mark, hi, it's Terrence. Clearly, size of engine does impact it. It's just not that meaningful. I think when you take the penetration that we've done in China both with the local OEMs and the multinational OEMs, the mix effect is what it used to be, and it is reflected in our guidance. Certainly, it's focused at 1.6-liter engines and below the stimulus, and what's good is we're cover every OEM there. We have content on it. So it is in our guidance, but it's pretty minor.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then a follow-up question for Bob on the potential tax settlement. If it does get finalized with the IRS, how should we think about both other income and the tax rate going forward?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As you might, yes, Mark, that gets really complicated really quick. I think the straightforward answer to give you is, the settlement is not yet final. It's proposed. The 2 sides are largely agreed. We're working through a lot of the nuances within t
componenttext: Yes. As you might, yes, Mark, that gets really complicated really quick. I think the straightforward answer to give you is, the settlement is not yet final. It's proposed. The 2 sides are largely agreed. We're working through a lot of the nuances within the IRS to get that finalized. And at this point, anything I give you would be speculation and hypothesis. We're very comfortable. As I stated in the 8-K, we're very comfortable that we're adequately reserved, and so there won't be any additional charge. And then going forward, once the settlement is absolutely finalized, we'll give some detail guidance on the implication of other income and the go-forward effective tax rate.
