headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining our conference call to discuss TE Connectivity second quarter results. With me today are Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Lynch; President, Terrence Curtin; and acting Chief Financial Officer, Mario Calastr
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining our conference call to discuss TE Connectivity second quarter results. With me today are Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Lynch; President, Terrence Curtin; and acting Chief Financial Officer, Mario Calastri. During the course of this call, we'll be providing certain forward-looking information. We ask you to review the forward-looking cautionary statements included in today's press release. In addition, we will use certain non-GAAP measures in our discussion this morning. We ask you to review sections of our press release accompanying slide presentation that address the use of these items. Press release and related tables, along with the slide presentation, can be found on the Investor Relations portion of our website at te.com. [Operator Instructions]
Now let me turn the call over to Tom for opening comments.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for joining us today, and please turn to Slide 3 and we will review the highlights of today's call. Q2 was another quarter of good execution and what continues to remain a sluggish global economic environment. Adjusted earnings per share of $0.90 w
componenttext:
Thanks for joining us today, and please turn to Slide 3 and we will review the highlights of today's call. Q2 was another quarter of good execution and what continues to remain a sluggish global economic environment. Adjusted earnings per share of $0.90 was $0.02 better than the midpoint of our guidance of sales of $2.95 billion, which was slightly below the midpoint of the guidance. Strong operating performance across the company more than offset continued market softness across our industrial businesses.
Our adjusted earnings per share was down 1 penny versus the prior year with foreign exchange headwinds of approximately, $0.02. On a constant currency basis, adjusted EPS was up 1% year-over-year. Adjusted operating margins were 14.9% in line with our expectation, with adjusted EBITDA margins of approximately 20% in the quarter. For the full year, we are reiterating the midpoint of our guidance of $12.3 billion in revenue and $4 in adjusted earnings per share, representing an increase of 11% over prior year EPS. We expect to return to revenue growth in second half and to generate double-digit EPS growth.
Our outlook for organic growth is 3%, down slightly compared to our guidance of 90 days ago. Our auto business remains solid, industrial inventory correction is largely behind us, and SubCom continues to build momentum. Our recent acquisition of is in our guidance as well. These positive factors are offsetting lower-than-expected growth in most industrial markets and slow growth in our non-transportation business in China.
Our EPS growth is benefiting from cost controls, the benefits of our share buyback and suitable lower tax rate. We have developed multiple levers to drive earnings growth in a slow economy. During the quarter, we returned $1.2 billion to shareholders, including $1.1 billion in share buybacks. We expect to continue to take a balanced approach with our capital strategy, returning approximately 2/3 of our free cash flow to shareholders of our time with 1/3 of free cash being used for acquisitions. We generated $165 million of free cash flow in the quarter and $400 million in first half of the year. We expect our normal strong second half cash generation to continue. We also continue to strengthen the company's harsh-environment portfolio.
In March, we completed the sale of our Circuit Protection business. Earlier this month, we completed the acquisition of Creganna, doubling the size of our medical business to about $500 million in revenue and establishing TE as a leading provider of solutions for the high growth minimally invasive medical market.
This morning, we also announced a small sensor activation, which will strengthen our portfolio of sensor technologies serving the transportation market. In our SubCom business, we continue to gain momentum with the recently announced award of a project called Hawaiki, which is a new trend specific cable system linking Australia and New Zealand with the mainland United States. This award will generate over $200 million in revenue over the life of the project. And this business as a backdrop of awarded projects of $1 billion. I will turn it over to Terrence Curtin, who will cover our performance in more detail

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Before we get to the segment updates, I want to provide brief insights into our order patterns, which will help provide baseline for our results as well as the expectations. If you turn to Slide 4 please and this s
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Before we get to the segment updates, I want to provide brief insights into our order patterns, which will help provide baseline for our results as well as the expectations. If you turn to Slide 4 please and this shows order trends extending our SubCom business. Overall, orders improved sequentially and are above the low levels of approximately $2.6 billion that we experienced in the fourth quarter of 2015 and if you remember in the fourth quarter of last year, when we began to experience the supply chain impact related to the slowing in China as well as markets. We have seen recovery in orders in both of these areas and feel that the supply chain correction effects has completed in our second quarter as we expected. Certainly, we're pleased with the recovery in the orders, however, the slope of the recovery is running behind original expectations in certain areas.
Specifically in China, we previously thought that orders would continue to accelerate through the rest of the year. While we believe the auto orders in China will continue to recover, we are now expecting orders outside of auto just so to remain current levels that we experienced in the second quarter.
Let me now to talk about the orders by segment. Overall, transportation orders remain solid and in auto, our orders were impacted by near-term customer backlog adjustment that related to a change in their schedule. I want to highlight this does not impact demand, it's really just a change in one of our customers' process. We continue to experience strong order trends both in Europe and in Asia in automotive. In industrial, orders grew 5% sequentially with growth in both our direct customer orders as well as growth through our channel partner distribution.
As I stated earlier, the industrial inventory correction that is now behind us. And in communications excluding SubCom, our orders grew 4% sequentially with the book-to-bill of 105, this improvement in both our appliances and data and device business. As Tom mentioned, in SubCom, we continue this momentum with the new Hawaiki program and we will support that order as working in order. 
If you could please turn to Slide 5, I'll discuss Transportation Solutions results in the second quarter. Overall, sales grew 3% in the segment organically in the quarter, with growth across all of our businesses. Our order of sales growth in the quarter was driven by strength in China as well as in Europe. For fiscal 2016, we continue to expect global auto production to be up 2% to 2.5%, with growth in all regions as strong growth in China. We remain confident that our auto business can grow ahead of auto production driven by electronic content growth as well as platform from design wins that were generated over a couple of years. 
In commercial transportation, sales grew 1% organically year-over-year, driven by the heavy truck sector in both China and Europe. North America heavy truck markets continue to remain weak along with continued weakness in global construction and ag markets. We're pleased that organic orders were up both year-over-year as well as sequentially as we continue to perform very well in this business in the tough economic backdrop. 
Turning to Sensors, we saw 2% organic growth as we did begin to feel the impact of weakness in the industrial markets in our Sensors business and just to highlight for you about 40% of our sensor sales go into the industry markets. We do continue to see strong design momentum in long cycle transportation and industrial applications that we expect will draw future growth. 
From a margin viewpoint, adjusted operating margin in the segment were 19% and were in line with our expectations and were up sequentially. The decline year-over-year was driven by currency impacts as well as investments for growth. We anticipate adjusted operating margins for the second half to continue to improve and should be at similar levels as the second half of last year. 
If you could please turn to Slide 6 and I'll discuss the Industrial Solutions segment. Revenues in the segment declined 7% organically year-over-year in the second quarter. Geographically, we continue to see trends across our businesses that are consistent. Europe is stable and growing in many markets, North America continue to see weakness due to oil and gas as well as supply-chain correction that impacted us in the last couple of quarters and China remains sluggish. 
We continue to be impacted by the oil and gas market which saw 42% organic reduction in sales year-over-year and the decline in oil and gas drives half of the organic decline in the segment in the second quarter. Low oil and gas prices continue to have derivative fact other areas of the industrial segment including factory equipment as well as demand, which affects our Aerospace business. We have included the impacts in the results as well as our guidance. 
In Aerospace and Defense, our Commercial Aerospace business grew year-over-year and this was more than offset by declines in the defense business due to the supply-chain affects that were current in the distribution channel. Our Energy business was down 2% organically, with declines in Asia and Europe, partially offset by the growth. As we look forward, we expect the industrial segment to grow sequentially and we expect it to be essentially flat organically year-over-year in the third quarter, and we expect it to return the growth in the fourth quarter now that the inventory corrections are behind us. 
Adjusted operating margins were down year-over-year, driven primarily by declines in the higher-margin oil and gas business, but they were up sequentially. We do expect adjusted operating margins to continue to improve in the second half, benefiting from the increased volumes as well as the cost actions that we have initiated. 
If you could please turn to Page 7 to talk about the communication medications segment. In the second quarter, the segment had revenue of $606 million, which was down 10% and 8% organically year-over-year. And it was slightly ahead of our expectations. Our SubCom business saw solid year-over-year growth driven by strong execution from multiple projects in force and as Tom mentioned earlier, the total value of programs, of course, is approximately $1 million. We now expect SubCom to grow approximately 20% year-over-year and this is an improvement versus our expectation in 90 days ago. 
Our Data and Devices and Appliances business were impacted by distribution inventory corrections as I mentioned earlier, and we believe these are behind us that we had in the second half of the year. Additionally, Data and Device growth is impacted by the exits we're highlighted all year as far as the repositioning effort and as discussed will impact our growth rate throughout this year. 
Adjusted operating margins in the segment declined 60 basis points year-over-year in line with our expectations and we do expect improvements to adjusted operating margins as we continue through the second half. Now let me turn it over to Mario, who will cover the financials

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Alan, and good morning, everyone. Please turn to Slide 8 while I'll provide more details on earnings. Adjusted operating income of $440 million was in line with guidance and down 13% over year-over-year, due to currency impact investments in trans
componenttext:
Thanks, Alan, and good morning, everyone. Please turn to Slide 8 while I'll provide more details on earnings. Adjusted operating income of $440 million was in line with guidance and down 13% over year-over-year, due to currency impact investments in transportation and the lower volume impacts as Dennis mentioned earlier. GAAP operating income was $535 million and included $4 million of acquisition-related charges and net restructuring and other credit of $99 million, primarily driven by a gain on the sale of our production business. 
Adjusted EPS was $0.90 for the quarter, down $0.01 from the prior year with the reduced volume from higher-margin profits and negative impacts from currency exchange rate, offsetting incremental benefits from share buyback. Excluding impacts from foreign currency, adjusted EPS was up $0.01 from the prior year. GAAP EPS was $1.06 for the quarter, driven by net restructuring and other credits of $0.17, primarily due to the production sale I just mentioned. 
We expect approximately $100 million of restructuring charges for the full year, a $15 million increase from prior guidance. Regarding tax, you should continue obtain long-term adjustment tax rate as approximately 23% to 24%. Due to the mix of profitability in different jurisdictions, we now expect our adjusted tax rate to slightly lower this year. 
As we mentioned last quarter, international on behalf entered into the agreement with IRS to resolve all disputes related to the previously disclosed intercompany debt issues. During the quarter, we made net pre-separation tax payments to the IRS of approximately $140 million, to prevent further accrual of interest and hope to add this sale and behind us in the near future. As you may know, the Treasury Department issued tax regulations earlier this month. addresses the tax characterizations of intercompany financing arrangements by multinational companies, it utilizes in the company financing more efficient capital deployment. We are in the process of finalizing this proposed regulations for any potential prospective impact. 
Turning to Slide 9, while we remain in a challenging environment, our performance was in line with our guidance and we expect improvement across our operating metrics in the second half. Our adjusted gross margin in the quarter was 32.6%, the decline from last year is mostly driven by lower volume in areas like oil and gas and distribution, which have higher margin in the company average. Adjusted operating margins declined 150 basis points consistently with our gross margin performance. 
Total operating expenses were $523 million in the quarter, down 5% from the previous year, reflecting strong spending controls. We continue to tightly manage discretionary spending, while balancing our continuing investment into our harsh business. 
Moving to cash flow and capital deployment. In the quarter, cash from continuing operations was $155 million and our free cash flow was $165 million, down from prior year levels due to timing of certain tax payments, but still up in the first half versus last year. We expect full year free cash flow to approximate net income. We continue to have a balanced capital allocation. In the second quarter, we returned $1.2 billion to our shareholders, including $1.1 billion in buybacks. In the quarter, we bought back 19 million shares, executing against our commitment of returning the proceed from the broadband networks divestiture. 
Over the past 18 months, we have returned approximately, $4.3 billion to our shareholders through buybacks and dividends. As Tom mentioned earlier, we expect to continue to take a balance approach with our capital strategy going forward. We are also including a chart on adjusted EBITDA margins, which have explained the profitability performance of our businesses including acquisitions. 
Adjusted EBITDA margins in Q2 were 20%, which show our margin resiliency despite lower sales levels. Continued to be pleased with the operating performance of our business, especially in line of the challenging macro environment. We've also added the balance sheet and cash flow summary in the appendix for additional details.
Now let me turn back to Tom.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mario. Before I get into Q3 guidance on Slide 10, let me provide some perspective on why we will return to growth in the second half. As you know, our first half was characterized by several year-over-year macro headwind, unfavorable foreign excha
componenttext:
Thanks, Mario. Before I get into Q3 guidance on Slide 10, let me provide some perspective on why we will return to growth in the second half. As you know, our first half was characterized by several year-over-year macro headwind, unfavorable foreign exchange due to the significant strengthening of the dollar against most major currencies, the significant decline in year-over-year oil prices, which resulted in over 40% decline in our higher-margin oil and gas business, overall industrial markets we can leading to a supply chain connection with OEM than our challenge partners, which we believe are now behind us and weakness across most China markets. 
In the first half, these factors impacted us significantly, and in the second half, most of these headwinds were reduced. As a result, we expect to return the revenue growth and strong double-digit adjusted EPS growth, driven by our harsh strategy and the many levers in our operating model. 
Now I'll cover the Q3 outlook. We expect Q3 revenue of $3 billion to $3.2 billion, up 1% on an actual basis and flat organically and adjusted earnings per share of $1 to $1.06, up 14% year-over-year at the midpoint. We expect growth in transportation and industrial, which includes approximately, $60 million from the Creganna acquisition. This is offset by decline in communications from the sale of the Circuit Protection business and the continuation of our strategy to exit certain product line in Data and Devices. We do expect continued growth in our SubCom.
Now please turn to Slide 11. We are reiterating our full year guidance of $12.3 billion in revenue and $4 in adjusted EPS at the midpoint. On a full year basis, continued strong performance of our transportation segment, addition of the Creganna acquisition and growth in our SubCom business, more than offsetting the negative impact of exchange rates softer industry markets, especially oil and gas in China. As mentioned earlier, the full year and fourth quarter includes the 53rd week, which contributes approximately $200 million of revenue. 
Now this full year outlook includes an unusually high Q4 revenue and EPS level compared to Q3, so I'll walk you through that. As previously mentioned, this year's fourth quarter includes an extra week, which contributes approximately $200 million of revenue and approximately $0.10 per share in our earnings. Excluding the 53rd week, revenue is increasing approximately $40 million from Q3 to Q4. But the way to think about this is the $240 million revenue will flow through the earnings at a 25% to 30% rate and this coupled with our typical productivity accounts for the significant sequential increase in EPS. 
Let me just to wrap up with a few comments. As we mentioned earlier, the global economic environment continues to be sluggish. Despite this, we expect to generate another solid performance. Our focus on harsh environment, driving TE with organization, strong cash flow and a consistent return of capital policy continues to enable us significantly, strengthen our earnings leverage. $1 of revenue today generates about 40% more EPS than 5 years ago. This is serving us very well in the slow growth economy and will deliver accelerated earnings growth with the global economic improves. Now let's open it up for questions.

componenttext: Sure. I will comment and then I'll have Terrence add do it. I think a couple of things. So that's when the business started to grow a little bit, flat out year of supply chain adjusted negatively, so we've been going through that. We do see China gradually picking up. So -- and it really began to turn down in the second half of last year and in the fourth quarter. So some of that is to compare. I don't think we're predicting -- we are not predicting a robust industrial market. It's really things getting more balanced and then we'll have the benefit of the Creganna acquisition, which is in our industrial segment. Terrence, do you want to add some more color to that?

We did -- we have taken the projection out that was in the second quarter, but that is not in the balance of the year, so when you go business by business, compliance, strong margins, steady, SubCom, take the first quarter out, it's a little bit of an aberration, growing at volume growth and Data and Devices poised to start improving next year based on what we see right now.

I think secondly as we talked about to the second part of your question around what does it do, which is really nice what Creganna does for us is really round out the portfolio. So just to remind everyone, it gets to about 90% of that integrated solution we'll have internally. I think the other thing that is very powerful, not only their position and engineering, but where it's positioned in the world, really medical platform and they fill it not only the manufacturing with engineering and fill the gap we had around Europe with their very strong Irish presence, and that clearly bringing 225 engineers that know that space, knows really doubled our engineering capability. So we really feel we have a very nice platform to continue to build upon and very early very but very excited about it as well.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Shawn, it's Terrence. I think first of all, let's take Japan. What I would say in Japan, I think you're sizing Toyota is not right. When you sit there and you think through the earthquake in Japan, clearly that's a fluid situation, that we're monotoning w
componenttext: Shawn, it's Terrence. I think first of all, let's take Japan. What I would say in Japan, I think you're sizing Toyota is not right. When you sit there and you think through the earthquake in Japan, clearly that's a fluid situation, that we're monotoning with our customers. We have not seen any disruptions yet. We sort of assuming normal pattern. But where we see demand of that, it may impact some timing a little bit, but we're talking to our customers constantly and making sure we're helping them anyway they can as they work through that tragic event in Japan. On China stimulus, I think that's a little bit more of a complicated question that when you look at it, we began impact in our first quarter as China's overall production adjusted, so we talked about that. What we have seen is China coming back to about a 6% production environment, opposed that, which is pretty much in line with GDP. I don't think we know whether the China stimulus accelerated some production or demand, but we do sort of view that China production long term will stay around GDP of China. So I don't think we're far off right now. I think we'll have to see as the stimulus works off if is there any timing effects. But right now, we feel pretty good as production as we stimulated post the first quarter being very slow.

componenttext: So we have a lot of customers, so there is a lot of data point. I would say the biggest indicators are just on one hand will be setting the industrial, so we do see that sequential growth in orders and it's continued in the April pretty solidly, so that gives us confidence. It's does -- it's not a slam dunk. The channel partners all are pretty much back to positive book to bill. Seeing POS in line, with increasing demand and reflecting inventory levels in the channel back in line. So those are all positive indicators. And if recall at this time, last year, those indicators were starting to -- they were raising caution flag. They're going the other way. So that's what's given us some optimism. Again, we're not expecting a boom from Q3 to Q4. I think it's just where the cycle is this time versus prior years. And of course, we got to always keep reminding you of that extra week. It's confusing all of us, but there's an extra week there. So when you strip that out, we're talking about $40 million in revenue pickup. But right now, it feels we think that balance. I mean, we a lot more and end of the third quarter, but when we look with the channel pattern versus prior years, when we look at our industrial businesses order sequentially and seeing it both in the OEM customers and the channel customers, that's what gives us the confidence. Terrace, do you want to add to that

It's just how we do business between the 2 companies.

componenttext: What I would add, Will, is just to help understanding this year. Our Automotive business will grow more in the second half in terms of first half. We actually are going to have a stronger auto business segments in second half than the first half. The overall sensor business growth range lower in the second half than the first half.

componenttext: 2 questions from me. First off, just getting back to the transportation margins. I understand the investment sort of going on. headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So this aggregate the 3 pieces of our transportation segment, Automotive, as Terrence said, very strong business. We expect to grow mid- to high-single digits on 2% to 3% -- 2.5% production growth margins there remain Sensors is below the transporta
componenttext: Sure. So this aggregate the 3 pieces of our transportation segment, Automotive, as Terrence said, very strong business. We expect to grow mid- to high-single digits on 2% to 3% -- 2.5% production growth margins there remain Sensors is below the transportation averages. As you know, with the acquisition, tremendous opportunity to move those margins up. And we are investing at -- we are increasing our R&D investment at a faster rate and our sales growth and Sensors because the opportunity is so great. And customers absolutely like another strong resilient technology, which company providing sensors into the transportation market and we are getting significant design and that requires engineers. It's been our plan from day 1 when we made the acquisition. And then in the industrial transportation business, which is the highest margin business in the group, we are -- I think we're navigating very well, maintaining our margins in a very -- almost really negative growth environment. Our growth is up because of our strong position in China and Europe which is offsetting North America. So we really within segment, we manage those businesses separately based on the dynamics and the opportunity. And as Terrence said in his comments, we're pretty confident that you'll see the margins that improve sequentially. It went up 40 or 50 basis points Q1 versus Q2. We expect that margin to continue in the second half of the year with a little bit of volume growth over the first half of the year because there's a lot of operating leverage in this business.

componenttext: So just does the push back on the second point around Sensors, so it safe to understand then that this was a sort of an unusual quarter in terms of the investment levels versus revenues actually ramping with some of new programs and those gaps starts to close going forward or does it stay at these levels for a little while, if you could sort of qualify that. And then my follow-up question was just to get an update on the CFO search?

componenttext: So it's ramping. We began increasing our Sensors investment late last year. And certainly, as went programs and we talked about design wins, especially longer cycle business, there will be a gap, so I don't think it's anomaly, but it's something we're -- we have to do best ahead and we run these programs, so it's a ramp that you're going to see in Sensors, but we've always expected that as we improve the business.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: One more comment before the CFO -- I just do the CFO search. I think it's really important, if you look at the transformation of the company to the harsh-environment, other businesses that no need -- that don't fit to that definition. For us that's highly
componenttext: One more comment before the CFO -- I just do the CFO search. I think it's really important, if you look at the transformation of the company to the harsh-environment, other businesses that no need -- that don't fit to that definition. For us that's highly engineered, higher barriers to entry, the capital allocation strategy, you see how that enables us even in a slow growth market to make strategic investments and something like Sensors, which is going to be a big business for us. And -- so yes, we have decided not to really change our strategy there given that we have all these other leverage to drive the earnings growth that we set up 6 months ago. Well, $3 million, $12 billion, $4 billion in revenue and $4 in EPS. So that's part of the story too, an important part. On the CFO search, we're active as you can imagine. We have a couple of internal candidates. We're going through the external candidates obviously a critically important job. What I feel good about is, we have a very strong financial organization across the company and the team is doing great. Mario has stepped in and that you can tell in an effective way. He has been 10 years with us all well from all dimensions, but yes that's an everyday aim on our list. And I would expect in the next couple of months, we'll be making some announcement.

It was centered around petroleum or diesel or electric or HB or how should we think about kind of what's going on there? And is this a rippling change in the industry? Then my second question or the follow-up would be on the intercompany debt. I know you mentioned that the past historical IRS settlement is in the works near accruing the interest for so on and so forth. Am I also correct to say that the new regulations also potentially end or do impact your current debt structure amongst the company? And if, if so, can you quantify or let us know about anything around that? Or was it all just simply backward stating and going forward there are no considerations?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll take the first point. And then I'll take -- take the second point. Number one, the customer, so when you look at programs and things like that, Jim, you can't really look at that. They change their process. So certainly, this was something that bu
componenttext: So I'll take the first point. And then I'll take -- take the second point. Number one, the customer, so when you look at programs and things like that, Jim, you can't really look at that. They change their process. So certainly, this was something that built up over time. It's why they did the process. They gave us very forward-looking orders that we recorded as orders and backlog. Now they've moved to be a more current JIT with the way I would articulated. That scheduling came out and they're going to hit us with orders more frequently. That does create a debooking in our world. It does not impact programs that we won with our customer throughout the world. So when you look at it, it is something that is very process centric. It does not impact programs and you can't get it into individual diesel versus electric versus production engineering. It isn't there. And over time, we'll just get those orders more frequently than have been scheduled back. Now I let Mario turn over to on your tax question.

componenttext: Sure. On the tax question, first of all, on the settlement. We did mention that we have made a repayment to the IRS that effectively stops the accrual of the interest on that liability, which basically takes out most of the impact of the settlement when we like them to settle. So we are having include in our guidance, the fact that we have did that payment that impacts our tax rate. On the second element as far as the that are put in place, first of all, those -- those proposed rides are prospective, so they do not have any impact on our current company debt position. And again, it's complicated matter that we are getting ahead around, but no, there is no impact to our current company debt position, that would be 100%.

componenttext: Sure. Yes, I couldn't my optimism around the Automotive business globally. And with our presence in our range of technology, it's becoming more and more important. So we have a significant share in the connectivity business. But over the last 5 years, we believe we increased at 5 points, that is quite an accomplishment and it really is as these solutions get more complex and all you have to do is kind of look under the hood to see how different it is over the last 5 or 6 years. The connectivity in the sensing solutions are more complex. On the connectivity side, we continue to win at a rate faster than we have in the past, which is why I think we said a few times if you go back 5 years and we talked about 2% production environment, we would have talked about a 3% -- 3% to 4% revenue to TE environment. Now we believe that's 5% to 6%. And that's really more market share than it is content. So I expect we'll continue to up our market share because of the range of capability we have and just for example, hydroelectric vehicle, the difference in our designing in rate in the last 3 years versus the first -- the prior 5 years is 2 to 3x. So that market now continues to pick up with high content and we're extremely well positioned with all the leading platforms. So we feel good about that. On the Sensor side, we have one significant design wins with technology and our go-to-market and the strength we bring and the credibility we bring to auto customer. We're an auto supplier through and through and we're doing that for over 50 years. And -- so they like the technology and they trust us and we're winning important awards and that's showing up in revenue and that will be in the next couple of years, but that's why when we talked earlier incredibly enthusiastic and feel that actually ahead of the high we had with about our ability to bring their technology into the auto market, which is the best market for Sensors. Terrence, will you add anything to do that?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining our conference call to discuss TE Connectivity second quarter results. With me today are Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Lynch; President, Terrence Curtin; and acting Chief Financial Officer, Mario Calastr
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining our conference call to discuss TE Connectivity second quarter results. With me today are Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Lynch; President, Terrence Curtin; and acting Chief Financial Officer, Mario Calastri. During the course of this call, we'll be providing certain forward-looking information. We ask you to review the forward-looking cautionary statements included in today's press release. In addition, we will use certain non-GAAP measures in our discussion this morning. We ask you to review the sections of our press release, the accompanying slide presentation that address the use of these items. Press release and related tables, along with the slide presentation, can be found on the Investor Relations portion of our website at te.com. [Operator Instructions]
Now let me turn the call over to Tom for opening comments.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for joining us today, and please turn to Slide 3 and we will review the highlights from today's call. Q2 was another quarter of good execution and what continues to remain a sluggish global economic environment. Adjusted earnings per share of $0.90
componenttext:
Thanks for joining us today, and please turn to Slide 3 and we will review the highlights from today's call. Q2 was another quarter of good execution and what continues to remain a sluggish global economic environment. Adjusted earnings per share of $0.90, was $0.02 better than the midpoint of our guidance on sales of $2.95 billion, which was slightly below the midpoint of the guidance. Strong operating performance across the company more than offset continued market softness across our Industrial businesses.
Our adjusted earnings per share was down 1 penny versus the prior year with foreign exchange headwinds of approximately, $0.02. On a constant currency basis, adjusted EPS was up 1% year-over-year. Adjusted operating margins were 14.9% in line with our expectation, with adjusted EBITDA margins of approximately 20% in the quarter. For the full year, we are reiterating the midpoint of our guidance of $12.3 billion in revenue and $4 in adjusted earnings per share, representing an increase of 11% over prior year EPS. We expect to return to revenue growth in the second half and to generate double-digit EPS growth.
Our outlook for organic growth is 3%, down slightly compared to our guidance of 90 days ago. Our auto business remains solid, industrial inventory correction is largely behind us, and SubCom continues to build momentum. Our recent acquisition of Creganna is now in our guidance as well. These positive factors are offsetting lower-than-expected growth in most industrial markets and slow growth in our non-transportation business in China.
Our EPS growth is benefiting from cost controls, the benefits of our share buyback and a suitable lower tax rate. We have developed multiple levers to drive earnings growth in a slow economy. During the quarter, we returned $1.2 billion to shareholders, including $1.1 billion in share buybacks. We expect to continue to take a balanced approach with our capital strategy, returning approximately 2/3 of our free cash flow to shareholders over time with 1/3 of free cash being used for acquisitions. We generated $165 million of free cash flow in the quarter and $400 million in the first half of the year. We expect our normal strong second half cash generation to continue. We also continue to strengthen the company's Harsh environment portfolio.
In March, we completed the sale of our Circuit Protection business. Earlier this month, we completed the acquisition of Creganna, doubling the size of our medical business to about $500 million in revenue and establishing TE as a leading provider of solutions for the high growth minimally invasive medical market.
This morning, we also announced a small sensor activation, which will strengthen our portfolio of sensor technologies serving the Transportation market. In our SubCom business, we continue to gain momentum with the recently announced award of a project called Hawaiki, which is a new trans-pacific cable system linking Australia and New Zealand with the mainland United States. This award will generate over $200 million in revenue over the life of the project. And this business has a backlog of awarded projects of $1 billion. I will now turn it over to Terrence Curtin, who will cover our performance in more detail.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Before we get into the segment updates, I want to provide brief insights into our order patterns, which will help provide a baseline for our results as well as the expectations. If you turn to Slide 4 please and th
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Before we get into the segment updates, I want to provide brief insights into our order patterns, which will help provide a baseline for our results as well as the expectations. If you turn to Slide 4 please and this shows order trends excluding our SubCom business. Overall, orders improved again sequentially and are above the low levels of approximately $2.6 billion that we experienced in the fourth quarter of 2015, and if you remember in the fourth quarter of last year is when we began to experience the supply chain impact related to the slowing in China as well as the industrial markets. We have seen recovery in orders in both of these areas and feel that the supply chain correction effects have completed in our second quarter as we expected. Certainly, we're pleased with the recovery in the orders, however, the slope with recovery is running behind original expectations in certain areas.
Specifically in China, we previously thought that orders would continue to accelerate through the rest of the year. While we believe the auto orders in China will continue to recover, we are now expecting orders outside of auto just so to remain at the current levels that were experienced in the second quarter.
Let me now talk about the orders by segment. Overall, Transportation orders remain solid and in auto, our orders were basically impacted by near-term customer backlog adjustment that related to a change in their scheduling. I want to highlight this does not impact demand, it's really just a change in one of our customers' processes. We continue to experience strong order trends both in Europe and in Asia in automotive. In industrial, orders grew 5% sequentially with growth in both our direct customer orders as well as those that go through our channel partners and distribution.
As I stated earlier, the industrial inventory correction is now behind us. And in Communications excluding SubCom, our orders grew 4% sequentially with a book-to-bill of 105, with improvements in both our appliances and data and device businesses. As Tom mentioned, in SubCom, it continues its momentum with the new Hawaiki program, and we will record that order as a booking in our third quarter. 
If you could please turn to Slide 5, I'll discuss Transportation Solutions results in the second quarter. Overall, sales grew 3% in the segment organically in the quarter, with growth across all of our businesses. Our auto sales growth in the quarter was driven by strength in China as well as in Europe. For fiscal 2016, we continue to expect global auto production to be up 2% to 2.5%, with growth in all regions, had strong growth in China. We remain confident that our auto business can grow ahead of auto production driven by electronic content growth as well as a rich pipeline of platform ramps from design wins that were generated over the past several years. 
In commercial transportation, sales grew 1% organically year-over-year, driven by the heavy truck sector in both China and Europe. North America heavy truck markets continue to remain weak along with continued weakness in global construction and ag markets. We're pleased that organic orders were up both year-over-year as well as sequentially as we continue to perform very well in this business in a tough economic backdrop. 
Turning to Sensors, we saw 2% organic growth as we did begin to feel the impact of weakness in the industrial markets in our Sensor business and just to highlight for you about 40% of our sensor sales go into the industrial markets. We do continue to see strong design momentum in long cycle transportation and industrial applications that we expect will drive future growth. 
From a margin viewpoint, adjusted operating margins in the segment were 19% and were in line with our expectations and were up sequentially. The decline year-over-year was driven by currency impacts as well as investments for growth. We anticipate adjusted operating margins for the second half to continue to improve and should be at similar levels as the second half of last year. 
If you could please turn to Slide 6 and I'll discuss the Industrial Solutions segment. Revenues in the segment declined 7% organically year-over-year in the second quarter. Geographically, we continue to see trends across our businesses that are consistent. Europe is stable and growing in many markets. North America continued to see weakness due to oil and gas as well as the supply-chain corrections that impacted us the past couple of quarters and China remains sluggish. 
We continue to be impacted by the oil and gas market which saw a 42% organic reduction in sales year-over-year and the decline in oil and gas drives half of the organic decline in the segment in the second quarter. Low oil and gas prices continue to have a derivative affect in other areas of the Industrial segment including factory equipment as well as in helicopter demand, which affects our Aerospace business. We have included the impacts in the auto results as well as in our guidance. 
In Aerospace and Defense, our Commercial Aerospace business grew year-over-year and this was more than offset by declines in the defense business due to the supply-chain affects that were occurring in the distribution channel. Our Energy business was down 2% organically, with declines in Asia and in Europe, partially offset by growth in U.S. As we look forward, we expect the Industrial segment to grow sequentially and we expect it to be essentially flat organically year-over-year in the third quarter, and we expect it to return to growth in the fourth quarter now that the inventory corrections are behind us. 
Adjusted operating margins were down year-over-year, driven primarily by declines in the higher-margin oil and gas business, but they were up sequentially. We do expect adjusted operating margins to continue to improve in the second half, benefiting from the increased volumes as well as the cost actions that we have initiated. 
If you could please turn to Page 7 to talk about the Communications segment. In the second quarter, the segment had revenue of $606 million, which was down 10% and 8% organically year-over-year. And it was slightly ahead of our expectations. Our SubCom business saw solid year-over-year growth driven by strong execution from multiple projects in force and as Tom mentioned earlier, the total value of programs, of course, is approximately $1 million. We now expect SubCom to grow approximately 20% year-over-year and this is an improvement versus our expectation 90 days ago. 
Our Data and Devices and Appliances business were impacted by distribution inventory corrections as I mentioned earlier, and we believe these are behind us that we had in the second half of the year. Additionally, Data and Devices growth is impacted by the product exits we've been highlighting all year as far as the repositioning effort and as discussed will impact our growth rate throughout this year. 
Adjusted operating margins in the segment declined 60 basis points year-over-year in line with our expectations and we do expect improvements to adjusted operating margins as we continue through the second half. Now let me turn it over to Mario, who will cover the financials

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terrence, and good morning, everyone. Please turn to Slide 8 where I'll provide more details on earnings. Adjusted operating income of $440 million was in line with guidance and down 13% over year-over-year, due to currency impact investments in T
componenttext:
Thanks, Terrence, and good morning, everyone. Please turn to Slide 8 where I'll provide more details on earnings. Adjusted operating income of $440 million was in line with guidance and down 13% over year-over-year, due to currency impact investments in Transportation and the lower volume impacts that Terrence mentioned earlier. GAAP operating income was $535 million and included $4 million of acquisition-related charges and net restructuring and other credit of $99 million, primarily driven by a gain on the sale of our Circuit
Protection business. 
Adjusted EPS was $0.90 for the quarter, down $0.01 from the prior year with reduced volume from higher-margin profits and negative impacts from currency exchange rates, offsetting incremental benefits from share buyback. Excluding the $0.02 impacts from foreign currency, adjusted EPS was up $0.01 from the prior year. GAAP EPS was $1.06 for the quarter, driven by net restructuring and other credits of $0.17, primarily due to the Circuit Protection sale I just mentioned. 
We expect approximately $100 million of restructuring charges for the full year, a $15 million increase from prior guidance. Regarding tax, you should continue to obtain [indiscernible] long-term adjusted tax rate as approximately 23% to 24%. Due to the mix of profitability in different jurisdictions, we now expect our adjusted tax rate to be slightly lower this year. 
As we mentioned last quarter, Tyco International on behalf of TE entered into an agreement with the IRS to resolve all disputes related to the previously disclosed intercompany debt issues. During the quarter, we made net pre-separation tax payments to the IRS of approximately $140 million, to prevent further accrual of interest and penalties and hope to have this resolved and behind us in the near future. As you may know, the Treasury Department issued proposed tax regulations earlier this month. One proposal addresses the tax characterizations of certain intercompany financing arrangements by most multinational companies, who utilizes in the company financing for efficient capital deployment. We are in the process of analyzing this proposed regulations for any potential prospective impact on TE.
Turning to Slide 9, while we remain in a challenging environment, our performance was in line with our guidance and we expect improvement across our operating metrics in the second half. Our adjusted gross margin in the quarter was 32.6%, a decline from last year and mostly driven by lower volume in areas like oil and gas and distribution, which have higher margin than company average. Adjusted operating margins declined 150 basis points consistently with our gross margin performance. 
Total operating expenses were $523 million in the quarter, down 5% from the previous year, reflecting strong spending controls. We continue to tightly manage discretionary spending, while balancing our continuing investment into our Harsh businesses. 
Moving to cash flow and capital deployment. In the quarter, cash from continuing operations was $155 million and our free cash flow was $165 million, down from prior year levels due to timing of certain tax payments, but still up in the first half versus last year. We expect full year free cash flow to approximate net income. We continue to have a balanced capital allocation. In the second quarter, we returned $1.2 billion to our shareholders, including $1.1 billion in buybacks. In the quarter, we bought back 19 million shares, executing against our commitment of returning the proceed from the Broadband Networks divestiture. 
Over the past 18 months, we have returned approximately, $4.3 billion to our shareholders through buybacks and dividends. As Tom mentioned earlier, we expect to continue to take a balanced approach with our capital strategy going forward. We are also including a chart on adjusted EBITDA margins, which have explained the profitability performance of our businesses including acquisitions. 
Adjusted EBITDA margins in Q2 were 20% and show our margin resiliency despite lower sales levels. Continue to be pleased with the operating performance of our business, especially in light of the challenging macro backdrop. We've also added the balance sheet and cash flow summary in the appendix for additional details.
Now let me turn it back to Tom.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mario. Before I get into Q3 guidance on Slide 10, let me provide some perspective on why we will return to growth in the second half. As you know, our first half was characterized by several year-over-year macro headwinds, unfavorable foreign exch
componenttext:
Thanks, Mario. Before I get into Q3 guidance on Slide 10, let me provide some perspective on why we will return to growth in the second half. As you know, our first half was characterized by several year-over-year macro headwinds, unfavorable foreign exchange due to the significant strengthening of the dollar against most major currencies, the significant decline in year-over-year oil prices, which resulted in an over 40% decline in our higher-margin oil and gas business, overall industrial markets weakened leading to a supply chain corrections with OEMs and our channel partners, which we believe are now behind us and weakness across most China markets. 
In the first half, these factors impacted us significantly, and in the second half, most of these headwinds are reduced. As a result, we expect to return to revenue growth and strong double-digit adjusted EPS growth, driven by our Harsh strategy and the many levers in our operating model. 
Now I'll cover the Q3 outlook. We expect Q3 revenue of $3 billion to $3.2 billion, up 1% on an actual basis and flat organically and adjusted earnings per share of $1 to $1.06, up 14% year-over-year at the midpoint. We expect growth in Transportation and Industrial, which includes approximately, $60 million from the Creganna acquisition. This is offset by declines in Communications from the sale of the Circuit Protection business and the continuation of our strategy to exit certain product lines in Data and Devices. We do expect continued growth in our SubCom.
Now please turn to Slide 11. We are reiterating our full year guidance of $12.3 billion in revenue and $4 in adjusted EPS at the midpoint. On a full year basis, continued strong performance of our Transportation segment, the addition of the Creganna acquisition and growth in our SubCom business, more than offsetting the negative impact of exchange rates and softer industrial markets, especially oil and gas in China. As mentioned earlier, the full year and fourth quarter includes the 53rd week, which contributes approximately $200 million of revenue. 
Now this full year outlook includes an unusually high Q4 revenue and EPS level compared to Q3, so I'll walk you through that. As previously mentioned, this year's fourth quarter includes an extra week, which contributes approximately $200 million of revenue and approximately $0.10 per share in earnings. Excluding the 53rd week, revenue is increasing approximately $40 million from Q3 to Q4. But the way to think about this is the $240 million revenue will flow through to earnings at a 25% to 30% rate and this coupled with our typical productivity accounts for the significant sequential increase in EPS. 
Let me just wrap up with a few comments. As we mentioned earlier, the global economic environment continues to be sluggish. Despite this, we expect to generate another year of solid performance. Our focus on Harsh environments, driving TEOA through the organization, strong cash flow and a consistent return of capital policy continues to enable us to significantly strengthen our earnings leverage. $1 of revenue today generates about 40% more EPS than 5 years ago. This is serving us very well in a slow growth economy and will deliver accelerated earnings growth as the global economy improves. Now let's open it up for questions.

componenttext: I guess, two questions from me. Tom, may be to carry on on what you told at the end of the call with the September quarter guidance. Historically, I think in September, revenues tend to be down a little bit sequentially, 2% by my math, so could you maybe talk about what gives you the comfort that sales could be up $40 million sequentially on organic basis? And then on the EPS line, I guess the same thing, the extra week gives you $0.10, the $40 million would give you another $0.02, $0.03. I still struggle to get the entire $0.20 that you guys are implying for September?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's a little static on the line. We'll try to get through this. Normally, if you go back over to many years, we've had a few years where we're up slightly in the fourth quarter, a few years where we're down slightly. I mean, last year was a pr
componenttext: I think there's a little static on the line. We'll try to get through this. Normally, if you go back over to many years, we've had a few years where we're up slightly in the fourth quarter, a few years where we're down slightly. I mean, last year was a pretty unusual year because that is where China and the industrial -- industry correction began to occur. This year, the pattern coming into the fourth quarter is different. You have industrial markets improving. We have China, while not quite as much as we thought improving, for sure the auto market is improving as we expected. So that's really the difference in accounting for us, a slight sequential improvement as opposed to with what we could say over time has been kind of a back to the [Technical Difficulty] quarter. We also pick up, when you add $240 million in revenue sequentially a lot of leverage comes with that, and that's how you -- I think we'll for sure be in that 25% to 30%. The restructuring that has been going on through the year continues to slow in and aggregate, so there'll be a better benefit in Q4 than Q3 and then our normal productivity momentum, which marches through the year. So when you add all that up and that's how you get to what looks like a pretty significant hockey stick but when you feel the pack, you'd say, it's a small hockey stick.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. That's helpful to kind of get the lever there. And then I guess, just the Transportation segment, I think you guys actually took up the production or unit expectation up modestly for autos, but the organic growth, I think went from high singl
componenttext: Fair enough. That's helpful to kind of get the lever there. And then I guess, just the Transportation segment, I think you guys actually took up the production or unit expectation up modestly for autos, but the organic growth, I think went from high single digit to mid-single digit. Could you maybe just talk about what are the variables that's lead into the lower organic growth within Transportation for the year?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Amit, its Terrence. 2 things, we did not change our auto production estimate. We have been around that 2% to 2.5% since last quarter and really that is China being middle to higher single digits, Europe being to about 1%, U.S. about 4%, so that's -- we ha
componenttext: Amit, its Terrence. 2 things, we did not change our auto production estimate. We have been around that 2% to 2.5% since last quarter and really that is China being middle to higher single digits, Europe being to about 1%, U.S. about 4%, so that's -- we have not changed those assumptions. When you look overall at the Transportation organic growth, primarily driven by the comments I made around sensors, we did reduce our expectation for the year around sensors organic growth, its really related to the impact of the industrial markets. So the growth we had there was slower than we thought, and we are seeing order impacts due to some of the industrial impact that we've seen elsewhere on the sensor business.

componenttextpreview: When you look at those increased investments, we've had a tremendous amount of program wins both in our Sensor business as well as in the Automotive business. As you know, they're long cycle businesses, Wamsi. So we have to put in investments in to suppor
componenttext: When you look at those increased investments, we've had a tremendous amount of program wins both in our Sensor business as well as in the Automotive business. As you know, they're long cycle businesses, Wamsi. So we have to put in investments in to support those programs, so it's mainly in engineering, and we've got launch teams both in Sensors as well as core Automotive around those programs launches that will benefit us in 2 or 3 years.

It sounds like, you think China is going to be relatively flat, but potentially I think you're saying that the inventory situation is better. So just trying to understand what makes you comfortable that things will get better in the second half?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I will comment and then I'll have Terrence add to it. I think a couple of things. One, when we look at inventory in the supply chain both at our direct customers and our channel customers, it feels like that's back in balance right now and that's wh
componenttext: Sure. I will comment and then I'll have Terrence add to it. I think a couple of things. One, when we look at inventory in the supply chain both at our direct customers and our channel customers, it feels like that's back in balance right now and that's what our channel partners feel as well. So that's when the business started to go a little bit flattened out last year and the supply chain adjusted negatively, so we've been going through that. We do see China gradually picking up. So -- and it really began to turn down in the second half of last year and in the fourth quarter of last year. So some of that is the compare. I don't think we're predicting -- we are not predicting a robust industrial market. It's really things getting more in balance and then we'll have the benefit of the Creganna acquisition, which is in our Industrial segment. Terrence, do you want to add some more color to that?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: No. I think, Sherri, Tom said it very well. Last year in the fourth quarter is when oil and gas as well as lot of the channel and inventory affects hit us. So in some ways, its week compared to the fourth quarter last year on an organic basis, but we do see them leveled out. I think the third quarter as we talk about it being flat year-on-year. I do think that the industrial world is relatively flat right now, so I think we're getting those supply chain affects behind us anniversarying oil and gas as well as calm air. We continue to expect the very strong market, and as Tom mentioned, medical predominant business.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Communications, as you know, is a mix of kind of 3 businesses, a very good appliance business, Subsea business that is growing, and our first quarter margins were very high because we had the close out of a job in Subsea that we expected to take a couple
componenttext: Communications, as you know, is a mix of kind of 3 businesses, a very good appliance business, Subsea business that is growing, and our first quarter margins were very high because we had the close out of a job in Subsea that we expected to take a couple of more quarters, and that really popped the margin in the first quarter. Second quarter is more normalized for Subsea. So I expect Subsea will gradually improve, the data and devices margins will start to improve later this year, but we're feeling more optimistic about that. We did -- we have taken the Circuit Protection out, that was into the second quarter, but that is not in the balance of the year, so when you go business by business, Appliance, strong margins, steady; SubCom, take the first quarter out, it's a little bit of an aberration, growing as volume grows; and Data and Devices, poised to start improving next year based on what we see right now.

componenttext: Question on Creganna, understanding it just closed, but if you can just give some anecdotes in terms of customer engagement number one? Number two, just kind of what that does for you more broadly in kind of the medical opportunity set?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Craig. It's Terrence. So what's reaction? The customers have been very positive. Certainly, we made the first move in the space last year with advance cap and I think the customer reaction of having both of these together to get bigger scale in the
componenttext: Sure, Craig. It's Terrence. So what's reaction? The customers have been very positive. Certainly, we made the first move in the space last year with advance cap and I think the customer reaction of having both of these together to get bigger scale in the space, like we said it's been a $3 billion market, but we're basically #2 player right now in that, customers have really appreciated. So that's sort of a positive. I think secondly as we talked about, to the second part of your question, around what does it do, what's really nice about what Creganna does for us is really round out the portfolio. So just to remind everyone, it gets us about 90% of that integrated solution we'll have internally. I think the other thing that is very powerful, not only their position and their engineering, but where it's positioned in the world, really balances out our medical platforms and they fill it not only with manufacturing but with the engineering and fill the gap we had around Europe with their strong Irish presence, and then clearly bringing in 225 engineers that know that space, know that per patients, really doubled our engineering capability. So really feel we have a very nice platform to continue to build upon and very early, but very excited about it as well.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: One thing I would add, Terrence, is we complement Creganna in China with our size in China and our robust platform across China and an existing medical business there in that market is made-to-order for minimally invasive, because you have the growing --
componenttext: One thing I would add, Terrence, is we complement Creganna in China with our size in China and our robust platform across China and an existing medical business there in that market is made-to-order for minimally invasive, because you have the growing -- a huge population and aging population and don't right have the affordability, so this -- we're really excited about helping them scale much faster than they would normally been able to in China.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And then, as my follow-up on the tuck-in announced this morning. If I look back to MEAS, they were -- did a number of tuck-ins and many deals, they've kind of build the base that you have today. So just your strategy in the sensor market, it feels like that's a market that is very fragmented, there's a lot of growth, there's a lot of opportunities, but could we expect more along these lines in terms of you dealing these type of $40 million, $50 million type revenue deals?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Craig, you said it very well.  Number one is, it's a very fragmented market and what we like about what was announced today [indiscernible] really is this is  a speed sensor product company that really plays very strongly into Transportation both in the I
componenttext: Craig, you said it very well.  Number one is, it's a very fragmented market and what we like about what was announced today [indiscernible] really is this is  a speed sensor product company that really plays very strongly into Transportation both in the Industrial Transportation side as well as Automotive into turbocharger applications. So I think when you look at the sensor space, you'll continue to see us do things similar to this as we continue to build out the portfolio and build on what both MEAS has and what we had historically, and continue to grow this business. So very excited about the business we announced last night, it will help strengthen us in the Transportation space.
