headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to get a sense of what drives your confidence that the Industrial segment will improve in the back half of the year? It sounds like, you think China is going to be relatively flat, but potentially I think you're saying that the inventory situatio
componenttext: I wanted to get a sense of what drives your confidence that the Industrial segment will improve in the back half of the year? It sounds like, you think China is going to be relatively flat, but potentially I think you're saying that the inventory situation is better. So just trying to understand what makes you comfortable that things will get better in the second half?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I will comment and then I'll have Terrence add to it. I think a couple of things. One, when we look at inventory in the supply chain both at our direct customers and our channel customers, it feels like that's back in balance right now and that's wh
componenttext: Sure. I will comment and then I'll have Terrence add to it. I think a couple of things. One, when we look at inventory in the supply chain both at our direct customers and our channel customers, it feels like that's back in balance right now and that's what our channel partners feel as well. So that's when the business started to go a little bit -- flattened out last year, the supply chain adjusted negatively, so we've been going through that. We do see China gradually picking up. So -- and it really began to turn down in the second half of last year and in the fourth quarter of last year. So some of that is the compare. I don't think we're predicting -- we're not predicting a robust industrial market. It's really things getting more in balance and then we'll have the benefit of the Creganna acquisition, which is in our Industrial segment. So Terrence, do you want to add some more color to that?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think, Sherri, Tom said it very well. Last year in the fourth quarter is when oil and gas as well as lot of the channel and inventory effects hit us. So in some ways, its weak compare to the fourth quarter of last year on an organic basis, but we do
componenttext: No. I think, Sherri, Tom said it very well. Last year in the fourth quarter is when oil and gas as well as lot of the channel and inventory effects hit us. So in some ways, its weak compare to the fourth quarter of last year on an organic basis, but we do see them leveled out. I think the third quarter as we talk about it being flat year-on-year, I do think that the industrial world is relatively flat right now, so I think we're getting those supply chain effects behind us anniversarying oil and gas as well as com air, we continue to expect to be a very strong market. And then Tom mentioned medical, with Creganna.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's really helpful. And then trying to just ask a quick question on the Communications margins, they were down year-over-year and I would have thought that maybe it would have been a bit stronger given the Subsea business is higher. How should w
componenttext: Great. That's really helpful. And then trying to just ask a quick question on the Communications margins, they were down year-over-year and I would have thought that maybe it would have been a bit stronger given the Subsea business is higher. How should we think about the Subsea business impacting that margin as we move through the year as revenue is stronger?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Communications, as you know, is a mix of kind of 3 businesses, a very good appliance business, a Subsea business that is growing, and the first quarter margins were very high because we had the close out of a job in Subsea that we expected to take a coupl
componenttext: Communications, as you know, is a mix of kind of 3 businesses, a very good appliance business, a Subsea business that is growing, and the first quarter margins were very high because we had the close out of a job in Subsea that we expected to take a couple of more quarters, and that really popped the margin in the first quarter. Second quarter is more normalized for Subsea. So I expect Subsea will gradually improve, the data and devices margins will start to improve later this year, but we're feeling more optimistic about that. We did -- we have taken the Circuit Protection out, that was into the second quarter, but that is not in the balance of the year, so when you go business by business, Appliance, strong margins, steady; SubCom, take the first quarter out, it's a little bit of an aberration, growing as volume grows; and Data and Devices, poised to start improving next year based on what we see right now.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that will come from the line of Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: And that will come from the line of Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Question on Creganna, understanding it just closed, but if you can just give some anecdotes in terms of customer engagement number one? Number two, just kind of what that does for you more broadly in kind of the medical opportunity set?
componenttext: Question on Creganna, understanding it just closed, but if you can just give some anecdotes in terms of customer engagement number one? Number two, just kind of what that does for you more broadly in kind of the medical opportunity set?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Craig. It's Terrence. So let's -- the reaction from the customers has been very positive. Certainly, we made the first move in this space last year with AdvancedCath and I think the customer reaction of having both of these together to get bigger sc
componenttext: Sure, Craig. It's Terrence. So let's -- the reaction from the customers has been very positive. Certainly, we made the first move in this space last year with AdvancedCath and I think the customer reaction of having both of these together to get bigger scale in a space, where like we said it's about a $3 billion market, but we're basically a #2 player right now in that, customers have really appreciated. So that's a real positive. I think secondly as we talked about, to the second part of your question, around what does it do, what's really nice about what Creganna does for us is really round out the portfolio. So just to remind everyone, it gets us about 90% of that integrated solution we'll have internally. I think the other thing that is very powerful, not only their position in their engineering, but where it's positioned in the world, really balances out our medical platform and they fill it not only with manufacturing both with the engineering and fill the gap we had around Europe with their strong Irish presence, and then clearly bringing in 225 engineers that know that space, knows of that location, really doubled our engineering capability. So really feel we have a very nice platform to continue to build upon and very early, but very excited about it as well.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: One thing I would add, Terrence, is we complement Creganna in China with our size in China and our robust platform across China and an existing medical business there in that market is made-to-order for minimally invasive, because you have the growing --
componenttext: One thing I would add, Terrence, is we complement Creganna in China with our size in China and our robust platform across China and an existing medical business there in that market is made-to-order for minimally invasive, because you have the growing -- a huge population and aging population and you don't quite have the affordability, so this -- we're really excited about helping them scale much faster than they would normally been able to in China.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, as my follow-up on the tuck-in announced this morning. If I look back to MEAS, they were -- did a number of tuck-ins and many deals, to kind of build the base that you have today. So just your strategy in the sensor market, it feels like
componenttext: Got it. And then, as my follow-up on the tuck-in announced this morning. If I look back to MEAS, they were -- did a number of tuck-ins and many deals, to kind of build the base that you have today. So just your strategy in the sensor market, it feels like that's a market that is very fragmented, there's a lot of growth, there's a lot of opportunities, but could we expect more along these lines in terms of you doing these type of $40 million, $50 million type revenue deals?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Craig, you said it very well. Number one is, it's a very fragmented market and what we like about what was announced today with Jaquet really is this is a speed sensor product company that really plays very strongly into Transportation both in the Industr
componenttext: Craig, you said it very well. Number one is, it's a very fragmented market and what we like about what was announced today with Jaquet really is this is a speed sensor product company that really plays very strongly into Transportation both in the Industrial Transportation side as well as Automotive in the turbocharger applications. So I think when you look at the sensor space, you'll continue to see us do things similar to this as we continue to build out the portfolio and build on what both MEAS has and what we had historically, and continue to grow this business. So very excited about the business we announced last night, it will help strengthen us in the Transportation space.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that will come from Shawn Harrison with Longbow Research.
componenttext: And that will come from Shawn Harrison with Longbow Research.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: What is -- just the buyback, just to be clear on the math, is there about $1.1 billion now available on the buyback? And should we assume the June quarter gets you back to the normal cadence of say $150 million to $250 million type of activity?
componenttext: What is -- just the buyback, just to be clear on the math, is there about $1.1 billion now available on the buyback? And should we assume the June quarter gets you back to the normal cadence of say $150 million to $250 million type of activity?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi Shawn, this is Mario. We still have actually about $1.3 billion of authorized. And just a reminder in terms of what we talked about in the comments, our strategy remains very much consistent with that path and a reminder of what we have accomplished in
componenttext: Hi Shawn, this is Mario. We still have actually about $1.3 billion of authorized. And just a reminder in terms of what we talked about in the comments, our strategy remains very much consistent with that path and a reminder of what we have accomplished in the last 18 months. And then, Tom, you just want to add anything?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would say, yes, we're going to get back probably to the lower end of the normal range in the next couple of quarters and we bought back $3 billion over the last 9 months. We did make the Creganna acquisition and -- but we feel the 2/3, 1/3 split r
componenttext: Sure. I would say, yes, we're going to get back probably to the lower end of the normal range in the next couple of quarters and we bought back $3 billion over the last 9 months. We did make the Creganna acquisition and -- but we feel the 2/3, 1/3 split really works for us. We haven't seen anything that changes our view from a strategic point of view, that's the sensible capital allocation. And as you know it, all of you have been following us for a while, there are periods where it's a lot higher than the 2/3 return to capital and then there's periods where we make any kind of sizable acquisition where it dips below that.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And as a follow-up just on auto in general maybe, it's a two-parter. Have you seen any impact from the earthquake in Japan, I think Toyota was give or take around $0.5 billion customer if my notes from 2011 are correct? And then just
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And as a follow-up just on auto in general maybe, it's a two-parter. Have you seen any impact from the earthquake in Japan, I think Toyota was give or take around $0.5 billion customer if my notes from 2011 are correct? And then just also on what you think the impact of China stimulus is on the business this year and how that could affect the business rolling into fiscal '17?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Shawn, it's Terrence. I think first of all, let's take Japan. What I would say of Japan, I think you're sizing of Toyota is about right. When you sit there and you think through the earthquake in Japan, clearly that's a fluid situation, that we're monitor
componenttext: Shawn, it's Terrence. I think first of all, let's take Japan. What I would say of Japan, I think you're sizing of Toyota is about right. When you sit there and you think through the earthquake in Japan, clearly that's a fluid situation, that we're monitoring with our customers. We have not seen any disruptions yet. We're sort of assuming normal pattern. But where we see demand at, it may impact some timing a little bit, but we're talking to our customers constantly and making sure we're helping them any way they can as they work through that tragic event in Japan. On China stimulus, I think that's a little bit more of a complicated question that when you look at it, we did get an act [ph] in our first quarter as China's overall production adjusted, so we talked about that. What we have seen is China coming back to about a 6% production environment a year post that, which is pretty much in line with GDP. I don't think we know whether the China stimulus accelerated some production or demand, but we do sort of view that China production long term will stay around GDP of China. So I don't think we're far off right now. I think we'll have to see as the stimulus works off, if there is any timing effects. But right now, we feel pretty good as production has restimulated post the first quarter being very slow.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And its Mark Delaney with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And its Mark Delaney with Goldman Sachs.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first one is a follow-up on the Q4 guidance. I know you have talked about some of the top-down factors that you're thinking about in terms of the different end markets. Can you help us understand is there anything that you're getting from specific cus
componenttext: The first one is a follow-up on the Q4 guidance. I know you have talked about some of the top-down factors that you're thinking about in terms of the different end markets. Can you help us understand is there anything that you're getting from specific customer forecasts that are giving you a lot of visibility that Q4 is up sequentially from Q3? Is there anything on the kind of the lead times? I thought they are normally 4 to 6 weeks. It seems like it's more top-down driven. But if you have a bottom-up reconciliation that is giving you more confidence, that would helpful, I think?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a lot of customers, so there is a lot of data points. I would say the biggest indicators are just on one hand what we said in Industrial, so we do see that sequential growth in orders and it continued into April pretty solidly, so that gives us co
componenttext: We have a lot of customers, so there is a lot of data points. I would say the biggest indicators are just on one hand what we said in Industrial, so we do see that sequential growth in orders and it continued into April pretty solidly, so that gives us confidence. It's doesn't -- it's not a slam dunk. The channel partners all are pretty much back to positive book-to-bill. Seeing POS in line, with increasing demand and reflecting inventory levels and the channel back in line. So those are all positive indicators. And if you recall at this time, last year, those indicators were starting to -- they were raising caution flags. They were going the other way. So that's what has given us some optimism. Again, we're not expecting a boom from Q3 to Q4. I think it's just where the cycle is this time versus prior years. And of course, got to always keep reminding you of that extra week. It's confusing to all of us, but there's an extra week there. So when you strip that out, we're talking about $40 million in revenue pickup. But right now, it feels, we think that's balanced. I mean, we know a lot more in the end of the third quarter, but when we look at what the channel pattern is versus prior years, when we look at our Industrial businesses orders sequentially and seeing it both in the OEM customers and the channel customers, that's what gives us that confidence. Terrace, do you want to -- did I miss anything there?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think you said it very well, Tom.
componenttext: No, I think you said it very well, Tom.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I appreciate the additional color there. And then follow-up question on the tax rate commentary, and kind of actually a two-parter. So I think 23% to 24% was the comment. What sort of effect should we expect for the potential settlement around the o
componenttext: Okay. I appreciate the additional color there. And then follow-up question on the tax rate commentary, and kind of actually a two-parter. So I think 23% to 24% was the comment. What sort of effect should we expect for the potential settlement around the old Tyco liabilities, should we be looking for any other income line? Are there changes there? And then can you just clarify the long-term guidance of 23% to 24% include what you think potential impact might be around earnings stripping regulation? Or you just haven't had a chance to better put that into numbers yet?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, but for the question, I think that what we talked about in the comments, our expectation for the longer term remains at 23% to 24%. That does not include any implications around regulations because it's really too early to talk about any potential im
componenttext: Yes, but for the question, I think that what we talked about in the comments, our expectation for the longer term remains at 23% to 24%. That does not include any implications around regulations because it's really too early to talk about any potential impact there we think we can get in. And when it comes to the second half, we do expect it to be a little bit lower than the 23% to 24%. And that's mostly driven around distribution of profitability around jurisdiction more than expectation around some --

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we'll go to line of William Stein with SunTrust.
componenttext: And we'll go to line of William Stein with SunTrust.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm still having trouble understanding your comments about the Transportation segment. I think that you noted that Automotive is at least as strong as it looked previously and that the downward adjustment to the full year guide in that segment is related
componenttext: I'm still having trouble understanding your comments about the Transportation segment. I think that you noted that Automotive is at least as strong as it looked previously and that the downward adjustment to the full year guide in that segment is related to the Sensor business. So you're seeing -- it sounds like you're seeing Industrial Sensor applications roll off at the same time that you expect the rest of the industrial exposure to start to improve. So maybe you start by reconciling that and then I'll have a follow-up please.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me start with that. I think -- well on -- the way to think about the sensor piece of that is, growth is slowing whereas in the connector part of the business, growth was down, right, because of inventory correction. So now we expect what's going to ha
componenttext: Let me start with that. I think -- well on -- the way to think about the sensor piece of that is, growth is slowing whereas in the connector part of the business, growth was down, right, because of inventory correction. So now we expect what's going to happen in the second half of the year in the industrial connectivity business, flat and then a little bit of growth in Q4. But Sensors is a different story. It's just really growth slowing, reflecting this uncertainty out there. Terrence, you want to talk more about Transportation?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Tom, you said it well. When you think through the interconnect piece of Industrial, about 50% of it goes through distribution and Sensor is very little. So what we've seen is we've actually seen our Sensors Industrial actually come down and slow more
componenttext: No. Tom, you said it well. When you think through the interconnect piece of Industrial, about 50% of it goes through distribution and Sensor is very little. So what we've seen is we've actually seen our Sensors Industrial actually come down and slow more like our direct customers. So, Tom, is very much right on it. In the rest of the Transportation, Will, it is like we said in the comments, we see the production environment staying steady at 2%, 2.5% growth. Certainly, China being a big driver of it, Europe being up slightly. So we see that continuing to be solid, and Transportation, when you say it's down a little bit, really has to do with that sensor comment. Perhaps...

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the follow-up there, is that within Transportation, Sensors is still quite small, I don't know 10% or 15% of the total transport. And I suspect that what's really driving the full year difference is some -- you made a comment on the prepared remarks ar
componenttext: So the follow-up there, is that within Transportation, Sensors is still quite small, I don't know 10% or 15% of the total transport. And I suspect that what's really driving the full year difference is some -- you made a comment on the prepared remarks around a supply chain or some other inventory adjustment that one of your customers is making in North America. Can you help us -- we're really trying to understand what's going on here, and is this sort of a valid read as to what's going on in the industry? Or is this particular to TE and is it very temporary and then snaps back? Or is there a bigger problem here?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, it is actually just how customers schedule orders into it, they change their process. So it does affect the numbers. It does not affect demand and that did impact our orders, but it is not impacting the demand we're seeing from customers. So really
componenttext: Well, it is actually just how customers schedule orders into it, they change their process. So it does affect the numbers. It does not affect demand and that did impact our orders, but it is not impacting the demand we're seeing from customers. So really it's just their process of how they gave orders. They've changed to a more real time and giving us a firm full-out calendar view of it, and that adjustment impacted our orders, but it doesn't impact the demand patterns at all. It's just how we do business between the 2 companies.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I would add, Will, is just to help -- helps with the understanding a bit here, is our Automotive business will grow more in the second half than it does in the first half. So we're not -- the mixes are changing, North America plateauing a bit, China
componenttext: What I would add, Will, is just to help -- helps with the understanding a bit here, is our Automotive business will grow more in the second half than it does in the first half. So we're not -- the mixes are changing, North America plateauing a bit, China picking up, Europe steady. But when you step back to your question, "Hey, is there something going on here." We actually are going to have a stronger auto business in the second half than the first half. The overall sensor business growth rate is lower in the second half than the first half.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just one last comment, Will, in that 2%, 2.5% production environment, we do expect to be mid to high single digits in our Automotive business.
componenttext: Just one last comment, Will, in that 2%, 2.5% production environment, we do expect to be mid to high single digits in our Automotive business.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And it will come from Steven Fox with Cross Research.
componenttext: And it will come from Steven Fox with Cross Research.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: 2 questions from me. First off, just getting back to the Transportation margins. I understand the investments that are going on. I'm just curious if you can just give us some bigger picture comments on how you're managing those against our own short-term
componenttext: 2 questions from me. First off, just getting back to the Transportation margins. I understand the investments that are going on. I'm just curious if you can just give us some bigger picture comments on how you're managing those against our own short-term expectations for margins in that segment versus what's an expanding opportunity for growth? And then I had a follow-up.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Steve. So I'll just aggregate for a moment. The 3 pieces of our Transportation segment, Automotive, as Terrence said, very strong business. We expect to grow mid- to high single digits on 2% to 3% -- 2.5% production growth margins there, remain stro
componenttext: Sure, Steve. So I'll just aggregate for a moment. The 3 pieces of our Transportation segment, Automotive, as Terrence said, very strong business. We expect to grow mid- to high single digits on 2% to 3% -- 2.5% production growth margins there, remain strong. Sensors is below the Transportation averages. As you know, with the acquisition, with tremendous opportunity to move those margins up. And we are investing at a -- we are increasing our R&D investment at a faster rate than our sales growth in Sensors because the opportunity is so great. And customers absolutely like another strong resilient technology-rich company providing sensors into the Transportation market, and we are getting significant design-ins, and that requires engineers. It's been our plan from day 1 when we made the acquisition. And then in the Industrial Transportation business, which is the highest margin business in the group, we are -- I think we're navigating very well, maintaining our margins in a very -- almost really negative growth environment. Our growth is up because of our strong position in China and Europe which is offsetting North America. So we really within the segment, we manage those businesses separately based on the dynamics and the opportunity. And as Terrence said in his comments, we're pretty confident that you'll see the margins improve again sequentially. They went up 40 or 50 basis points Q1 to Q2. We expect that march to continue in the second half of the year with a little bit of volume growth over the first half of the year because there's a lot of operating leverage in this business.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just -- does -- to push back on the second point around Sensors, so is it safe to understand then that this was sort of an unusual quarter in terms of the investment levels versus revenues actually ramping with some new programs and that gap starts to
componenttext: So just -- does -- to push back on the second point around Sensors, so is it safe to understand then that this was sort of an unusual quarter in terms of the investment levels versus revenues actually ramping with some new programs and that gap starts to close going forward or does it stay at these levels for a little while, if you could sort of qualify that. And then my follow-up question was just to get an update on the CFO search?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it is ramping. We began increasing our Sensors investment late last year. And certainly, as we win programs and we talked about the design wins, especially in longer cycle businesses, there will be a gap, so I don't think it's an anomaly, but it's some
componenttext: So it is ramping. We began increasing our Sensors investment late last year. And certainly, as we win programs and we talked about the design wins, especially in longer cycle businesses, there will be a gap, so I don't think it's an anomaly, but it's something we're -- we have to invest ahead in as we win these programs, so it's a ramp that you're going to see in Sensors, but we've always expected that as we built the business.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: One more comment before the CFO -- I address the CFO search. I think it's really important, if you look at the transformation of the company to Harsh environment out of businesses that don't need -- that don't fit that definition. For us that's highly eng
componenttext: One more comment before the CFO -- I address the CFO search. I think it's really important, if you look at the transformation of the company to Harsh environment out of businesses that don't need -- that don't fit that definition. For us that's highly engineered, high barriers to entry, the capital allocation strategy, you see how that enables us even in a slow growth market to make strategic investments in something like Sensors, which is going to be a big business for us. And -- so yes, we have decided not to really change our strategy there given that we have all these other levers to drive the earnings growth that we set up 6 months ago, $3 billion, $12 billion, $4 billion in revenue and $4 in EPS. So that's part of the story too, an important part. On the CFO search, we're active as you can imagine. We have several internal candidates. We're going through the external candidates, obviously a critically important job. What I feel good about is, we have a very strong financial organization across the company, and the team is doing great. Mario has stepped in, and you can tell in an effective way, he has been with us for 10 years now, knows us very well from all dimensions, but yes that's an everyday item on our list. And I would expect in the next couple of months, we'll be making some announcements.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that will come from Jim Suva with Citi.
componenttext: And that will come from Jim Suva with Citi.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you mentioned on the prepared remarks as well as a little bit on the Q&A about your Automotive customer changing its supply chain a little bit, can you give us some details like did you benefit from that in a prior quarter or it sounds like this quar
componenttext: When you mentioned on the prepared remarks as well as a little bit on the Q&A about your Automotive customer changing its supply chain a little bit, can you give us some details like did you benefit from that in a prior quarter or it sounds like this quarter you had some weakness associated with that. Do you, then in the future, recoup that weakness, because it seems like at the end of the day the supply chain has to all connect itself. And was that change, I assume led by the customer, and it is then going to be rolled out globally to them or already has it? Is it centered around petroleum or diesel or electric or HV or how should we think about kind of what's going on there? And is this a rippling change to the industry? Then my second question or the follow-up would be on the intercompany debt. I know you mentioned that the past historical IRS settlement is in the works and you're accruing the interest for it and so on and so forth. Am I also correct to say that the new regulations also potentially and/or do impact your current debt structure amongst the company? And if, if so, can you quantify or let us know about anything around that? Or was it all just simply backward stating and going forward there are no considerations?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll take the first point. And then I'll take -- let Mario take the second point. Number one, it's at a customer, so when you look at programs and things like that, Jim, you can't really look at them. They change their process. So certainly, this was s
componenttext: So I'll take the first point. And then I'll take -- let Mario take the second point. Number one, it's at a customer, so when you look at programs and things like that, Jim, you can't really look at them. They change their process. So certainly, this was something that built up over time. It's why they did the process. They gave us very forward-looking orders that we recorded as orders and backlogs. Now they've moved to be a more current JIT was the way I would articulate it. That as scheduling came out and they're going to hit us with orders more frequently. That does create a debooking in our world. It does not impact the programs that we won with that customer throughout the world. So when you look at it, it is something that is very process-centric. It does not impact programs and you can't get it into individual diesel versus electric versus combustion engine. It isn't there. And over time, we'll just get those orders in more frequently than having it scheduled back. Now, I'll let Mario turn over to the second piece, you the tax question.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the tax question, first of all, on the settlement. We did mention that we have made a prepayment to the IRS that effectively stops the accrual on interest on that liability, which basically takes out most of the impact of the settlement when we'l
componenttext: Sure. On the tax question, first of all, on the settlement. We did mention that we have made a prepayment to the IRS that effectively stops the accrual on interest on that liability, which basically takes out most of the impact of the settlement when we'll actually settle. So we already have that included in our guidance, the fact that we have made that payment that impacts our tax rate. On the second element as far as the regs that are put in place, first of all, those regs -- those proposed regs are prospective, so they do not have any impact on our current company debt position. And again, it's a complicated matter that we are getting ahead around, but no, there is no impact to our current intercompany debt position, that would be only prospective.

componenttext: Realizing that your visibility is very good in the auto platforms, can you just give us your incremental enthusiasm or concerns over just where your share will be moving over the next several years? And has there been any platform wins on the passenger vehicle side from Measurement Specialties?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure thing. Yes -- I mean jeez. I couldn't -- I have to contain my optimism around the Automotive business globally. And with our presence and our range of technology, it's becoming more and more important. So we have a significant share in the Connectivi
componenttext: Sure thing. Yes -- I mean jeez. I couldn't -- I have to contain my optimism around the Automotive business globally. And with our presence and our range of technology, it's becoming more and more important. So we have a significant share in the Connectivity business. But over the last 5 years, we believe we increased that 5 points, that is quite an accomplishment and it really is as these solutions get more complex and all you have to do is kind of look under the hood to see how different it is over the last 5 or 6 years. The connectivity and the sensing solutions are more complex. On the connectivity side, we continue to win at a rate faster than we have in the past, which is why I think we said a few times if you go back 5 years and we talked about a 2% production environment, we would have talked about a 3% -- 3% to 4% revenue to TE environment. Now we believe that's 5% or 6%. And that's just really more market share than it is content. So I expect we'll continue to inch up our market share because of the range of capability we have and just for example, hybrid electric vehicles, the difference in our design-in rate in the last 3 years versus the first -- the prior 5 years is 2 to 3x. So as that market now continues to pick up we have -- with high content and we're extremely well positioned with all the leading platforms. So we feel good about that. On the Sensor side, we have won significant design-ins with MEAS technology and our go-to-market and the strength we bring and the credibility we bring to an auto customer. We're an auto supplier through and through and we've been doing that for over 50 years. And -- so they like the technology and they trust us and we're winning important awards, they're not showing up in revenue yet, and that will be in the next couple of years, but that's why when we talked earlier incredibly enthusiastic and feel that actually ahead of the hypothesis we had with MEAS about our ability to bring their technology into the auto market, which is the best market for Sensors. Terrence, want to add anything to do that?

It's not just concentrated in one geography, which actually leverages that great go-to-market that we have in our auto business we've always talked to you all about.

componenttext: Yes. Sure, Mike. Just let me grab it quick. When you look at the trends in the quarter between the 2 that you had, what we saw on the OEM side year-over-year was relatively flattish. And then, on the channel side, we were still down year-over-year, but what's nice is it was getting back to where last year's order levels were, which gives us confidence that when we get to the third and fourth quarter, our channel sales versus last year will be up, because we did have that correction in the fourth quarter. The other thing that Tom mentioned that I think's important, our channel partners have seen positive POS. They are seeing a book-to-bill greater than 1. So it's not only our order patterns and as we talk to our channel partners, they have also seen their book-to-bill go back above 1 as well as positive POS. So it's a combination of those factors that we see.

Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by, and welcome to the Q3 2016 TE Connectivity Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, today's conference is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Sujal Shah. Please go ahead.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining our conference call to discuss TE Connectivity's third quarter results. With me today are Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Lynch; President, Terrence Curtin; and Acting Chief Financial Officer, Mario Calast
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining our conference call to discuss TE Connectivity's third quarter results. With me today are Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Lynch; President, Terrence Curtin; and Acting Chief Financial Officer, Mario Calastri. 
During the course of this call, we will be providing certain forward-looking information. We ask you to review the forward-looking cautionary statements included in today's press release. In addition, we will use certain non-GAAP measures in our discussion this morning. We ask you to review the sections of our press release, and accompanying slide presentation that address the use of these items. Press release and related tables, along with the slide presentation, can be found on the Investor Relations portion of our website at te.com. [Operator Instructions] 
Now let me turn the call over to Tom for opening comments.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for joining us today. Please turn to Slide 3, and we will cover the highlights from today's call. Q3 was another quarter of solid execution in what continues to remain a challenging global economic environment. Our adjusted EPS was $1.08, represe
componenttext:
Thanks for joining us today. Please turn to Slide 3, and we will cover the highlights from today's call. 
Q3 was another quarter of solid execution in what continues to remain a challenging global economic environment. Our adjusted EPS was $1.08, represents a new company record, and was up 20% on a year-over-year basis. 
Sales of $3.12 billion were essentially flat with last year and in line with our guidance midpoint.  Sales and orders were up sequentially, with sales up 6%; and orders up 7%, excluding SubCom.
Adjusted operating margins were strong at 16%, with adjusted EBITDA margins of 21% in the quarter. 
For the fourth quarter, we expect the midpoint of our revenue and earnings per share to be $3 --  $3.35 billion and $1.20 respectively. Note that these features include the benefit of approximately $200 million in revenue and $0.10 in EPS from the extra week in Q4 that we've been communicating all year.  If we exclude the extra week, we would expect revenue to be up about 3% organically year-over-year and adjusted EPS growth to be 22% year-over-year.
Also, if you exclude the extra week, we expect our transportation business to have the best growth quarter in Q4 and our industrial segment to grow slightly for the first time this year.
For the full year, we are reiterating our adjusted EPS midpoint of $4, representing an 11% increase over the prior year.
Continued growth in most of our businesses, cost controls, share buybacks and a lower tax rates are more than offsetting the first of currency headwinds and supply chain correction.
This has enabled us to reiterate our original guidance that we provided in October 2015, delivering double-digit earnings growth in a slower economy.
As I mentioned earlier, we expect to return year-over-year organic growth in Q4, excluding the extra week.
During the quarter, we continue to strengthen our large portfolio through acquisition. In April, we announced the acquisition of Jaquet, which bolstered our portfolio of sensors for the auto market.
This morning, we announced an agreement to acquire the Intercontec Group, a German-based manufacturer of high-quality industrial metric circular connectors. This acquisition strengthens the position of harsh connectivity applications for factory automation and will be reported in the industrial segment.
In addition, we're pleased to say our recent acquisition of Creganna is performing very well and ahead of expectations and positions TE as a leader in the high-growth, minimally invasive market.
We had a very strong cash generation quarter, with free cash flow of almost $600 million. This brings our year-to-date free cash flow to just about $1 billion.
During the quarter, we returned approximately $230 million to shareholders, including about $100 million in share buybacks. Year-to-date, we have returned nearly $2.9 billion to shareholders, including $2.5 billion in share buybacks.
We expect to continue to take a balanced approach with our capital strategy, returning approximately 2/3 of our free cash flow to shareholders over time, with 1/3 free cash flow being through acquisition. 
I'll now turn it over to Terrence Curtin, who will cover our performance in more detail.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom and good morning, everyone. Before we get to the segment updates, I'd like to cover our orders for the quarter, which will help provide the foundation for our results and expectations.So if you could please turn to Slide 4. And this shows ou
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom and good morning, everyone. Before we get to the segment updates, I'd like to cover our orders for the quarter, which will help provide the foundation for our results and expectations.
So if you could please turn to Slide 4. And this shows our order trends, excluding our SubCom business. 
Overall, orders were essentially flat year-over-year and improved again sequentially by 7%. As the supply chain correction that impact us from the first half are behind us. Our book-to-bill was 1.01, and we also had slight growth year-over-year, reflecting the recovery and stability of our end markets.
The transportation, orders remain solid with 7% sequential growth, industrial orders grew 15% sequentially. And I do want to highlight about 60% of the industrial order growth was due to the acquisition of Creganna, with remainder of the growth made growth based across our industrial businesses.
In industrial, we saw order growth in each region as the inventory supply chain is now back in line, and we expect sales growth in the second half over the first half across each of our Industrial business.
In communications, excluding the impact of the sale of our Circuit Protection business last quarter, we saw sequential growth of 3%, driven by both our appliances and data and devices business. 
Now to talk to SubCom, that business continues its strong momentum. We were recently named as the supplier of the New Marias [ph] Transatlantic Program and with this award, we have approximately $1 billion of programs in force in our SubCom business.
Please turn to Slide 5 so I can discuss our transportation solutions segment results.
Segment sales grew 2% organically in the quarter, with growth in auto and in Commercial Transportation, offset by weakness in sensors that we highlighted last quarter.
Our auto sales growth in the quarter was in line with our expectations, and growth was driven by strength in Europe and China, partially offset by the year-over-year decline in North America.
For fiscal 2016, we continue to expect mid-single-digit organic revenue growth in auto on a 2% to 2.5% global auto production growth environment. While we are maintaining our view of global auto production, the regional profile is slightly different versus our prior view.
We now expect slightly higher growth in Europe and China, offset by slower growth in North America. We do remain confident that our Auto business will continue to grow ahead of auto production, driven by the electronic content growth as well as the rich plate line of platform ranch from the design wins, generated over the past several years.
In the fourth quarter, we expect our Auto business to have mid-teen organic growth, including the extra week. If you exclude the extra week, we expect our growth to be about half of that mid-teen growth in the mid-single digits.
We were also very pleased with our Commercial Transportation organic growth of 3% year-over-year, in what continues to be a challenging backdrop. The growth we experienced was driven by the heavy truck sector in China and Europe, while in North America, heavy truck market did continue to remain weak as well as weakness in the global construction and Ag markets.
Turning to sensors, we saw a 2% organic decline as we continue to be impacted by the weakness in industrial-related markets which make up more than half of our sensors sales. We continue to see strong design momentum especially in the automotive space and we expect future growth.
For the segment, adjusted operating margins were 19.4%, and were in line with our expectations, and we saw sequential expansion of 40 basis points.
Now let me turn to Industrial Solutions, if you could please turn to Slide 6.
Overall segment sales were up 5% year-over-year due to the acquisition of Creganna. If you remove the impact of Creganna, organic sales declined 4%. About half of the organic decline is driven by the impact of the oil and gas downturn, which has resulted in our oil and gas sales being down 31%. 
On a geographic basis, we continue to see trends across the segment that are consistent. Europe is stable and growing in many markets, North America continues to be weak and China remains sluggish.
When we started the year, we expect this further market improvement in China and North America and what we're actually seeing currently.
Now turning to the markets within the segment. In the industrial equipment area, we saw a 14% growth driven by the Creganna acquisition, which as Tom mentioned is performing ahead of our expectations. 
We are very excited about the growth potential in the minimally invasive medical market. If you exclude Creganna, the industrial equipment area, we did see a decline of 7% organically due to softness in North America and in China, but we did see a sequential growth of 4% on an organic basis as we see markets coming back in long.
In the aerospace and defense area, our sales grew 4% organically, with strong performance both in the commercial air and in the defense markets.
And in energy, our business was flat organically, with growth in the Americas and Europe, offset by declines in Asia.
As we look forward, we expect first half to second half growth of approximately 12%, with growth in each of the business units now that the inventory corrections are behind us.
From a margin perspective, adjusted operating margins were slightly down year-over-year, driven entirely by the declines in our higher-margin Oil and Gas business, which impacted segment operating margins by partially 100 basis points year-over-year.
Segment operating margins expanded 180 basis points sequentially as we expected, driven by both the benefit of increased volumes and cost management.
Now let me turn over to communication solutions. And if you could please turn to Page 7 of the slides.
During the quarter, the communication solutions segment revenue was down 4% organically year-over-year, but grew 8% sequentially on an organic basis, if you exclude the impact of the Circuit Protection divestiture. Our SubCom business saw 10% year-over-year growth, driven by strong execution from the multiples project it has in force. And as I stated earlier, the value of the programs in force with the new program we just launched is approximately $1 billion.  And we continue to expect SubCom to grow approximately 20% year-over-year in 2016.
Our appliance business sales grew 2% organically, while our data and devices business declined 17% organically due to both the Circuit Protection sale as well as product exits.
We did experience sequential sales growth in the data and devices area, if you exclude the Circuit Protection divestiture.
For the segment, adjusted operating margins expanded 80 basis points year-over-year, as well as 270 basis point sequentially.
Now with that, I'll turn it back over to Mario to cover the financials.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terrence, and good morning, everyone. Please turn to Slide 8 where I will provide more details on earning.Adjusted operating income of $501 million was essentially flat prior year of flat sales. Adjusted operating margin of 16.1%. Net [ph] opera
componenttext:
Thanks, Terrence, and good morning, everyone. Please turn to Slide 8 where I will provide more details on earning.
Adjusted operating income of $501 million was essentially flat prior year of flat sales. Adjusted operating margin of 16.1%. Net [ph] operating income was $452 million and included $80 million of acquisition-related charges. And net restructuring and other charges of $31 million.
Adjusted EPS was $1.08 for the quarter, up 20% from the prior year, with balances from share buybacks and a lower tax rate of 17%.
The tax rate was lower than we expected, resulting in an incremental benefit of $0.04 in the quarter. We expect the fourth quarter tax rate to be at a similar level as Q3. Note that the Q3 and Q4 tax rates are lower than our run rate. We now expect the full year 2016 tax rate to be approximately 20%.
GAAP EPS was $2.19 for the quarter, driven by a $1.21 expense benefit, primarily from the settlement of all pre-separation tax disputes with Internal Revenue Service. As we previously disclosed, Tyco International [ph] entered into an agreement with the IRS to resolve all disputes related to the previously disclosed with the company issues.
As a result, we recognized a reduction of tax results of $1.1 billion as well as an expense of $604 million, representing a reduction in receivables from our tax sharing agreements with Tyco International in the median. We're happy to report that all of our IRS legacy tax disputes are now closed. As a result of the IRS settlement, we wanted to give you some color in our tax rate and income going forward.
The IRS settlement benefit tax rate, however, [indiscernible] essentially offset by the reduction income, generated by the tax sharing agreement with Tyco and Comedan [ph] . We now assume that these long-term adjusted tax rate declines to approximately 20%, versus our previously communicated range of 23% to 24%.
At the same time, going forward, we should assume that the IRS settlement will be essentially neutral to EPS.
We now expect approximately $110 million of restructuring charges for the full year, $10 million increase from the prior guidance as we accelerate certain actions due to slightly weaker and overall economic conditions.
I'll now turn into Slide 9. Our business is executing well in an uncertain macro environment. We're pleased to report sequential improvement in all of the operating markets from the prior quarter. Our adjusted gross margin in the quarter was 33%, in line with our expectations. Adjusted operating margins expanded 30 basis points year-over-year, with a strong and spending control and improvement of such decline with higher-margin business.
Total operating expenses were $528 million in the quarter, down 4% from the prior year. We continue to tightly manage discretionary spending while balancing our continuing investment in our harsh businesses.
Moving to cash flow. In the quarter, cash from continuing operations was $750 million, and our free cash flow was $589 million, up from prior year levels due to strong working capital improvements.
We saw year-over-year improvement in DSOs and inventory days of [indiscernible].
We have generated nearly $1 billion in free cash flow for the year to date, bringing [indiscernible]. And we continue to expect full year to cash flow with approximate [indiscernible].
Adjusted EBITDA margin have explained the profitability performance of our businesses with acquisitions. And adjusted EBITDA margins in Q3 were 20.7% [ph] , 460 basis points above adjusted operating margins over prior year.
Continue to be pleased with the operating performance of our business, especially given the challenging macro backdrop. Tom mentioned earlier, we announced the agreement to acquire Intercontec, expanding our harsh connectivity portfolio in the industrial sector. We expect Intercontec to add approximately $75 million of sales and $32 million of EBITDA on an annual basis. Transaction is a cash deal of $340 million that is expected to close in September 2016, and be accretive to adjusted EPS next year.
We have added a balance sheet and cash flow summary in the appendix for additional details.  And now let me turn it back to Tom.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mario. I'll now cover our guidance. So please turn to Slide 10 for the Q4 outlook.We expect Q4 revenue of $3.25 billion to $3.45 billion and adjusted EPS of $1.17 to $1.23.  This guidance includes the extra week we have discussed throughout the
componenttext:
Thanks, Mario. I'll now cover our guidance. So please turn to Slide 10 for the Q4 outlook.
We expect Q4 revenue of $3.25 billion to $3.45 billion and adjusted EPS of $1.17 to $1.23.  This guidance includes the extra week we have discussed throughout the year, which adds approximately $200 million of revenue and $0.10 of EPS. Excluding this extra week, we expect revenue to be up about 3% organically at the midpoint and adjusted EPS to be up 22%, a very good finish to our year.
Slide 10 provides details on actual and organic growth by segment. The extra week results in total growth of 11% in the quarter. We expect strong performance in our harsh businesses including automotive, Commercial Transportation, commercial aerospace, medical and appliances. In addition, the Creganna acquisition adds revenue from a high-growth interventional medical market and SubCom continues to remain robust, with multiple programs in force. 
Communications continue to be impacted year-on-year by the sale of the Circuit Protection business and product exits in data and devices.
Now please turn to Slide 11.
For the full year, we expect revenue of $12.25 billion, and our reiterating our full year adjusted EPS guidance of $4 at the midpoint, about 11% during year-on-year. This adjusted EPS output is the same guidance we provided back in October. 
I feel very good about our ability to drive this performance in a slow economy. 
In transportation, we continue to expect auto growth to grow -- we continue to expect Auto to grow in the mid-single-digit to organically on a 2% to 2.5% vehicle production growth. 
In industrial, while organic growth is expected to be down year-over-year for the full year due to the impact of the oil and gas downturn and supply chain corrections in the first half, we do expect strong growth on the first half to the second half across all of our business units in the industrial sector. 
In communications, our SubCom business continues to be the primary driver of growth, but we do expect both our appliance and data and devices business to grow in the second half. This is especially for our data and devices segment.
This past quarter was an important threshold for TE, and reflects the strength of our model, namely focus our investments in harsh environment applications, relentlessly drive GEOA [ph] through the organization to deliver a strong productivity and as you can see, strong working capital and cash flows results; and consistently execute our capital allocation plan. 
On a normalized 13-week per quarter basis, in a low growth world, we are delivering second half revenue growth, 16% [ph] adjusted operating margins, strong double-digit adjusted earnings per share growth and outstanding cash flow.
And with that, let's open it up for questions.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And today our first question comes from the line of Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And today our first question comes from the line of Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Industrial market, nice to see a little recovery there. But just kind of big picture how you manage the near-term profitability, which is weak in the current backdrop versus longer term growth expectations. I know you guys have been investing for industri
componenttext: Industrial market, nice to see a little recovery there. But just kind of big picture how you manage the near-term profitability, which is weak in the current backdrop versus longer term growth expectations. I know you guys have been investing for industrial, but just help us with kind of the longer term path in what you see is appropriate margins for that business longer term.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Tom. I'll ask Terence to add on when I'm done here. Industrial is an important obviously, an incredibly important segment for us, where we're well-positioned and as you can see with the Intercontec acquisition, this is an important area to add in
componenttext: This is Tom. I'll ask Terence to add on when I'm done here. Industrial is an important obviously, an incredibly important segment for us, where we're well-positioned and as you can see with the Intercontec acquisition, this is an important area to add in organically as well. It has been a pretty sluggish environment, with the exception of commercial aerospace for the last several years. But it's fundamentally very good business. We still believe this is the business with high teen operating margins, if you get to a normalized growth over time. And you saw the leverage with a little bit of growth sequentially on our operating margin. So it fits right into the sweet spot of a harsh environment, highly-engineered products, but we have a tremendous range of products, we have expanded that product range not only in connectors with the recent acquisition, but with our sensor acquisition over a couple of years ago. While those markets are a little soft right now, we continue to be very bullish. So important market, well-positioned in the market, in every market, so wherever the industrial leaders of the world are, we are there close to them. Terrence, you want to add to that?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The only thing I wanted to add, Craig, is we're pretty proud of where we've gone the margin to. Well it's not, we're we want it to be long term, but when you think about the oil and gas effect we've had, it's slightly north 100 [ph] basis points. So in a
componenttext: The only thing I wanted to add, Craig, is we're pretty proud of where we've gone the margin to. Well it's not, we're we want it to be long term, but when you think about the oil and gas effect we've had, it's slightly north 100 [ph] basis points. So in a market that's flattish at best, being able to get back and cover that headwind we have. So clearly, that is something that when you look the margin has impacted us and that has come down. I think, also, we still have an industrial equipment space that I talked about in the call. Still I would say, this probably the other sluggish areas just trying to get momentum. I do think as the volume comes in, saw a great improvement we have of 100 basis point sequentially, if you see the volume through. But I do think we're doing a good job balancing it. So good growth, in relationship to ComAir and defense, 4%, I think, we're performing very well there. So overall, I think, say margin expectation we've had is higher teen. But clearly, I think, we battled through the oil and gas downturn pretty well from a margin perspective.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

Now when you deal with more integration and really as how do we bring the portfolio we had did so well together, early stages on that but I think, that's what Joe get some of the value creation on the growth side and how we are making for the integration and get to a higher concept per unit opportunity that either companies had together. So I think, it's much more rant bringing the products together, the go to market is how do you make sure there's a cover a large player in that space and what we've had in the Creganna the years and have a nice position as we get to the leading position.

componenttext: Mark, a couple of points I would say. The fundamental point is the design wins over many years are coming into play. So that's been great for us a longtime, and we continue to expect that to be. So just momentum in design and share. I think, also last year's fourth quarter was up -- wasn't a strong quarter particularly in China. It was in Europe and in the U.S., but China was in the midst of a kind of a 3-quarter [ph] decline. We've seen that recovery in our third quarter this year, and expect to see year-over-year growth in the fourth quarter. But the bottom line is, it's a pretty solid market. We are well-positioned in it. Terrence you want to add anything to that?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: Yes the only other thing is I think, when you look at fourth quarter, fourth quarter -- and we had some blips earlier in the year around how production was, like Tom said China. When you look at production, production has been pretty stable and -- we're at that 2%, 2.5% production rate and I think that's really just proving our model that we can grow that mid-single-digit to 2%, 2.5% production rate. And while we are not guiding for next year, I do think, thinking about next year and about a 2% production environment, is how we're thinking about right now we'll update you in the fall, when we give the '17 guidance.

componenttext: Wamsi, yes just to reiterate the regional view of transportation. China improving in Q3, expect to see that continue in Q4. Europe, sort of on a steady track for a couple of years now. Steady reasonable growth. And the U.S., following a bit but in a high level. I mean, it get nears this 18 million [ph] per unit level, I do think it's slowed down a little bit if you hear what the OEMs are saying. So we have factored that into our outlook for sure in Q4. We haven't really factored in any BREXIT, we're of course, we're so close to the Auto OEM, talking to them all the time and right now, meaning if you look at our first 3 weeks order rates in transportation in July, they are very, very robust. So not [indiscernible] not crazy hot, but up over last year as we expected nicely and continuing to work they have been as Terrence laid out with his comments earlier, strong third quarter. So and just to reiterate, I think, the industry and what we see listening to our customers and it's still early and we'll get more specific next quarter, but kind of feels like a 2% production rate if we had a -- put the gauntlet down right now for next year. Probably

You do have to pull the extra week out of the -- our fourth quarter.

componenttext: Got it. A follow-up. componenttext: Well, I think, number one, Amit, we have to call takeout [indiscernible] soft environment, really get to where we've been, to keep it flat, even with the higher margin on oil and gas impact that we've had. componenttext: I think, with that, as when you this you got commercial air and defense above the guided energy a little bit below medical moving up with the acquisition, because that's accretive to the margin. And then, you have the Industrial Equipment business that's really been the factory floor and a flat market for a couple of years, but is fundamentally a really business and the business which is a nice product line and the revenue as well accretive to margin. So we feel pretty confident that with reasonable industrial production, will follow that. And also embedded are there is a significant piece of the business challenge which is attracted business.

componenttext: What I wanted to drill in was the restructuring, looking I guess now for $110 million this year. What would be the savings that you'll see in fiscal '16? headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Mario. We have increased slightly our restructuring for this year, up to $110 million. The way you should read it is normally the pay back is around 18 months to 2 years. So you should think about the benefit in '17 to be on that basis. And as far
componenttext: This is Mario. We have increased slightly our restructuring for this year, up to $110 million. The way you should read it is normally the pay back is around 18 months to 2 years. So you should think about the benefit in '17 to be on that basis. And as far as pipeline of restructuring activity going into 2017, we're going to be much more clear in the next quarter, with the guidance but you should expect some of that [indiscernible] into '17 as well.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: As a follow up, maybe for you Tom or Terrence. M&A activity, I don't know if it's timing, but it's stepped up now, 3 acquisitions over the past 2 quarters. Is the environment for M&A freeing up? I know valuations aren't cheap. Or is there just, given the
componenttext: As a follow up, maybe for you Tom or Terrence. M&A activity, I don't know if it's timing, but it's stepped up now, 3 acquisitions over the past 2 quarters. Is the environment for M&A freeing up? I know valuations aren't cheap. Or is there just, given the shift in the portfolio to harsh environment, just more resources being put on the split the work M&A so we should expect maybe a more consistent cadence of M&A over the next few years?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Shawn, good question. I think, this short period of time is more coincidence than anything else honestly because just to give you a little bit of history, Intercontec we've been, like we often do, and is often the case with a really nice privately held co
componenttext: Shawn, good question. I think, this short period of time is more coincidence than anything else honestly because just to give you a little bit of history, Intercontec we've been, like we often do, and is often the case with a really nice privately held company, it takes a while towards -- and in this case, we actually did some market experiments, I would say, over a couple of years to prove to both of us, both parties, that there was synergy. And it was great. So that's been in the works for a while. Jaquet, the sensor is a fragmented market and there's always small sensor companies, most of which we're not interested in. Much shorter [indiscernible] now it's a Creganna, was shorter than normal, but part of the plan once we have done advance AdvancedCath, so they happened to come into these 3 months way ahead of others. Intercontec would have been a couple of years ago but sometimes that's how they work out. So I don't think the universe of properties or the availability has changed that much, Terrence you want to add some color?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Tom , I think you said it right. I think, it is, some of these things -- if something gets auctioned, like in Creganna, we don't control that [indiscernible]. And then Intercontec, it was a journey of -- with the owner of that also want to see compara
componenttext: No, Tom , I think you said it right. I think, it is, some of these things -- if something gets auctioned, like in Creganna, we don't control that [indiscernible]. And then Intercontec, it was a journey of -- with the owner of that also want to see comparable selling to make sure you see how this company is going to go up. And I think, that takes time. I think it's a little bit of 3 things at once, so it's just ask Shawn, I think when you look at the environment, the environment you said it very well. I think, things were still, you have to pay for good assets and I think, we have 3 good assets here. And that's a lot of our strategy. Our strategy we talked about interventional a lot over the past 6 months, but I think, when you also look here, Jaquet in the sensors how we strengthen those along with automotive-s especially in turbo sensor applications. And I think, when you look at Intercontac, what's great about Intercontac is it gets us closer to the factory floor, their leader in that space that really relates to how do you observe your motors on the factory floor and which is a very harsh application that you make sure you power the signal into the application control, not to -- make sure you never have downtime. This company has an exceptional product line and technology that we are bringing in, that was a gap [indiscernible] . So I think, each one of this show how a lot of our portfolio continues to evolve around [indiscernible] as well as how do we serve our customers better with a more complete portfolio. So I think, that's what really the 3 of these being together at the same time, is you get to see how we're thinking. So hopefully, that helps.

componenttext: Just a couple of specific questions on some of the results. First of all, the appliance business, it sounded like it's experiencing some decent growth. Can you just talk about what's driving some of that growth in a little bit more specific? And then, secondly, you talked about organic growth X Creganna, I was just curious what kind of growth you're seeing from Creganna, out-of-the-box with that business? And then I have a quick follow-up.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure Steve, it's Terrence. First of all, on appliance, what we've seen in the appliance. Appliances been impacted a little bit around the inventory corrections channel partners. Because they do have part of that business goes through something. If you're
componenttext: Sure Steve, it's Terrence. First of all, on appliance, what we've seen in the appliance. Appliances been impacted a little bit around the inventory corrections channel partners. Because they do have part of that business goes through something. If you're looking what we've been experiencing and we've been experiencing a very robust U.S. and Europe production environment. So I think, were seeing a nice growth there. That's been the backdrop. What we have had in appliance is that China OEMs has slowed in China. So the appliance production in China has come off a little bit, so while we're growing 2% it's really been driven by the U.S. and Europe. We see it again here in the quarter, we just guided to. If you go to the next, we probably expect a similar picture. On Creganna, certainly we didn't owe  it -- own it a year ago, but this first quarter, we did own it, it would have grown about 11%. So when we look at that interventional market as we forecast, we see a market that we like it very much because of the trends for it to mid to higher single-digit market environment and that interventional space of $3  billion market that Creganna helps us get a leadership position in. But really a good first quarter that on a pro forma, we own to be a year ago, would have been up about 11%.

componenttext: The margins are similar, and we're seeing margins gradually move up. So it's following the same general pattern. None of the patterns are exactly the same. But yes, we are seeing the margins now are higher than they were, on a 1-year run rate than they we are a year ago. So we are seeing that happen.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me start with your, BREXIT question, Jim. It's hard to feel any impact right now. I mean, as I said, if you -- we've been looking at our orders right through last year. They're running what we basis guidance on slightly ahead run rate last quarter
componenttext: So let me start with your, BREXIT question, Jim. It's hard to feel any impact right now. I mean, as I said, if you -- we've been looking at our orders right through last year. They're running what we basis guidance on slightly ahead run rate last quarter and nicely ahead of the run rate last year. So and Europe, continues to be really solid, kind of across most of our businesses. So it's -- we haven't really seen any impact yet, like I guess like everybody else in the planet, we're waiting to see if there's really going to be an impact or not. On the tax rate, Mario, you want to?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just reiterating the comments around total tax rates, our view is now around 20%, down from where we communicated previously, which we were around 23% to 24%. Currently, the settlement, the IRS settlement is the biggest moving piece here. As you think abo
componenttext: Just reiterating the comments around total tax rates, our view is now around 20%, down from where we communicated previously, which we were around 23% to 24%. Currently, the settlement, the IRS settlement is the biggest moving piece here. As you think about that, you need to combine with the fashion the other end, going away. So that is why we correct or rise it as a kind of an EPS neutral move. And of course, for the '16 in the second half, we are experiencing a lower than run rate tax rate. So here in Q3, we have the 17% [ph] tax rates. We expect Q4 to be [indiscernible] .

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
