componenttext: And we do have a question from the line of William Stein with SunTrust.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gentlemen, I think, Terrence, you've mentioned sort of a preview on auto production for next year. And Tom, you might have reiterated that view. I'm curious whether the China stimulus that's been in place since last September, and therefore, about to annu
componenttext: Gentlemen, I think, Terrence, you've mentioned sort of a preview on auto production for next year. And Tom, you might have reiterated that view. I'm curious whether the China stimulus that's been in place since last September, and therefore, about to annualize, how that factors into your view of global production, if at all? And why shouldn't that drag unit -- global unit growth more?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Will, yes. I think, what we certainly saw is the stimulus helped reverse the decline that was happening earlier in the year. So we return to growth, nice solid growth in Q3, and we'll see that again in Q4 in auto. And if you -- and all the numbers from th
componenttext: Will, yes. I think, what we certainly saw is the stimulus helped reverse the decline that was happening earlier in the year. So we return to growth, nice solid growth in Q3, and we'll see that again in Q4 in auto. And if you -- and all the numbers from the industry are, of course, very preliminary for next year, but they are assuming a reasonable China market next year, not a booming market, not a bearish market. That kind of how we see it and what our leadership over there sees. So I don't think we don't expect an unusually positive catalyst from it, because I think, it's kind of -- it's really already into the base the way I would think about it.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: What I'm asking is the stimulus for consumers for taxes in automotive, that's in place since last September. So is that annualized is, if they're not an expectation that China is going to be a more difficult market next year?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, it's hard to say. But again, based in -- if you think of this year being 2%, 2.5%, next year being in the 2% range, other markets were kind of weak, some of the Asian markets very consistent. It really depends how is China going to come off. I
componenttext: Okay. Well, it's hard to say. But again, based in -- if you think of this year being 2%, 2.5%, next year being in the 2% range, other markets were kind of weak, some of the Asian markets very consistent. It really depends how is China going to come off. If you look at macro China, where the weakness has been in industrial China, not consumer China, the consumer markets in China and the consumer in China continues to be pretty healthy and the growth in the China economy is in the consumer market, which is a good thing over -- in general, because that's what fuels economic growth and eventually the industrial part of the economy. So I think -- we don't have a crystal ball, for sure, Will, but right now what we're seeing is we would expect reasonable growth in China, definitely down from what it's run over. Take fiscal -- our fiscal '16 [ph] out of it because growth in fiscal '16 is pretty modest. I think, we cannot see another modest growth in fiscal '17, just below the historical growth rate. And that's how you get to the -- just want to have 2% production growth in '17. But I think, that's what will play out, but generally we're not seeing or anything from our customers, from our pattern that would say differently right now. We're better in our third quarter than we thought, probably, a little better in the third quarter and a little less than fourth quarter, we saw the current being a little bit different in the second half overall, it's about where we expect.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, just to add one thing, we look to 2% next year, we'll got it more next quarter. It does assume a slower China production environment versus this year's China production environment. So that will -- we do expect to anticipate being a little slower e
componenttext: Sorry, just to add one thing, we look to 2% next year, we'll got it more next quarter. It does assume a slower China production environment versus this year's China production environment. So that will -- we do expect to anticipate being a little slower environment in China from a production perspective due to 1.6 L engine that you talked about. We still expect the China production environment to grow next year based on what we're seeing at that.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

And then in aerospace, I think, we've had some negative data points from Boeing and Airbus under wide-body jets, and I'm wondering if that's a weather results and outlook are doing well despite that because of growth elsewhere or you're just not seeing that weakness yet?

componenttext: Will, a couple of things. Commercial aerospace, we feel very good with the program wins and even if you have some [indiscernible] we do view that our commercial Aerospace business would grow that mid-single digit with the platform we have on, not only with the big carriers also, the regional carriers like Ambi Air [ph] and Bombardier. I think, in defense, it's been nice that as we see some of the budgetary things, we start to see some pickup in defense. I think you saw at our quarterly results, where we grew 4%. And I think, that's creating a little bit more of a constructive backdrop in the sense that we've had a quite some time with the whole sequesters on it. So it's actually nice to see it burning in the revenue on the defense side. I think, the momentum we have there is strong as well. So close our areas, are the view, you're going to continue to see [indiscernible]

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple for me here. Regarding in the sensor business and the fact that it has it been growing here. And I understand the industrial weakness that you've seen. It's those like you're talking about some increase in bookings. So could you update us wh
componenttext: Just a couple for me here. Regarding in the sensor business and the fact that it has it been growing here. And I understand the industrial weakness that you've seen. It's those like you're talking about some increase in bookings. So could you update us when you expect that to grow? And on the automotive side, the cross-selling, I know it takes 2 to 3 years in terms of these design cycles, but when do you expect, Tom, to see the payoff in the automotive side of things?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Matt, automotive as you know, the cycle is a little bit longer. Not [indiscernible]. Everybody is designing faster these days. But I would say '18. That's when these nice wins are really going to start to come in, in fact you'll see it in the aut
componenttext: I think, Matt, automotive as you know, the cycle is a little bit longer. Not [indiscernible]. Everybody is designing faster these days. But I would say '18. That's when these nice wins are really going to start to come in, in fact you'll see it in the auto revenue line. In the industrial line, I think, it will follow kind of industrial production. The design win nature there is very different, it's like the industrial market in general, much more fragmented, smaller revenue per design. So in there, it's continue to build scale in the non-auto products, and make sure that we are growing with our slightly better than the market. But auto is where you can get significant chunks of business for design. So we really feel good about that. And we are a little disappointed in the industrial market side of it, but still very, very excited about the prospects of that expenses in the portfolio. What it does for us is every customer, every big OEM, we always have a nice seat at the table. But it's like you get a bigger seat, sometimes a bigger table because it brings in the integrated solution opportunities. You've heard us talk about that, we've had some tremendous design wins in automotive with that. And it's starting to lend itself, I think, in the aerospace market. Terrence have talked before about the medical markets when you pull together higher interventional capability along with our core connector, doing and protect, and miniaturized sensors. So it's a pretty robust portfolio that we have that should bolster our growth rate in industrial.

componenttext: Sure. Well, you're absolutely right that the harsh -- the acquisition strategy is focused on the harsh environments. And there's a lot of opportunity there. It's our real house and it's where we can bring the most value for customers. So that where we are exclusively focused. On our M&A, at this point in time, I would say that on a shifting over to data and devices business that add on to what Terrence said, we're feeling really good about the progress and the fact that we're going to see sequential growth in the fourth quarter for the first time in a long time. Restructuring getting behind us, the margin's moving up. We definitely see this business is getting on the improvement path, so encouraged about that. So we have to earn that one quarter at a time. So we're not getting carried away here. But a lot of hard work to reposition the business around our core connector capability, which is still very good. And very good products with attractive margins, and as far your point on the product exits, it will probably, a little bit early next year, Terrence [indiscernible] .

componenttext: I think on the exits, Mario has talked about it earlier to your question. Certainly, they have been a drag in the past 2 [ph] years. So there's  a lot of those exits are related to consumer space and making sure where we spend resources, where we create value for our customer as well as for our shareholders.

componenttext: Tom, I wanted to ask, you guys have been switching some of the business around with acquisition and divestiture over the past couple of years. How do you feel about the portfolio right now? Do you think you have the right mix of business? Is there any opportunity to do additional divestitures at this point?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I feel really good about the portfolio. You know it. Heck, quite a bit in it, at one point in time, and now we're up to the safe [ph] 90% connectivity in sensors. We often get asked about SubCom. It's an unusual business for sure. There really isn't
componenttext: Sure. I feel really good about the portfolio. You know it. Heck, quite a bit in it, at one point in time, and now we're up to the safe [ph] 90% connectivity in sensors. We often get asked about SubCom. It's an unusual business for sure. There really isn't that much of a market. There's no market, really, that we've seen in 10 years sell it, but it's an exceptionally well-run business, it's a clear world leader in what it does, and especially because the customer base is different. And with cloud computing and make it data centers and fiber security and all those things driving, what we think is going to lead to the more transcontinental connectivity. SubCom can hold its own in our portfolio, but when you get past that, everything else is related. So more of what you see is tweaking the product lines, which will always have in the business. Product line and maybe it's commoditized, we don't have any unique value, let's price ourselves out of it or may be sell it, but for the most part, the most recent one being start the protection, kind of the big chunks that are available, never say never, but really like the portfolio, I think. You can see it in the margins, the harsh businesses, if you look at those businesses, above company average margin, nicely, very dependable, highly-engineered, really played to our strength at the engineering and manufacturing company. And as Terrence pointed out, with the acquisition, we just met -- we just added $1.5 billion of touch [ph] revenue into the portfolio over the last 90 days. And EBITDA margins well above the company average. And this is what we know best and do best. So this is what we're going to continue after the cycle.

I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Sujal Shah. Please go ahead.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining our conference call to discuss TE Connectivity's third quarter results. With me today are Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Lynch; President, Terrence Curtin; and Acting Chief Financial Officer, Mario Calast
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining our conference call to discuss TE Connectivity's third quarter results. With me today are Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Tom Lynch; President, Terrence Curtin; and Acting Chief Financial Officer, Mario Calastri. 
During the course of this call, we will be providing certain forward-looking information. We ask you to review the forward-looking cautionary statements included in today's press release. In addition, we will use certain non-GAAP measures in our discussion this morning. We ask you to review the sections of our press release and the accompanying slide presentation that address the use of these items. Press release and related tables, along with the slide presentation, can be found on the Investor Relations portion of our website at te.com. [Operator Instructions] 
Now let me turn the call over to Tom for opening comments.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks for joining us today. Please turn to Slide 3, and we will cover the highlights from today's call. Q3 was another quarter of solid execution in what continues to remain a challenging global economic environment. Our adjusted EPS of $1.08 represent
componenttext:
Thanks for joining us today. Please turn to Slide 3, and we will cover the highlights from today's call. 
Q3 was another quarter of solid execution in what continues to remain a challenging global economic environment. Our adjusted EPS of $1.08 represents a new company record and was up 20% on a year-over-year basis. 
Sales of $3.12 billion were essentially flat with last year and in line with our guidance midpoint.  Sales and orders were up sequentially with sales up 6% and orders up 7%, excluding SubCom.
Adjusted operating margins were strong at 16% with adjusted EBITDA margins of 21% in the quarter. 
For the fourth quarter, we expect the midpoint of our revenue and earnings per share to be $3 --  $3.35 billion and $1.20 respectively. Note that these features include the benefit of approximately $200 million in revenue and $0.10 in EPS from the extra week in Q4 that we've been communicating all year. If we exclude the extra week, we would expect revenue to be up about 3% organically year-over-year and adjusted EPS growth to be 22% year-over-year. Also, if you exclude the extra week, we expect our Transportation business to have the best growth quarter in Q4 in our industrial segment to grow slightly for the first time this year.
For the full year, we are reiterating our adjusted EPS midpoint of $4, representing an 11% increase over the prior year.
Continued growth in most of our harsh businesses, cost controls, share buybacks and a lower tax rate are more than offsetting the first half currency headwinds and supply chain correction. This has enabled us to reiterate our original guidance that we provided in October 2015, delivering double-digit earnings growth in a slower economy.
As I mentioned earlier, we expect to return the year-over-year organic growth in Q4, excluding the extra week.
During the quarter, we continued to strengthen our harsh portfolio through acquisition. In April, we announced the acquisition of Jaquet, which bolstered our portfolio of sensors for the auto market.
This morning, we announced an agreement to acquire the Intercontec Group, a German-based manufacturer of high-quality industrial metric circular connectors. This acquisition strengthens the position in harsh connectivity applications for factory automation and will be reported in the industrial segment.
In addition, we're pleased to say our recent acquisition of Creganna is performing very well and ahead of expectations and positions TE as a leader in the high-growth, minimally invasive market.
We had a very strong cash generation quarter with free cash flow of almost $600 million. This brings our year-to-date free cash flow to just about $1 billion.
During the quarter, we've returned approximately $230 million to shareholders, including about $100 million in share buybacks. Year-to-date, we have returned nearly $2.9 billion to shareholders, including $2.5 billion in share buybacks.
We expect to continue to take a balanced approach with our capital strategy, returning approximately 2/3 of our free cash flow to shareholders over time with 1/3 free cash flow being used for acquisition.
I'll now turn it over to Terrence Curtin, who will cover our performance in more detail.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Before we get to the segment updates, I'd like to cover our orders for the quarter, which will help provide the foundation for our results and expectations. So if you could please turn to Slide 4. And this shows ou
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Before we get to the segment updates, I'd like to cover our orders for the quarter, which will help provide the foundation for our results and expectations. So if you could please turn to Slide 4. And this shows our order trends, excluding our SubCom business. 
Overall, orders were essentially flat year-over-year and improved again sequentially by 7%. As the supply chain corrections that impact us from the first half are behind us. Our book-to-bill was 1.01, and we also had slight growth year-over-year, reflecting the recovery and stability of our end markets.
The Transportation. Orders remain solid with 7% sequential growth. Industrial orders grew 15% sequentially. And I do want to highlight about 60% of the industrial order growth was due to the acquisition of Creganna, with remainder of the growth being broad-based across our industrial businesses.
In industrial, we saw order growth in each region as the inventory supply chain is now back in line, and we expect sales growth in the second half over the first half across each of our industrial businesses.
In Communications, excluding the impact of the sale of our Circuit Protection business last quarter, we saw sequential growth of 3%, driven by both our Appliances and Data and Devices businesses. 
Now to talk to SubCom, that business continues its strong momentum. We were recently named as the supplier of the new Marea's trans-atlantic program. And with this award, we have approximately $1 billion of programs in force in our SubCom business.
Please turn to Slide 5 so I can discuss our Transportation Solutions segment results. Segment sales grew 2% organically in the quarter with growth in Auto and in Commercial Transportation, offset by weakness in sensors that we highlighted last quarter.
Our Auto sales growth in the quarter was in line with our expectations, and growth was driven by strength in Europe and China, partially offset by the year-over-year decline in North America.
For fiscal 2016, we continue to expect mid-single-digit organic revenue growth in auto on a 2% to 2.5% global auto production growth environment. While we are maintaining our view of global auto production, the regional profile is slightly different versus our prior view. We now expect slightly higher growth in Europe and China, offset by slower growth in North America. We do remain confident that our Auto business will continue to grow ahead of Auto production, driven by the electronic content growth as well as the rich plate line of platform ranch from the design wins generated over the past several years.
In the fourth quarter, we expect our Auto business to have mid-teen organic growth, including the extra week. If you exclude the extra week, we expect our growth to be about half of that mid-teen growth in the mid-single digits.
We were also very pleased with our Commercial Transportation organic growth of 3% year-over-year in what continues to be a challenging backdrop. The growth we experienced was driven by the heavy truck sector in China and Europe. While in North America, heavy truck market did continue to remain weak as well as weakness in the global construction and ag markets.
Turning to sensors. We saw a 2% organic decline as we continue to be impacted by the weakness in industrial-related markets, which make up more than half of our sensors sales. We continue to see strong design momentum, especially in the automotive space that we expect to fuel future growth.
For the segment, adjusted operating margins were 19.4%, and we're in line with our expectations and we saw sequential expansion of 40 basis points.
Now let me turn to Industrial Solutions, if you could please turn to Slide 6. Overall segment sales were up 5% year-over-year due to the acquisition of Creganna. If you remove the impact of Creganna, organic sales declined 4%. About half of the organic decline is driven by the impact of the oil and gas downturn, which has resulted in our oil and gas sales being down 31%.
On a geographic basis, we continue to see trends across the segment that are consistent. Europe is stable and growing in many markets, North America continues to be weak and China remains sluggish. When we started the year, we expect this further market improvement in China and North America and what we're actually seeing currently.
Now turning to the markets within the segment. In the industrial equipment area, we saw a 14% growth driven by the Creganna acquisition, which, as Tom mentioned, is performing ahead of our expectations. We are very excited about the growth potential in the minimally invasive medical market. If you exclude Creganna, the Industrial Equipment area, we did see a decline of 7% organically due to softness in North America and in China, but we did see a sequential growth of 4% on an organic basis as we see markets coming back in long.
In the Aerospace and Defense area, our sales grew 4% organically with strong performance both in the commercial air and in the defense markets.
And in energy, our business was flat organically with growth in the Americas and Europe, offset by declines in Asia.
As we look forward, we expect first half to second half growth of approximately 12% with growth in each of the business units, now that the inventory corrections are behind us.
From a margin perspective, adjusted operating margins were slightly down year-over-year, driven entirely by the declines in our higher-margin Oil & Gas business, which impacted segment operating margins by partially 100 basis points year-over-year.
Segment operating margins expanded 180 basis points sequentially as we expected, driven by both the benefit of increased volumes and cost management.
Now let me turn over to Communications Solutions, and if you could please turn to Page 7 of the slides. During the quarter, the Communications Solutions segment revenue was down 4% organically year-over-year, but grew 8% sequentially on an organic basis if you exclude the impact of the Circuit Protection divestiture. Our SubCom business saw 10% year-over-year growth, driven by strong execution from the multiple project it has in force. And as I stated earlier, the value of the programs in force with the new program we just won is approximately $1 billion. And we continue to expect SubCom to grow approximately 20% year-over-year in 2016.
Our Appliance business sales grew 2% organically, while our Data and Devices business declined 17% organically due to both the Circuit Protection sale as well as product exits. We did experience sequential sales growth in the Data and Devices area, if you exclude the Circuit Protection divestiture.
For the segment, adjusted operating margins expanded 80 basis points year-over-year as well as 270 basis point sequentially.
Now with that, I'll turn it back over to Mario to cover the financials.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Terrence, and good morning, everyone. Please turn to Slide 8 where I will provide more details on earning.Adjusted operating income of $501 million was essentially flat prior year on flat sales. Adjusted operating margin of 16.1%. GAAP operating
componenttext:
Thanks, Terrence, and good morning, everyone. Please turn to Slide 8 where I will provide more details on earning.
Adjusted operating income of $501 million was essentially flat prior year on flat sales. Adjusted operating margin of 16.1%. GAAP operating income was $452 million and included $80 million of acquisition-related charges and net restructuring and other charges of $31 million.
Adjusted EPS was $1.08 for the quarter, up 20% from the prior year, with balances from the share buyback and a lower tax rate of 17%.
The tax rate was lower than we expected, resulting in an incremental benefit of $0.04 in the quarter. We expect the fourth quarter tax rate to be at a similar level as Q3. Note that the Q3 and Q4 tax rates are lower than our run rate. We now expect the full year 2016 tax rate to be approximately 20%.
GAAP EPS was $2.19 for the quarter, driven by a $1.21 expense benefit, primarily from the settlement of all pre-separation tax disputes with Internal Revenue Service. As we've previously disclosed, Tyco International entered into an agreement with the IRS to resolve all disputes related to the previously disclosed with the company's debt issues.
As a result, we recognized a reduction of tax results of $1.1 billion as well as an expense of $604 million, representing a reduction in receivables from our tax sharing agreements with Tyco International and Covidien. We're happy to report that all of our IRS legacy tax disputes are now closed. As a result of the IRS settlement, we want to give you some color on our tax rate and other income going forward.
The IRS settlement benefits of tax rate, however, this time, it is essentially offset by the reduction in other income, generated by the tax sharing agreement with Tyco and Covidien. We now assume that this long-term adjusted tax rate declines to approximately 20% versus our previously communicated range of 23% to 24%. At the same time, going forward, we should assume that the IRS settlement will be essentially neutral to EPS.
We now expect approximately $110 million of restructuring charges for the full year, $10 million increase from the prior guidance as we accelerate certain actions due to slightly weaker and overall economic conditions.
Now turn it to Slide 9. Our business is executing well in an uncertain macro environment. We are pleased to report sequential improvements in all of the operating metrics in the prior quarter. Our adjusted gross margin in the quarter was 33%, in line with our expectations. 
Adjusted operating margins expanded 30 basis points year-over-year with a strong focus in spending control and as rotating [ph] improvements of such decline in higher-margin business.
Total operating expenses were $528 million in the quarter, down 4% in the prior year. We continue to tightly manage discretionary spending while balancing our continuing investment in our harsh businesses.
Moving to cash flow. In the quarter, cash from continuing operations was $750 million and our free cash flow was $589 million, up from prior year levels due to strong working capital improvements.
We saw year-over-year improvement in DSOs and inventory days on hand in [indiscernible]. We have generated nearly $1 billion in free cash flow for the year to date, reinforced with the help of our business. And we continue to expect full year to cash flow with approximate net income.
Adjusted EBITDA margin have explained the profitability performance of our businesses with the acquisitions. And adjusted EBITDA margins in Q3 were 20.7%, 460 basis points above adjusted operating margins and flat prior year.
We continue to be pleased with the operating performance of our business, especially given the challenging macro backdrops. Tom mentioned earlier, we announced the agreement to acquire Intercontec, expanding our harsh connectivity portfolio in the industrial sector. We expect Intercontec to add approximately $75 million of sales and $32 million of EBITDA on an annual basis. Transaction with cash deal, $340 million that is expected to close in September 2016 and be accretive to adjusted EPS next year.
We have added a balance sheet and cash flow summary in the appendix for additional details. And now let me turn it back to Tom.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mario. I'll now cover our guidance. So please turn to Slide 10 for the Q4 outlook.We expect Q4 revenue of $3.25 billion to $3.45 billion and adjusted EPS of $1.17 to $1.23. This guidance includes the extra week we have discussed throughout the y
componenttext:
Thanks, Mario. I'll now cover our guidance. So please turn to Slide 10 for the Q4 outlook.
We expect Q4 revenue of $3.25 billion to $3.45 billion and adjusted EPS of $1.17 to $1.23. This guidance includes the extra week we have discussed throughout the year, which adds approximately $200 million of revenue and $0.10 of EPS. Excluding this extra week, we expect revenue to be up about 3% organically at the midpoint and adjusted EPS to be up 22%, a very good finish to our year.
Slide 10 provides details on actual and organic growth by segment. The extra week results in total growth of 11% in the quarter. We expect strong performance in our harsh businesses including Automotive, Commercial Transportation, Commercial Aerospace, Medical and Appliances. In addition, the Creganna acquisition adds revenue from a high-growth interventional medical market, and SubCom continues to remain robust with multiple programs in force. 
Communications continues to be impacted year-on-year by the sale of the Circuit Protection business and product exits in Data and Devices.
Now please turn to Slide 11. For the full year, we expect revenue of $12.25 billion and are reiterating our full year adjusted EPS guidance of $4 at the midpoint, about 11% year-on-year. This adjusted EPS outlook is the same guidance we provided back in October. I feel very good about our ability to drive this performance in a slow economy.
In Transportation, we continue to expect Auto growth to grow -- we continue to expect Auto to grow in the mid-single digits organically on a 2% to 2.5% vehicle production growth. 
In Industrial, while organic growth is expected to be down year-over-year for the full year due to the impact of the oil and gas downturn and supply chain corrections in the first half, we do expect strong growth from the first half to the second half across all of our business units in the industrial segment.
In Communications, our SubCom business continues to be the primary driver of growth, but we do expect both our Appliances and Data and Devices business to grow in the second half. This is especially for our Data and Devices segment.
This past quarter was an important threshold for TE and reflects the strength of our model, namely focus our investments in harsh environment applications, relentlessly drive TEOA through the organization to deliver strong productivity. And as you can see, strong working capital and cash flow results, but it consistently execute our capital allocation plan. 
On a normalized 13-week per-quarter basis in a low-growth world, we are delivering second half revenue growth, 16% adjusted operating margins, strong double-digit adjusted earnings per share growth and outstanding cash flow.
And with that, let's open it up for questions.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And today our first question comes from the line of Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And today our first question comes from the line of Craig Hettenbach with Morgan Stanley.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The industrial market, nice to see a little recovery there. But just kind of big picture how you manage the near-term profitability, which is weak in the current backdrop versus longer-term growth expectations. I know you guys have been investing for indu
componenttext: The industrial market, nice to see a little recovery there. But just kind of big picture how you manage the near-term profitability, which is weak in the current backdrop versus longer-term growth expectations. I know you guys have been investing for industrial, but just help us with kind of the longer-term path in what you see is appropriate margins for that business longer term.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Tom. I'll ask Terrence to add on when I'm done here. Industrial is an important -- obviously and incredibly important segment for us, where we're well positioned. And as you can see with the Intercontec acquisition, this is an important area to ad
componenttext: This is Tom. I'll ask Terrence to add on when I'm done here. Industrial is an important -- obviously and incredibly important segment for us, where we're well positioned. And as you can see with the Intercontec acquisition, this is an important area to add in organically as well. It has been a pretty sluggish environment with the exception of Commercial Aerospace for the last several years, but it's fundamentally very good business. We still believe this is the business with high-teen operating margins, if you get kind of normalized growth over time. And you saw the leverage with a little bit of growth sequentially on our operating margin. So it fits right into the sweet spot of harsh environment, highly engineered products. We have a tremendous range of products. We have expanded that product range not only in connectors with the recent acquisition, but with our sensor acquisition of a couple of years ago. And while those markets are a little soft right now, we continue to be very bullish. So important market, well positioned in the market -- in every market. So wherever the industrial leaders of the world are, we are there close to them. Terrence, you want to add to that?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. The only thing I would add, Craig, is we're pretty proud of where we've gone the margin to. It's not where we want it to be long term, but when you think about the oil and gas effect we've had, it's slightly north 100 basis points. So we -- in a mark
componenttext: Yes. The only thing I would add, Craig, is we're pretty proud of where we've gone the margin to. It's not where we want it to be long term, but when you think about the oil and gas effect we've had, it's slightly north 100 basis points. So we -- in a market that's flattish and best, being able to get back and cover that headwind we have. So clearly, that is something that when you look the margin, it has impacted us and that has come down. I think, also, we still have an industrial equipment space that I talked about in the call that still I would say was probably the other sluggish areas, just trying to get momentum. I do think as the volume comes in and saw a great improvement we have about 100 basis point sequentially, you see the volume through. But I do think we're doing a good job balancing it. So good growth in relationship to ComAir [ph] and Defense, 4%, I think. We're performing very well there. So overall, I think, we continue at the same margin expectation we've had as higher teen. But clearly, I think, we battled through the oil and gas downturn pretty well from a margin perspective.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And if I could on my follow-up for the medical space, you guys have talked about kind of assistance solutions approach, if you will. Can you just talk about the go-to market there, how it might be different versus the traditional sales approach yo
componenttext: Got it. And if I could on my follow-up for the medical space, you guys have talked about kind of assistance solutions approach, if you will. Can you just talk about the go-to market there, how it might be different versus the traditional sales approach you have? And then also as it relates to that, what are you able to ring out in terms of value in medical?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, there's a couple of things to that. When you talk about the go-to market in medical, it is probably more akin to what we do in automotive. It's a much more direct sales, Craig. So when you said there what's great with Creganna, Creganna not only
componenttext: I think, there's a couple of things to that. When you talk about the go-to market in medical, it is probably more akin to what we do in automotive. It's a much more direct sales, Craig. So when you said there what's great with Creganna, Creganna not only help balance [indiscernible] we had geographically. But also with the 200 engineers, they came in to help service that model as well as the footprint that needs them behind. So I think, when you think through that space, it's much more direct. Now when you deal with more integration and really as how do we bring the portfolio we had and what they did so well together, and we're early stages on that. But I think that's where you'll get some of the value creation on the growth side, it's how we're making further integration and get to a higher content per unit opportunity that neither companies had together. So I think it's much more around bringing the product set together. The go-to market is how do you make sure you cover a large player in that space and what we've had. And with Creganna, they cover all the major players and have a nice position as we get to that leading position.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: To add, Craig, the customer feedback of us being acquirer has been very positive. Customers' newest preferably from all the things we build, but important to them that only with our strength and commitment to the market in there. So that's been pretty una
componenttext: To add, Craig, the customer feedback of us being acquirer has been very positive. Customers' newest preferably from all the things we build, but important to them that only with our strength and commitment to the market in there. So that's been pretty unanimous, we've been out to all the big customers.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: We do have a question from the line of Mark Delaney with Goldman Sachs.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on the Transportation segment. Can you talk about what the reason is that you think you're seeing an improvement in the year-over-year growth rates excluding the extra week in the Transportation segment in the fiscal fourth quarter and i
componenttext: First question is on the Transportation segment. Can you talk about what the reason is that you think you're seeing an improvement in the year-over-year growth rates excluding the extra week in the Transportation segment in the fiscal fourth quarter and if you can offer any views you have about the sustainability of the Auto cycle as you move going forward after the September quarter?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Mark. A couple of points I would say. The fundamental point is the design wins over many years are coming into play. So that's been great for us for a long time and continue to expect that to be. So just momentum in design and share, I think
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Mark. A couple of points I would say. The fundamental point is the design wins over many years are coming into play. So that's been great for us for a long time and continue to expect that to be. So just momentum in design and share, I think. Also, last year's fourth quarter was up -- wasn't a strong quarter, particularly in China. It was in Europe and in the U.S., but China was in the midst of a kind of a 3-quarter decline. We've seen that recovery in our third quarter this year and expect to see year-over-year growth in the fourth quarter. But the bottom line is, it's a pretty solid market. We're well positioned in it. Terrence you want to add anything to that?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, the only other thing is, I think, when you look at fourth quarter and we had some blips earlier in the year around how production was, like Tom said in China. When you look at production, production's been pretty stable, and we're at that 2%, 2.5
componenttext: Yes. No, the only other thing is, I think, when you look at fourth quarter and we had some blips earlier in the year around how production was, like Tom said in China. When you look at production, production's been pretty stable, and we're at that 2%, 2.5% production rate. And I think that's really just proving our model that we can grow that mid-single digit in a 2%, 2.5% production rate. And while we're not guiding for next year, I do think -- thinking about next year and about a 2% production environment is how we're thinking about it right now. We'll update you in the fall when we give that '17 guidance.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very helpful. And for a follow-up question on gross margins. They were down year-over-year in each of the first 3 quarters of fiscal of '16. I know you talked about the mix issues that have been impacting margins. Is there anything else going on with gros
componenttext: Very helpful. And for a follow-up question on gross margins. They were down year-over-year in each of the first 3 quarters of fiscal of '16. I know you talked about the mix issues that have been impacting margins. Is there anything else going on with gross margins being down? Or is it entirely mix?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're talking, Mark, about transportation, right?
componenttext: You're talking, Mark, about transportation, right?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: For the whole thing.
componenttext: For the whole thing.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: For the whole thing. It's a little bit of the volume in the first half and the mix. But now you can see, you get back to this 13-week quarters, $3.1 billion run rate, the margins are back 33% gross margin. The operating margins are back to 16%. So no, I m
componenttext: For the whole thing. It's a little bit of the volume in the first half and the mix. But now you can see, you get back to this 13-week quarters, $3.1 billion run rate, the margins are back 33% gross margin. The operating margins are back to 16%. So no, I mean, our productivity has been good this year. The help of the portfolio, I mean, you look at the dramatic improvement in the gross margins over the last several years in the operating margins because of the transformation of the portfolio. So now I tell you, we're getting back to sort of where we expect to be and of course, we expect to continue to improve as long as markets have some growth in them.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Wamsi Mohan of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Tom, organic growth in transport, you've noted some strength in China, also EMEA. Can you comment a little bit on the state of the multi-American market? I think you alluded to it being a little bit softer. How do you see there progressing? And are you
componenttext: So Tom, organic growth in transport, you've noted some strength in China, also EMEA. Can you comment a little bit on the state of the multi-American market? I think you alluded to it being a little bit softer. How do you see there progressing? And are you accounting for any softness in your outlook in European autos, particularly post-BREXIT? And I have a follow-up.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Wamsi. Yes, just to kind of iterate -- reiterate the regional view of transportation. China improving in Q3, expect to see that continue in Q4. Europe, sort of on a steady track for a couple of years now. Steady reasonable growth. And the U.S., fo
componenttext: Thanks, Wamsi. Yes, just to kind of iterate -- reiterate the regional view of transportation. China improving in Q3, expect to see that continue in Q4. Europe, sort of on a steady track for a couple of years now. Steady reasonable growth. And the U.S., following a bit, but in a high level. I mean, so you get near this 18 million per unit level, I do think it slowed down a little bit as you see what the OEMs are saying. So we have factored that in to our outlook, for sure, in Q4. We haven't really factored in any BREXIT. We're -- of course, we are so close to the Auto OEMs that is talking to them all the time. And right now, I mean, if you look at our first 3 weeks' order rates in transportation in July, they're very, very robust. So not [indiscernible], not crazy hot. But up over last year as we expected nicely and continuing to where they've been, and as Terrence laid out in his comments earlier, strong third quarter. So -- and just to reiterate, I think the industry and what we see listening to our customers, and it's still early and we'll get more specific next quarter, but it kind of feels like a 2% production rate if we had a -- put the gauntlet down right now for next year, probably.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That will be great. And thanks for calling out the impact of that extra week. So clearly in fiscal 4Q, I was wondering how should we think about seasonality going into the first quarter of next year? If you x out the $200 million, consensus is roughly dow
componenttext: That will be great. And thanks for calling out the impact of that extra week. So clearly in fiscal 4Q, I was wondering how should we think about seasonality going into the first quarter of next year? If you x out the $200 million, consensus is roughly down 3%. It was down 5% last year, but you obviously have made a lot of portfolio changes here and some other M&A here as well. So how should we really be thinking about the seasonality going to the first quarter of next year?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wamsi, I'll take that. It's Terrence. I think when you think about the seasonality, last year, we had some inventory corrections that started fourth quarter of [indiscernible] into first quarter [ph]. I think when we look at this correction to be behind u
componenttext: Wamsi, I'll take that. It's Terrence. I think when you think about the seasonality, last year, we had some inventory corrections that started fourth quarter of [indiscernible] into first quarter [ph]. I think when we look at this correction to be behind us, I think you can expect taking our Quarter 4, backing out the extra week and then assuming any work from a 3% to 5% normal seasonal spend down. So I do think you get into a top line perspective, much more of a normal seasonal Quarter 4 and a quarter long. As you're thinking about, you highlighted it well. You do have to pull the extra week out of our fourth quarter.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: And we do have a question from the line of Amit Daryanani from RBC Capital Markets.

componenttext: I have 2 questions as well. So just looking at the guide for September, maybe within transportation. You guys are looking for, I think, 70% growth, excluding the extra week in the transportation segment in September. The orders, well, I think, are up 2% based on the June quarter number. So could you guys maybe help me understand the delta between orders up 2% in the guide that you have, what else could drive the upside there?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you have the ongoing backlog, Amit. And as I said a minute ago, the orders continue into July to be really, really solid. And you have to think of there was inventory correction last year that especially affected China, so you have some of that norm
componenttext: Well, you have the ongoing backlog, Amit. And as I said a minute ago, the orders continue into July to be really, really solid. And you have to think of there was inventory correction last year that especially affected China, so you have some of that normalizing. So you don't have the normal just linear quarter-to-quarter by Q3 orders that look like Q4 sales. But when you look at our backlog right now and the way it's scheduled out and the rate of orders, it's a solid Q4.  Terrence, you want to add to that?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think what you see, we'll see a little bit of a seasonal step down like we normally get around Europe, so I actually think we're again back to a more normal pattern, Amit. I feel very good with the backlog, as you said, Tom, that backlogs there to d
componenttext: No. I think what you see, we'll see a little bit of a seasonal step down like we normally get around Europe, so I actually think we're again back to a more normal pattern, Amit. I feel very good with the backlog, as you said, Tom, that backlogs there to deliver on that 70% growth you are finalizing.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And I guess can I just follow up? Terrence, on the industrial side, you had some nice margin improvement in the quarter, but you guys always talked about industrial getting to -- in line to corporate average margin, 16%, 17%, let's just say. How d
componenttext: Got it. And I guess can I just follow up? Terrence, on the industrial side, you had some nice margin improvement in the quarter, but you guys always talked about industrial getting to -- in line to corporate average margin, 16%, 17%, let's just say. How do you think the path is there for the next 300 basis points of margin expansion? Is there an Absolute revenue number that you need to achieve? And are there incremental cost takeout that you would call out that should help you out as well?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, number one, Amit, we have been doing cost takeout as we've been in a small environment to really get to where we've been, to keep it flat, even with the higher margin oil and gas impact that we've had. I do think what's nice about the indus
componenttext: Well, I think, number one, Amit, we have been doing cost takeout as we've been in a small environment to really get to where we've been, to keep it flat, even with the higher margin oil and gas impact that we've had. I do think what's nice about the industrial business, and you saw it sequentially, is how strong the pull through can be in that business across the segment. So when you sit there, it is much more around volume as we continue to march up because a lot of the cost actions have always -- already been effectuated so we'll be much more volume dependent as we go from here.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think with that, when you disaggregate a bit, you got commercial air and defense above, we've got energy a little bit below, medical moving up with the acquisition because that's accretive to the margin. And then you have the Industrial Equipment busine
componenttext: I think with that, when you disaggregate a bit, you got commercial air and defense above, we've got energy a little bit below, medical moving up with the acquisition because that's accretive to the margin. And then you have the Industrial Equipment business that's really been -- the factory floor has been a flat market for a couple of years, but it's fundamentally a really nice business and the business we just added in, which is a nice add to the product line, into the revenue as well, is accretive to margin. So we feel pretty confident that with reasonable industrial production will follow that. And also embedded in there is a significant piece of the business goes through the channel, which is attractive business.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Shawn Harrison with Longbow Research company.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Shawn Harrison with Longbow Research company.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I wanted to drill on I guess was the restructuring, looking I guess now for $110 million this year. What would be the savings that you'll see in fiscal '16 and how much of that spills into '17? And I guess do you have any commentary in terms of how y
componenttext: What I wanted to drill on I guess was the restructuring, looking I guess now for $110 million this year. What would be the savings that you'll see in fiscal '16 and how much of that spills into '17? And I guess do you have any commentary in terms of how you would think about incremental restructuring actions in '17? Are you finished? Or are there other things that need to be tidied up?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Shawn. This is Mario. We have increased slightly our restructuring for this year up to $110 million. The way you should read it is normally the payback is around 18 months, 2 years. So you should think about the benefit in '17 to be on that basis. An
componenttext: Yes, Shawn. This is Mario. We have increased slightly our restructuring for this year up to $110 million. The way you should read it is normally the payback is around 18 months, 2 years. So you should think about the benefit in '17 to be on that basis. And as far as pipeline of restructuring activity going into 2017, we're going to be much more clear in the next quarter with the guidance but you should expect some of that in the year 2017 as well.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. As a follow-up, maybe for you, Tom or Terrence. M&A activity, I don't know if it's just timing, but it's stepped up now, 3 acquisitions over the past 2 quarters. Is the environment for M&A freeing up? I know valuations aren't cheap. Or is there just
componenttext: Okay. As a follow-up, maybe for you, Tom or Terrence. M&A activity, I don't know if it's just timing, but it's stepped up now, 3 acquisitions over the past 2 quarters. Is the environment for M&A freeing up? I know valuations aren't cheap. Or is there just, given the shift in the portfolio to a harsh environment, just more resources being put on -- put toward M&A so we should expect maybe a more consistent cadence of M&A over the next few years?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Shawn, thanks. Good question. I think this 3 in this short period of time is more coincidence than anything else, honestly, because -- just to give you a little of the history, Intercontec, we've been, like we often do, and is often the case with a really
componenttext: Shawn, thanks. Good question. I think this 3 in this short period of time is more coincidence than anything else, honestly, because -- just to give you a little of the history, Intercontec, we've been, like we often do, and is often the case with a really nice privately held company, it takes a while to work through it. And in this case, we actually did some market experiments, I would say, over a couple of years to prove to both of us, both parties, that there was synergy. And it was great. So that's been in the works for a while. Jaquet, the sensor is a fragmented market and there's always small sensor companies, most of which we're not interested in. That was a much shorter train. And I would say Creganna was shorter than normal, but part of the plan once we have done AdvancedCath, so that they happen to come into these 3 months way ahead of druthers [ph], Intercontec would have been a couple of years ago. But sometimes, that's how they work out. So I don't think the universe of properties or the availability has changed that much. Terrence, you want to add some color to that?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, Tom , I think you said it right. I think it is some of these things. If something gets auctioned, like in Creganna, we don't control that hotbox. And then in Intercontec, it was a journey of with the owner about also once he's comfortable selling and
componenttext: No, Tom , I think you said it right. I think it is some of these things. If something gets auctioned, like in Creganna, we don't control that hotbox. And then in Intercontec, it was a journey of with the owner about also once he's comfortable selling and making sure he sees how his company is going to go on. And I think that takes time. So I do think it's a little bit of 3 things at once, so it's -- just to add, Shawn, I think when you look at the environment, I think the environment -- you said it very well. I think things are still -- you have to pay for good assets and I think we have 3 good assets here. And that's a lot of our strategy. Our strategy, we talked about interventional a lot over the past 6 months. But I think when you also look here, Jaquet in the Sensors, how we strengthen those in Automotive especially in turbo sensor applications. And I think, when you look at Intercontec, what's great about Intercontec is it gets us closer to the factory floor, they're a leader in that space that really relates into how do you hook up servomotors on the factory floor and -- which is a very harsh application that you make sure you're powering your signal into the application's control, not to -- make sure you never have downtime. And the company has some exceptional product line and technology that we're bringing in that was a gap for TE. So I think each one of these show how our thought about the portfolio continues to evolve around harshness as well as how do we serve our customers better with a more complete portfolio. So I think that's what -- really, the 3 of these being together at the same time is you get to see how we're thinking. So hopefully, that helps.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Steven Fox with Cross Research.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Steven Fox with Cross Research.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016

componenttext: Just a couple of specific questions on some of the results. First of all, the appliance business, it sounded like it experienced some decent growth. Can you just talk about what's driving some of that growth in a little bit more specific? And then, secondly, you talked about organic growth x Creganna. I was just curious what kind of growth you're seeing from Creganna out-of-the-box with that business. And then I have a quick follow-up.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Steve. It's Terrence. Thanks for the question. First of all, on appliance, what we've seen in appliance. Appliance has been -- it got impacted a little bit around the inventory correction with our channel partners because they do have -- a part of t
componenttext: Sure, Steve. It's Terrence. Thanks for the question. First of all, on appliance, what we've seen in appliance. Appliance has been -- it got impacted a little bit around the inventory correction with our channel partners because they do have -- a part of their business goes through there. But if you really look at what we've been experiencing and we've been experiencing a very robust U.S. and Europe production environment. So I think we're seeing nice growth there. That's been the backdrop. What we have had in appliance is that the China OEMs, that has slowed in China. So the appliance production in China has come off a little bit. So while we're growing 2%, it's really been driven by the U.S. and Europe. We see it again here in the quarter we just guided to. You go into the next, we probably expect a similar picture. On Creganna, certainly we didn't owe it -- own it a year ago, but in this first quarter, if we did own it, it would have grown about 11%. So when we look at that interventional market as we've talked here, we see a market that we like it very much because of the trends that support mid to higher single-digit market environment and that interventional space of $3 billion [ph] market that Creganna helps us get a leadership position in. But really a good first quarter that on a pro forma, if we owned them a year ago, it would have been up about 11%.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. That's helpful. And then just real quick on the SubCom business. Given the growth you're seeing, where are we versus prior cycle margins? And can you talk to how margins have improved recently and how they may improve in the next couple of quarters
componenttext: Great. That's helpful. And then just real quick on the SubCom business. Given the growth you're seeing, where are we versus prior cycle margins? And can you talk to how margins have improved recently and how they may improve in the next couple of quarters?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The margins are similar, and we're seeing margins gradually move up. So it's following the same general pattern. No -- none of the patterns are exactly the same. But yes, we are seeing the margins now are higher than they were on a 1-year run rate than th
componenttext: The margins are similar, and we're seeing margins gradually move up. So it's following the same general pattern. No -- none of the patterns are exactly the same. But yes, we are seeing the margins now are higher than they were on a 1-year run rate than they we are a year ago. So we are seeing that happen.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we do have a question from the line of Jim Suva with Citi.
componenttext: And we do have a question from the line of Jim Suva with Citi.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you briefly -- you mentioned about, I believe it was automotive from BREXIT did not have a impact. Can you just make sure -- did I get that right? And then what about your other segments? Did you see any impact post the quarter close from BREXIT? An
componenttext: Could you briefly -- you mentioned about, I believe it was automotive from BREXIT did not have a impact. Can you just make sure -- did I get that right? And then what about your other segments? Did you see any impact post the quarter close from BREXIT? And then my follow-up, just to kind of throw it in at the same time is on the tax rates, it ended up this year, I think, lower than everyone expected. So it helped out your earnings, that's your reiterated guidance. So was it the industrial market that kind of the profitability came in softer? Or what was the cause that even though earnings reiterated guidance, and you have more M&A, the tax rate really helped out this year? In longer term, are we looking at a lower tax rate? How should we plan tax rate longer term?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me start with your, BREXIT question, Jim. Thanks for the comments, by the way. Yes, it's hard to feel any impact right now. I mean as I said, if you -- you can look at our orders right out to last week, they're running what we based this guidance o
componenttext: So let me start with your, BREXIT question, Jim. Thanks for the comments, by the way. Yes, it's hard to feel any impact right now. I mean as I said, if you -- you can look at our orders right out to last week, they're running what we based this guidance on and slightly ahead of the run rate last quarter and nicely ahead of the run rate last year. So -- and Europe continues to be really solid kind of across most of our businesses. So it's -- we haven't really seen any impact yet like, I guess -- like everybody else on the planet, we're waiting to see if there's really going to be an impact or not. On the tax rate, Mario, you want to...

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Just reiterating [ph] the comment around our long-term tax rate view is now around 20%, down from where we communicated previously, which we were around 23% to 24%. Currently, the settlement, the IRS settlement is the biggest moving piece here. As yo
componenttext: Yes. Just reiterating [ph] the comment around our long-term tax rate view is now around 20%, down from where we communicated previously, which we were around 23% to 24%. Currently, the settlement, the IRS settlement is the biggest moving piece here. As you think about that, you need to combine it with the -- basically the other income going away. So that is why we characterize it as kind of an EPS neutral movement. And of course, for '16 in the second half, we are experiencing a lower than run rate tax rate. So here in Q3, we have the 17% tax rates. We expect Q4 to be similar.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks for the details, and especially for pointing out the other income line fluctuates with the tax rate. I think some people will then struggle with that.
componenttext: Great. Thanks for the details, and especially for pointing out the other income line fluctuates with the tax rate. I think some people will then struggle with that.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we do have a question from the line of William Stein with SunTrust.
componenttext: And we do have a question from the line of William Stein with SunTrust.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gentlemen, I think, Terrence, you've mentioned sort of a preview on auto production for next year. And Tom, you might have reiterated that view. I'm curious whether the China stimulus that's been in place since last September, and it's therefore about to
componenttext: Gentlemen, I think, Terrence, you've mentioned sort of a preview on auto production for next year. And Tom, you might have reiterated that view. I'm curious whether the China stimulus that's been in place since last September, and it's therefore about to annualize, how that factors into your view of global production, if at all? And why shouldn't that drag unit -- global unit growth more?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Will. Yes, well, I think what we certainly saw is the stimulus helped reverse the decline that was happening early in the year. So we return to growth in -- nice solid growth in Q3, and we'll see that again in Q4 in auto. And if you -- and all the
componenttext: Thanks, Will. Yes, well, I think what we certainly saw is the stimulus helped reverse the decline that was happening early in the year. So we return to growth in -- nice solid growth in Q3, and we'll see that again in Q4 in auto. And if you -- and all the numbers from the industry are, of course, very preliminary for next year, but they're assuming a reasonable China market next year, not a booming market, not a bearish market. That's kind of how we see it and what our leadership over there sees. So I don't think we don't expect an unusually positive catalyst from it because I think it kind of -- it's really already into the base is the way I would think about it.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: To clarify, what I'm asking is the stimulus for consumers for taxes in Automotive that's been in place since last September. So as that annualizes, is there not an expectation that China is going to be a more difficult market next year?
componenttext: To clarify, what I'm asking is the stimulus for consumers for taxes in Automotive that's been in place since last September. So as that annualizes, is there not an expectation that China is going to be a more difficult market next year?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh, okay. Well, it's hard to say. But again, based in -- if you think of this year being 2% to 2.5%, next year being in the 2% range, other markets were kind of weak, some of the Asian markets were inconsistent. It really depends how is China going to com
componenttext: Oh, okay. Well, it's hard to say. But again, based in -- if you think of this year being 2% to 2.5%, next year being in the 2% range, other markets were kind of weak, some of the Asian markets were inconsistent. It really depends how is China going to come off. I mean if you look at macro China, where the weakness has been is in industrial China, not consumer China. The consumer markets in China and the consumer in China continues to be pretty healthy and the growth in the China economy is in the consumer market, which is a good thing over -- in general because that's what fuels economic growth and then eventually feed the industrial part of the economy. So I think -- we don't have a crystal ball for sure, Will, but right now, what we're seeing is we would expect reasonable growth in China, definitely down from what it's run over. Take fiscal -- our fiscal '16 out of it because growth in fiscal '16 is pretty modest. I think we kind of see another modest growth in fiscal '17, it's below the historical growth rate. And that's how you get to this 1.5%, 2% production growth in '17. But I think this will play out. But generally, we're not hearing or seeing anything from our customers, from our pattern that would say differently right now. It was better in the third quarter than we thought, probably a little better in the third quarter and a little less than fourth quarter, we saw the curve being a little bit different in the second half. Overall, it's about where we expect.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, just to add one thing. We look to 2% next year, we'll guide more next quarter. It does assume a slower China production environment versus this year's China production environment. So that will -- we do anticipate it will be a little slower environ
componenttext: Sorry, just to add one thing. We look to 2% next year, we'll guide more next quarter. It does assume a slower China production environment versus this year's China production environment. So that will -- we do anticipate it will be a little slower environment in China from a production perspective due to the 1.6 liter engine that you talked about. We still expect the China production environment to grow next year based on what we're seeing today.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That perspective is very helpful. If I can squeeze one more in. Your military and aerospace end markets seem to have done well in the quarter. I'm wondering if the DoD budget and the sequestration, is that helping? Or is this more sort of unrelated to tha
componenttext: That perspective is very helpful. If I can squeeze one more in. Your military and aerospace end markets seem to have done well in the quarter. I'm wondering if the DoD budget and the sequestration, is that helping? Or is this more sort of unrelated to that? And then in aerospace, I think, we've had some negative data points from Boeing and Airbus on the wide-body jets, and I'm wondering if that's -- whether your results and outlook are doing well despite that because of growth elsewhere or you're just not seeing that weakness yet?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Will, thanks for the question. A couple of things. Commercial aerospace, we feel very good with the program wins and even if you have some of the wide body adjustment, we do view that our commercial Aerospace business would grow that mid-single digit with
componenttext: Will, thanks for the question. A couple of things. Commercial aerospace, we feel very good with the program wins and even if you have some of the wide body adjustment, we do view that our commercial Aerospace business would grow that mid-single digit with the platform we have won, not only with the big carriers also, the regional carriers like Embraer and Bombardier. So I actually feel very good even with those data points you mentioned about. I think in defense, it's been nice that as we see some of the budgetary things happen, we're starting to see some pickup in defense. I think you saw it at our quarterly results, where we grew 4%. And I think, that's creating a little bit more of a constructive backdrop in defense, and we've had it quite some time when the whole sequester started. So it's actually nice to see it burning in the revenue on the defense side. And I think the momentum we have there is strong as well. So both are areas that I view, you're going to continue to see growth out of [indiscernible].

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we do have a question from the line of Matt Sheerin with Stifel.
componenttext: And we do have a question from the line of Matt Sheerin with Stifel.

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple for me here. Regarding the Sensor business and the fact that it hasn't been growing here. And I understand the industrial weakness that you've seen. It sounds like you're talking about some increase in bookings. So could you update us when y
componenttext: Just a couple for me here. Regarding the Sensor business and the fact that it hasn't been growing here. And I understand the industrial weakness that you've seen. It sounds like you're talking about some increase in bookings. So could you update us when you expect that to grow? And on the Automotive side, the cross-selling, I know it takes 2 to 3 years in terms of these design cycles, but when do you expect, Tom, to see the payoff on the Automotive side of things?

headline: TE Connectivity Ltd., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, Matt, Automotive, as you know, the cycle is a little bit longer, not as long as it used to be as everybody is designing faster these days, but I would say '18. That's when these nice wins are going to really start to come in, and so that you'll s
componenttext: I think, Matt, Automotive, as you know, the cycle is a little bit longer, not as long as it used to be as everybody is designing faster these days, but I would say '18. That's when these nice wins are going to really start to come in, and so that you'll see it in the auto revenue line. In the industrial line, I think, it will follow kind of industrial production. The design win nature there is very different. It's like the industrial market in general, much more fragmented, smaller revenue per design. So in there, it continues to build scale in the nonauto products, and make sure that we're growing with or slightly better than the market. But auto is where you can get significant chunks of business for design. So we really feel good about that. We're a little disappointed in the industrial market side of it, but still very, very excited about the prospects of having Sensors in the portfolio. And what it does for us and every customer, every big OEM, we always have a nice seat at the table. But it's like you get a bigger seat, sometimes a bigger table because it brings in the integrated solution opportunities. You've heard us talk about that, we've had some tremendous design wins in Automotive with that. And it's starting to lend itself, I think, in the aerospace market. Terrence has talked before about the medical market when you pull together our interventional capability along with our core connector, fueling and protect, and now, miniaturized sensors. So it's a pretty robust portfolio that we have that should bolster our growth rate in industrial.

componenttext: Sure. Well into it, as you would expect. And I expect in the not-too-distant future, we'll be making a choice. But it's not over till it's over, but pleased with how things are running in the interim. Very pleased. So haven't really skipped a beat.
